PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. I refer the Minister to Mr Keating's comments last week when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Young people are the nation's future. Our success as a nation depends upon their skills and resources and the degree of commitment of this society.

I ask the Minister: with that background, why did the Government allow youth unemployment to rise to such appalling levels, the highest since statistics were recorded—34 per cent overall, 45 per cent in Victoria and 46 per cent in South Australia—and, in the light of those awful figures, does the Government have any plans to reduce this ongoing tragedy which even the Premier of Victoria described as a national disgrace and a calamity?

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me say that the unemployment figures released last week generally were pretty horrifying and pretty tragic—
—Cut out your super levy.
—I am sorry?
—Cut out your superannuation levy for a start.

—The interjection sadly indicates the banality of the debate about a very serious issue. Let me say, first of all, that the overall unemployment figure accepted by the Government, not with any pleasure, at the time of the last Budget, was that unemployment could rise to 10.75 per cent before coming down. That was in the last Budget statement and that was one of the unfortunate things that we had to face up to. In terms of youth unemployment, let me just say this: that is the more tragic edge of the overall unemployment situation, although the unemployment situation for adult males is also—
—Yes. At 45, it would be tragic too.

—Unless you are in the Senate, Senator Lewis. The unemployment situation for adult males is also serious. Senator Hill comes in and says that this is a tragic situation, with which I agree, and he asks what the Government will do about it.
—Who caused it?
—A number of things have led to this situation. We have been through a deep recession in this country—
—The engineered recession, you know.
—Plenty of other countries have been through deep recessions—
—Your Government caused it.

—The answer is that the honourable senator's great hero in the United Kingdom, Margaret Thatcher, led Britain into recession, and honourable senators opposite are still prescribing policies which belong to the 1970s—which were invented by Margaret Thatcher at that time—as solutions to these problems.

PARA.TAB: Looking at Dr Hewson's performance over the weekend, he says, `I am going to create two million jobs by the year 2000'. Talk about a vapid attempt to win the Green vote by recycling old promises which nobody has had any confidence in at all! Senator Hill asks what the Government will do about unemployment as if there was an instant response which the Government could make on this issue. We have to face the reality that there is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could resign; that would be something.

—Senator Macdonald says we could resign. That would put him in a job which he has coveted for a long time but, unfortunately, it would not do very much at all for the country. This is an issue of which the Government, of course, is conscious on a daily basis. If we have some proposals which will attend to it, we will announce them, but I do not propose to announce them at Question Time in the Senate.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister seriously saying to the Senate that he as Leader of the Government in this place is not prepared to outline any plan whatsoever to reduce the record high levels of youth unemployment in this country? I give him the opportunity, at a second bite of the apple, to at least make some attempt to explain to the Australian people what his Government will do during its last months of office.
—Mr President, it is not a supplementary question. I have already said that the Government does not make policy in response to Senator Hill in the Senate. We never have and we will not start now.

—Is the Minister for Transport and Communications aware that Optus launched the first phase of its mobile telephone network yesterday? What benefits will flow to customers from this service? Is the launch of this system an indication that the Government's micro-economic reform program in telecommunications is producing positive results?

—Yesterday, Optus Communications, the second telecommunications carrier, began operating mobile services in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory, only four months after it was licensed to do so. I understand it received around 1,500 calls inquiring about the service on that day. Mobile services in Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania are to commence on 15 July and the remaining mobile services are to commence on 15 August.

PARA.TAB: Initially, Optus mobile services will operate on AOTC's analogue cellular system. However, by the second quarter of 1993, it will begin services on its own GSM mobile network. GSM is a digital rather than an analogue cellular mobile telephony standard, which is state-of-the-art technology. This is the first major tangible benefit of the Government's telecommunications reforms. It provides the consumer with a choice of operator and, as Optus rolls out its own network, it will offer better quality and a wider range of services.

Also, the introduction of competition is having an effect on price from the very beginning. For example, a saving of 31 per cent—that is, 20c as compared to 29c—can be made on a 30-second local call under the Optus economy plan compared with the Telecom flexiplan standard. Optus believes that the majority of mobile phone users will save up to 10 per cent on current costs under the three pricing plans.

In the longer term, Optus believes that prices for domestic and international long distance and business network services will drop by 40 per cent in real terms over the first five years of operation and 60 per cent over 10 years. More choice will be available around Christmas this year when Optus proposes to begin offering long distance services from Sydney, Melbourne and here in Canberra.

Over the next five years, Optus plans to spend some $2 billion on designing and building fixed and mobile services. Optus began laying its nationwide optical fibre in March this year. By 1997, it expects that more than 90 per cent of its traffic will be carried on its own network. This large capital expenditure program will flow through to other sectors of the telecommunications network.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister representing the Prime Minister and follows the question asked previously of him by Senator Hill. When the Prime Minister, when he was Treasurer, boasted that he had engineered the recession we had to have, did he take into account the fact that it would lead to record postwar unemployment figures of 10.6 per cent nationally and the absolute disaster of 34 per cent youth unemployment? What policy action, if any, will the Government be taking to address this horrific human tragedy? In particular, will the Government make the necessary financial arrangements with the States to abolish that iniquitous tax on jobs, namely, payroll tax? Will the Government reduce the Budget deficit and hence its borrowing drain on the private sector? Will the Government now scrap its ill-conceived plans for introducing another tax on employment in the form of the superannuation guarantee levy?

—The first part of the question, as usual, is couched in terms which are smart rather than intelligent. Senator Short full well knows that, when the Prime Minister made that remark about the recession, he was talking about reducing the level of growth in the Australian economy, which was unsustainable. He has made comments about what he said since, which the honourable senator is fully aware of. In so far as whether at the time that statement was made there was any intention or understanding in his mind that these levels of unemployment would arise from it, the answer of course is no.
—He just didn't know what he was doing.

—Senator, that is something you would understand. In relation to what Senator Short has described as the ameliorative policies which could be followed, the most ameliorating policy is to return growth to the Australian economy. That is what this Government has been trying to do. We have had 1.5 per cent growth for the last three quarters. The honourable senator and I have had exchanges in the Senate about whether that is likely to improve and what the effects will be in relation to the projections made in the One Nation statement. That is the prime task which the Government has.

PARA.TAB: As distinct from other countries which have similar high levels of unemployment, we do have a fairly reasonably cohesive social security system and safety net here. In so far as the magic wands of payroll tax and so on are concerned, payroll tax has been around in this country for a very long time. I have to proffer the view that if we were to abolish payroll tax tomorrow as, by implication, the honourable senator suggests could be done—and it could not be done tomorrow, particularly under the Opposition's package because it would have to finance it and it would take several years; nor could it be done in terms of the honourable senator's own question about the size of the Budget deficit—I do not think that would provide a solution to the problem which we are all apparently concerned about. I am. In so far as reducing the Budget deficit is concerned, that is totally inconsistent with the honourable senator's suggestion that we abolish payroll tax.

On the third issue, of superannuation, I will say nothing at the present time because it is still under discussion. When those discussions have been resolved the honourable senator can comment about the results.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise whether Australian import restrictions on US products are set at the same standards as United States import restrictions on Australian products? Further, is there evidence that the Australian export industry has been disadvantaged by inequitable import restrictions?

—The impediments to United States trade with Australia simply cannot be compared with the kinds of restrictions Australia continues to face in the United States market and the impact that United States policies have on third country markets of interest to Australia. That is so, notwithstanding the fact that the US is Australia's second largest trading partner in a relationship that works very much to the advantage of the United States, with a balance of trade approximately 2 : 1 in favour of the US.

PARA.TAB: To protect its domestically sensitive industries, the US continues to maintain very significant import restrictions, through not only tariffs but also non-tariff measures. The impact of non-tariff measures on manufacturers is not great, although there are exceptions, such as the provisions of the Jones Act which effectively restrict the transportation of merchandise by water between points in the United States to vessels not only owned and registered in the US, but also built there.

So far as access to the US market for other export commodities—beef, sugar and dairy products other than manufactures—is concerned, the situation is really very serious with the restrictions of import quotas that apply in that area. Australia has access to only around 4 per cent of total US beef consumption and one per cent of the US sugar market and negligible access to the US dairy market. Compounding the situation, particularly for our rural industries, is the aggressive use of export subsidies by the United States, largely for wheat, but also for rice, barley, malt and dairy products.

Australia also faces significant barriers in the US market in relation to services—an area which is sometimes underappreciated and neglected in analysis and commentary—such as telecommunications, banking and insurance, where a whole range of regulations, including at the State level, discriminate against foreign firms generally operating in the US market. In relation to government procurement, the United States has in place `buy America' legislation which currently effectively minimises foreign access to approximately one per cent of that market.

Finally, the United States is very well aware of our concerns, which we have pursued relentlessly over the years. Clearly, some of those concerns over access to the US market and the impact that some US policies have indirectly on Australia in third markets will be ameliorated with a positive outcome to the Uruguay Round. Both of our countries remain wholly committed to that. We can only hope that there will be some results soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Collins, the Minister for Transport and Communications, who is obviously communicating at the moment. By way of preamble, I say that this question was asked of the Prime Minister by Paul Lyneham the other evening, but the Prime Minister failed to provide any answer. Surprisingly, Paul Lyneham let him get away with it. Would the Minister identify any quality programs which Australia is not now receiving through its ABC, SBS or three commercial television networks which will be made available through the introduction of pay TV?
—Frankly, I consider that question ridiculous.
—Mr President—
—I just consider it a stupid question.

—I ask a supplementary question. I must say that, in view of the enormous amount of money that Australia is going to spend, that answer is completely unacceptable. If the Minister cannot identify any quality programs that we are not already getting which pay TV is going to make available, why are we going down this road? If there are no such programs, will not the enormous expenditure on pay TV simply be a waste of resources which could be invested in other ways which would address the very important unemployment problems that the Opposition has been talking about in its questions?

—I imagine that there must be millions of quality programs floating around the world that have not been broadcast on the ABC and SBS; there must be thousands. Whether they will ever be broadcast on pay TV, I do not know. But what I can say about pay TV is what I have always said about pay TV—
—Take it or leave it.

—Take it or leave it. It is an optional service. The fundamental truth about pay TV is that, if people want to pay to watch crud, that is what will be broadcast to them. I am not going to put myself in a position of telling them they cannot have crud, if crud is what they want. I have said that consistently. This superior view that is taken constantly by people who consider—
—Especially the Democrats.

—Not just by the Democrats; but the view of people who consider that the Government should be not only an arbiter of some basic censorship grounds—which I think the Government should be—but also keeper of the culture and should prevent people from having access to what they want is not a view that I will ever adopt. The fundamental truth about pay TV is that, if pay TV does not provide the consumers with what they want, it will go broke.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery on my left of a delegation of young political leaders from the Federal Republic of Germany. I recognise them because all members of the delegation are members of the Bundestag of the Federal Republic. I welcome them to Australia and to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Justice been drawn to press reports in which the New South Wales Minister for Police claims that the Federal Government has a secret plan to ban the possession of guns in private ownership within 10 years? Is this true? If not, what is the Government's attitude to the possession of firearms by responsible shooters in the Australian community?

—I have seen certain press reports attributing to Mr Ted Pickering, the New South Wales Minister for Police, a view which is absolute rubbish, absolutely absurd. He claims that the Federal Government will try to ban the possession of guns and firearms in the community by private citizens some time within the next 10 years forever. That is absolute rubbish. It is a patent attempt to divert the anger of New South Wales shooters away from Mr Pickering, who has been so inept in the handling of the gun control question in New South Wales, announcing every six months that New South Wales gun laws are strict but fair and then a few months later changing them, tightening the screws—no wonder the people in New South Wales are bewildered—and on to the Federal Government.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, it is a fact that an employment pamphlet compiled by DEET in South Australia, acting on the advice of those in the gun industry in that State, did purvey that view from those industry sources. It certainly does not represent Federal Government policy in any manner, shape or form. It is not our intention at all to make into criminals those who hold a valid licence to possess and use firearms under State law.

In fact, the policy of the Federal Government is best demonstrated by my attendance in Hobart on Saturday morning last at the opening training session of a group of people—dedicated shooters, responsible shooters from various sporting organisations, shooting organisations and clubs State wide—who came together to spend a weekend undertaking a training course so that they could become instructors. All of those Tasmanians newly applying for a gun licence under the new legislation will receive training and safety instruction, drawing on the experience and skills of these instructors nominated by their various sporting clubs and organisations. I was very pleased to be at the opening of that training weekend.

I was particularly pleased that that weekend was organised under the auspices and direction of Mr Graeme Norris—a very well known shooter in Tasmania, a man with an international reputation and well known as a competitive shooter worldwide. He has organised these gun safety training seminars on behalf of the Tasmanian community. I put it that way because in Tasmania we have come a long way with responsible shooters bearing their responsibility properly. I am quite sure that in the next 10 years we will end up with not the abolition of private gun ownership but an enhancement of that particular sporting, recreational and competitive activity in a way which emphasises safety and responsibility. That is the aim of the Federal Government and that is our only policy in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Having regard to the fact that the Prime Minister has already ruled out any discount to the ACTU's proposed 4.5 per cent wages claim and today's threat by the ACTU to press for further wage increases, can the Minister indicate to the Senate what the unemployment consequences will be if the superannuation guarantee levy goes ahead, even with a temporarily lower starting rate of 4 per cent for companies with payrolls in excess of $1m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think I would try your patience and exceed the five-minute limit that is put on answers in this chamber if I were to deal with each of the factually wrong premises upon which that question is constructed.

PARA.TAB: In terms of a proper presentation of the facts, it is a grotesquerie to present a question in that form. However, let me say that the superannuation guarantee levy, in whatever form it is finally enacted—and I hope it is in the form that was proposed in the Budget as announced by the Treasurer last year—will do a number of quite significant things to the benefit of this economy. It will introduce, in the first place, a retirement incomes program which will provide for all Australians at a reasonable standard so that they can retire in dignity, irrespective of whether they are privileged white-collar workers or whether they are not privileged white-collar workers but blue-collar workers. It will create a massive pool of investment in Australian industry, in reserves held by those superannuation funds, and it will be a major social reform.

In terms of the allegation about the unemployment figures that an extra levy will impose, I point out that those figures arise from estimates which, in my view, have not been properly justified and which cannot be justified and, in the case of the so-called Treasury estimate, from a program that was put through Treasury at the Opposition's request based on its parameters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it that the Minister is telling the Senate that there will be no job losses as a result of the introduction of the superannuation guarantee levy, even if the full cost burden is borne by employers? Will the Minister be so good as to advise the Senate of any recent discussions or arrangements involving himself, the Prime Minister and the ACTU about any wages freeze or other form of deal to get this legislation through?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is passing strange that the Opposition should have the barefaced arrogance to ask a question of this nature at all. Opposition senators sit there as an alternative to the Government, pretending to be economic managers but with no wages policy whatsoever. We have a wages policy; I will not go to the details of that wages policy.
—Your wages policy has resulted in one million unemployed; so much for your policy.
—Order!

—Mr President, can I just reply to the interjection about our wages policy. Our wages policy has been one of considerable wage restraint voluntarily entered into by the trade union movement with this Government on the basis of an incomes policy through which taxes have been reduced and the social wage has been improved in compensation for a reduction in real wages, and the living standard has been maintained by and large through the whole course of the period of this Government. That is what a wages policy is about. The Opposition has a free for all wages policy as a result of which, if we go back to the last occasion on which it had an opportunity to implement that policy, we had double digit unemployment, double digit inflation and negative growth.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am sure you and the Minister well understand that the question was about the employment consequences of the SGL and any little sleazy deal that has been done in recent days. Instead, what we are getting is a lecture on the failings of the Government's wages policy and some subjective reflections on ours, neither of which has anything to do with the question. I ask you to direct him to be relevant in his answer.
—Order! I remind the Minister to answer the question that Senator Alston asked. However, the Minister was replying to persistent interjections.
—That is right, Mr President, but you are right in drawing my attention to the fact that I should avoid the idiotic interjections from the other side and answer the question.

PARA.TAB: There is no sleazy deal. All of the deals that we have entered into about wages policy have been made public, are public and are a matter of record in terms of their economic performance. But let me just go to the nub of the question. We have a wages policy which will guarantee wage increases in line with the level of inflation in this country or that of our trading partners, whichever is the lesser.

TALK.START.PARA: —Utterly irrelevant.
—It is not utterly irrelevant. Senator Alston asked me about the—
—Order! Senator Alston, you have asked the supplementary question.

—Our wages target is to be no greater than the level of inflation in this country or that of a representative sample of our trading partners, whichever is the least. In the context of that wages policy, the changes in superannuation through the superannuation guarantee levy are to be taken into account when we arrive at what the claim will be for a national wage case increase. This will guarantee that there will be a responsible wages outcome and that wages, consistent with the requirement of the superannuation guarantee levy, will feed a responsible outcome into the wider economic outcomes in the economy.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support been drawn to reports of complaints about the Government's inquiry into the process of tendering for the Australian advanced air traffic system following the hearings on the issue by the Joint Committee on Public Works? Is the complaint correct that the terms of reference for the inquiry were drawn up not by the Government but by the Civil Aviation Authority itself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now making my debut as Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support.
—Your very first on the subject.

—No, I am sorry; that honour belongs to Senator MacGibbon, because he asked me a question under this portfolio in the last sittings. On 5 June, I announced that an independent review would be held into the Australian advanced air traffic system selection process. I also announced that Mr Pat Brazil, a former Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, would chair the review and would be assisted in the course of that review by independent specialist advisers on air traffic control systems and on financial issues.

PARA.TAB: Since that announcement, Mr Brazil has withdrawn as chairman of the review because of what he now regards as a possible conflict of interest. For the information of the Senate, I table the letter from Mr Brazil announcing his withdrawal. It states, inter alia, that only after the announcement, to which he had of course agreed, did it become clear that in his legal firm, which involves over 2,000 people including 217 partners throughout Australia and overseas, there may be a possible conflict of interest. As a consequence of that withdrawal, I am moving apace and expect to announce shortly the replacement for Mr Brazil as chairman of the review.

In the interim, there has been an amount of criticism about this review. It is fair to make the observation that much of the criticism appears not to be about whether the critics want an independent review, but more like the burblings of a lynch mob determined on a victim rather than any real scrutiny and examination in this matter.

Three particular criticisms have been raised. One is that the terms of reference are not sufficient. On that point, the terms of reference are drawn very broadly indeed. In my view, they are comprehensive enough to involve any of the matters that might be raised. In any case, the independent chairman, when selected, will have an ability to modify those terms of reference to make sure that they do not get in the way of, and/or restrict, his ability to inquire into the subject matter.

The second criticism involves a rumour of who might be the technical expert advising this inquiry. On that subject, the population of companies in this world that are expert in this esoteric area is very small indeed. Because there is only a small number, all of them have had dealings at one time or another with each other and with particular governments on this matter. It seems to me, on the face of it, that none of them has a basis on which they are able to be described as uninvolved at any point in this whole process. Nonetheless, these things will be taken on board. The independent reviewer will be consulted on the selection of the technical advisory people and be responsible for the final outcome of the report.

The third criticism has been about the Caesar unto Caesar allegation, that this is a review by the Civil Aviation Authority and that it will report to the Civil Aviation Authority. This will be an independent review. The Civil Aviation Authority board has decided the review should go ahead and supports it, but it will be a genuinely independent review. Naturally, since the Civil Aviation Authority is the statutory body which has the power to make the selection, the review will report to the Civil Aviation Authority. It will report to me as well. The process will be open and transparent and able to be scrutinised in the proper way. I think that in the end it will be a fair and proper process. I hope we can concentrate on getting the inquiry up and running and in due course look at the quality of its product and the findings it makes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to the Marshall Islands scandal and particularly the documents the Minister provided to the Senate when it last met. According to document No. 1, tabled by the Minister on 4 June, his Department in Canberra knew of Senator Sibraa's involvement in the Marshall Islands affair in November of last year. A senior officer in the Washington Embassy immediately noted that Senator Sibraa's letter raised the possibility of the Government of the Marshall Islands having sought Australian Government assistance. The relevant branch officers in Canberra also recognised that the scheme was fraught with negative potential and that the Department had been dragged in only because of Senator Sibraa's request. According to document No. 56, the Department further knew on 3 April, the day after the arrest of Mr Symons and Mr Finch, that Symons was claiming `political connections in Australia'. According to document No. 8, the Department knew on 6 April that Senator Richardson had written a reference for Mr Symons which had been tabled in court. What explanation can the Minister give for the failure of his Department to provide him with information on these matters, which were so politically embarrassing, for nearly six months?

—The circumstances have been explained about a dozen times as to why there was no particular communication with my office on that subject. The matter was dealt with last November when the letter of introduction from Senator Sibraa resulted in Mr Symons turning up in Washington. He was dealt with in Washington in a way which was absolutely responsible and sensible, in the sense that a judgment was made that this was not an issue in which the Australian Government should involve itself. That was obviously the same judgment that was made by officers in Canberra, who annotated various documents flying backwards and forwards with comments to that effect.

PARA.TAB: The matter was dealt with in a routine way. I assume that the reference to the political connection is a reference to the Sibraa letter of introduction rather than there being anything else lying behind it. In all the circumstances of the case, given the preoccupations that I have, it is highly to be expected that the Department would regard this as a matter that could be treated as routine and dealt with in that way, which is exactly the way it did deal with it. We would waste a lot less of the Senate's time if Senator Hill would accept that and treat it accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Government considering the reintroduction of the tax deductible business lunch? What impact would the reintroduction of tax deductible lunches have on the fairness of the taxation system and its vulnerability to rorts?

—I assume the honourable senator has raised this issue because there has been some press publicity and comment about it. The Government, unlike the Opposition, is not considering reintroducing the bad old days of the tax-free lunch. Until quite recently, Opposition spokesmen recognised that they were the bad old days. The Government is not considering doing that because we have not threatened the tourism and hospitality industry with a 15 per cent consumption tax and we do not have to go back to tax rorts to undo the damage which a consumption tax would inflict.

PARA.TAB: Mr Jull, the Opposition spokesman on tourism, has been reported as saying that the restaurant, hospitality and tourism industries have a legitimate case that they would not benefit from the abolition of payroll tax and petrol excise under a consumption tax package of the Hewson variety. Mr Jull recognises that they have a legitimate argument that the GST package will affect their employment capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe that?
—They are Mr Jull's words, not mine. That is a rather belated recognition of the effects of the GST package on business, particularly the tourist and hospitality business.

PARA.TAB: The Treasury analysis on this showed that the price of meals out—that is meals in restaurants and so on—would go up 11.3 per cent as a result of the GST package. Mr Jull has finally seen that that will not be a good thing for the tourism industry and it has certainly recognised that itself. So he now suggests—he is the Opposition spokesman on tourism, not ours—that the Opposition might think about tax deductibility for entertainment expenses. That is an extraordinary suggestion, but it is typical of a number of suggestions which have come from Opposition spokesmen seeking to plug so-called holes in the package.

I remind the Senate that in 1985 the deductibility of entertainment expenses was estimated to cost revenue about $300m a year. If one were to extrapolate inflation from that period to the present time, the figure would be almost double. So the estimate of Mr Jull's proposal in terms of cost would put a funding hole in the GST package of about $600m a year.

Many other businesses, not just the tourism sector, would not benefit from the abolition of payroll tax. I have been asked questions about this here today. Small business is largely exempt from payroll tax throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It flows through on whatever they buy.

—I made the point that small business is exempt from payroll tax. If the honourable senator wants to extrapolate some other loopy conclusions from that he can do so, but I am not going to embark on that course. I am saying that small businesses throughout this country will be turned into tax collectors under the coalition plan. But they are largely exempt from the application of the payroll tax. The abolition of payroll tax and the replacement of it with a 15 per cent GST will have those effects.

PARA.TAB: As industry Minister, I am concerned about other industries which will be hurt by this package. Of course, there are a number in the retail sector, such as dry-cleaning and shoe repairs, where prices are estimated to go up by 10.51 per cent. Books, newspapers and magazines will go up 10.45 per cent. The same sorts of figures apply to newsagents.

There have been a lot of questions asked about the tragedy of unemployment today which have been simply based on exaggerated or misrepresented figures in relation to the picture for those who are actually seeking work and the percentage of those who have not been successful in obtaining jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go and explain that to the unemployed youngsters.

—I understand that. In the last recession there were 40,000 to 45,000 more young people in the 15- to 19-year-old age group unemployed in this country than there are now. The point is that far more young people are in training now than there were in those days. That is a result of structural change which has taken place in the Australian economy. The point about it all in relation to this question is that those opposite are proposing to put a 15 per cent tax on the food and clothing of all of those people, and those opposite cannot escape that fact.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Would the Minister explain to the Senate how his intervention in the Middle East and his continuing attacks on Israel, firstly, will assist the Middle East peace process and, secondly, will advance the Australian interests; or is this just another demonstration of the same naivety which led him to believe that he could rely on the good faith of the murderous Khmer Rouge in Cambodia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a matter of making an attack on anybody; it is a matter of trying to make a constructive contribution from where we stand and with the relationships we have to what is a deeply and seriously intractable problem. I think the situation is best understood in the context in which I described it in a TV interview a couple of days ago when I said that the context, in a nutshell, against which I said what I did was as follows. In the first place we are acutely conscious, as we always have been, of the very great and grave security problems that Israel faces—both external and internal—and the need for Israel to have long term guarantees about that security situation.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, we argue—and I think the rest of the world agrees with us in this respect; indeed, there is a common, united position on this—that the present peace process that is under way is the best possible way, and probably the only way, of guaranteeing that kind of secure future for Israel. We argue, thirdly—and I think not naively in this respect—that there is a constituency for such a peace settlement within the neighbouring Arab countries and within the Palestinian community that has never previously existed. It is a function of lapse of time; it is a function of the end of the Cold War and the realignment of international relationships as a result of that; it is a function, in particular, of the outcome of the Gulf war and the dynamics that have been operating in the region since then. We argue further in that context—and I put this point in Israel—that it is tremendously important that every nation in the region do everything possible within its power to assist that particular peace process and not undermine it or set obstacles to it.

We are concerned, as a great many other countries around the world are concerned—and I can vouch for that on the basis of very direct conversations with some very key Foreign Ministers in that respect—with the continued, very active program of settlement building not just in East Jerusalem but in many other locations on the West Bank and indeed Gaza; with the policy that is being implemented in the West Bank and Gaza; and with these combined with the kind of approach that Israel has adopted across the conference table. The third mentioned of those things is probably less significant than the other two in the particular timing context we are talking about, with the Israeli elections and so on, but the combination of those three factors has been formidable. And there is a very real prospect, in my judgment and in the judgment of a great many other people around the world, that the peace process will collapse if those obstacles are maintained in the way that is the case at the moment. The fragile constituency of moderates within the Arab nations and within the Palestinian community—both within Israel and in the Occupied Territories and beyond—simply cannot be held together if that present conjunction of policy attitudes continues.

I know it is not always popular to say things like this, to say things directly and frankly, even to a country with which we have the kind of relationship that we have had traditionally with Israel. But I want to say in this respect that I really do think it is a little unfortunate, and represents short memory on the part of a number of people, to suggest that, in making these points and making them in the way that I did in the Middle East, this represents either any serious backsliding in terms of the friendly relationship that Australia has with Israel, or any falling short in terms of my own commitment to the position of Israel.

One of my most treasured possessions, on my mantelpiece at home in Melbourne, is a piece of early Roman glass in a case with the following inscription on it: `Presented to Senator Gareth Evans for his outstanding contribution to the campaign to rescind United Nations resolution 3379'. The inscription records that this was in the presence of the Israeli Ambassador and the Chairman of the World Zionist Organisation and is signed `Mark Leibler, President of the Zionist Federation of Australia'. I have also very carefully filed at home—along with a number of other letters to similar effect from people like Leslie Caplan, the head of the Executive Council of Australian Jewry; Shimon Peres in Israel; Isi Leibler himself—a letter from Mr Yitzhak Shamir, to the effect—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask the Minister whether he would like me to recite a few letters that I have received back home, too. It might put it in perspective.
—Order! Senator Walters knows that is not a point of order.

—If Senator Walters has a letter like this from Yitzhak Shamir, I would be only too delighted to see her table it in Parliament. In reference to my and Australia's role in diplomatically working for the rescission of the `Zionism is racism' resolution, he used the following language:

ANSWER.PARA: It took 16 years for the blot—
he is referring to the `Zionism is racism' resolution—
to be removed from the record of the United Nations.

PARA.TAB: Throughout those years, few governments and a few individuals made valiant and consistent efforts to achieve the repeal. I take this opportunity of thanking you personally and the Australian Government for all you did in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Should apologies and personal explanations be made after Question Time or during Question Time?
—There is no point of order. Senator Evans, it is becoming a very long answer.

—I would just like to finish by saying that, among many such exchanges I have had in recent years with various members of the Jewish leadership in Australia, I treasure in particular the following words that were put on the public record from Mark Leibler in Melbourne in 1988 when responding to something I had earlier said critically about the situation in the Occupied Territories and about the position of the PLO. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: Gareth, you make the point that true friendship both requires and accommodates frankness. I agree, and trust that my response to some of your remarks will be accepted in the same spirit.

I make that point because there has been a long tradition of robust and lively debate in the Jewish community in Australia, and between the Jewish community and the Australian Government, over many years. The commitment of this Government to the situation in Israel, to the peace process, to the survival of Israel and to the position of the Jewish community is absolutely unqualified and undiminished. I hope that some of the robust political debate that has been taking place recently, and some of the opportunism of the Opposition in this respect, will not conceal that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I did ask how this will advance Australian interests. That seems to have escaped Senator Evans. I am prepared to concede that his visit was not for anything other than his own self-gratification, but how will it advance Australian interests?

—The interests of every country in the world are affected by the course of events in the Middle East. That was very clear in the response that the Opposition and others made to the emerging situation in the Gulf War. There is an intractable interconnection in all the various complex issues that are running in the Middle East, and the future course of the peace process and the implications of what flows from it are of immense relevance not only to the immediate situation of the people in those countries, and the region as a whole, but indeed to the whole world. There is no doubt that the countries in that region believe that that is so because of the very active way they pursue diplomatically the support of other nations all around the world for the particular issues that are constantly being debated in this context in the United Nations. It is an absolute nonsense to suggest that Australia has no interest in the outcome of these particular issues. If people felt that, I would be very grateful if they ceased to besiege me, from both sides of the fence, with representations constantly to take positions diplomatically, in the UN and elsewhere, on just these issues that we are talking about. People cannot have it both ways.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government and bears upon the tragic crisis of unemployment, including youth unemployment, in Australia today. Has the Government taken up my repeated request that it examine and look at the composition of and participation rate in the paid work force so as to set in place policies which will enable those who desire to leave the paid work force for socially constructive alternatives to do so without undue financial burden to them or to their families?

—Senator Harradine has asked me questions about this over a period. I apologise to Senator Harradine. I consulted with Treasury and others about that some time ago and I thought he was given an answer on that question. If he was not given an answer to his satisfaction, I will pursue the matter again.

PARA.TAB: The fact of the matter is that we do have a high participation rate in Australia which is relevant to the question of overall unemployment figures. In so far as youth unemployment is concerned, which Senator Harradine specifically mentioned, there is of course a changing pattern in relation to the activities which young people are engaged in in Australia now from what there was a number of years ago. Now, about seven or eight out of 10 young people in the 15- to 19-year-old age group are in education or training of some kind; two out of 10 are in the work force. The figures which have been given here dramatically today show that one in 10 of that total age cohort seeking work are actually looking for work and of those, varying from State to State, 34 per cent to 43 per cent or 45 per cent—I think the figures were—were actually in the category of not having obtained work.

Those are the figures. They represent a changing pattern of course in the participation of younger people in various activities from the 1982-83 recession when the number of people unsuccessful in obtaining work—looking for work and being unsuccessful—was higher in absolute terms than it is even at the present time. These changes have taken place and they are all relevant to the participation rate. I will see whether I can get further information about that for Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Minister aware of the concern of the Queensland Catholic education department that it is facing a shortfall of $3m this calendar year and $5m for the next calendar year, caused by an award restructuring in which the State Government, the Federal Government, and the Catholic education department were to fund on a proportional basis any increase in costs on that structural reform? In relation to the Commonwealth contribution, it has not met its full proportion of the teachers' wages and it has not made any contribution towards holiday leave loading, workers compensation, superannuation or long service leave. Can the Minister inform the Senate what action the Government proposes to take to make up the shortfall?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —When I first heard this question I was a bit amazed that there was a need to make up a shortfall for award restructuring purposes, because the whole purpose of award restructuring is that the increases paid are met by virtue of the efficiency gains due to award restructuring. I understand that this refers to a broader principle of award restructuring in education than applies elsewhere in the work force. Therefore, I do not know that it is fair for Senator Boswell to include in his question references to annual leave loading, superannuation, long service leave and those other matters that he referred to.

PARA.TAB: However, I am advised by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training that Commonwealth funding for all non-government schools is linked to a percentage of the community standards test, and that Catholic schools are currently funded at 41 per cent of the community standard, which will increase to 47 per cent of the community standard by the year 2000. The award restructuring assistance program was introduced to provide the Commonwealth's share of the cost of award restructuring. I understand from a chart provided to me by the Department that in 1991 that was an amount of $3.632m and this year it is an amount of $4.838m, making a total over those two years of $8.470m, for the Queensland Catholic school system. In addition, I can inform Senator Boswell that the real increases awarded to Catholic schools every year from 1985 to the year 2000 assist in meeting the costs of award restructuring.

That may not be a full answer to all the points that Senator Boswell has raised in his question, but it is at least a brief summary of the main points. If he finds it agreeable, I will obtain a more detailed answer and put it down at the end of Question Time tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware that Indonesian courts have imposed sentences of up to 10 years on organisers of the protest march in Dili on November 12 last year? This stands in contrast to the sentences of 20 months or less given by military tribunals to officers connected with the killing of unarmed marchers on the same occasion. Does the Minister believe the sentences are reasonable under international law and according to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and associated covenants?

—Although it is difficult to make a definitive comment at this stage, given that not all of the civilian trials have been completed and also that a number of the civilians and military who have been sentenced have said they will appeal, nonetheless I am disturbed at the apparent discrepancies so far in the sentences that have been administered for the civilians and the military. It is the case that sentences in the civilians' trials have ranged from six months to 10 years imprisonment while sentences in the military trials have ranged from eight to 18 months.

PARA.TAB: The trials of the military personnel are at least indicative of the commitment by the Indonesian authorities to follow through the process foreshadowed earlier this year by the Military Honour Council which was established to investigate the role of the military in the killings. These trials are, of course, in addition to the disciplinary action that was taken earlier this year resulting in the discharge of three officers from military service and the removal of three officers, one temporarily, from positions within the established armed forces structure.

We do recognise that much of the action taken by the Indonesian Government in response to the Dili killings, particularly the public acknowledgment of wrongdoing by the military, does constitute unprecedented action in Indonesia. But, as I have already said, we do believe it is important that those responsible for the killings be appropriately punished.

As to the kind of action that the Australian Government has taken in this respect, I remind Senator Bourne that, from the time we first became aware of the killings, we made known at the most senior levels in Indonesia our view that those responsible should be appropriately punished and that no-one should be detained or punished for non-violent political activities.

More recently, I have instructed our Embassy in Jakarta to convey our reaction to the disparities in sentences in the terms which I have just outlined. In the course of a general discussion about Australia-Indonesia relations with His Excellency Radius Prawiro, the very senior Indonesian Minister who is presently in Australia, I yesterday indicated to him that, notwithstanding our appreciation of the overall response to the situation, we were worried by the discrepancies in the sentences.

I say finally,to clarify it for the record, that in conveying these concerns now, and in any other conversations I have had or representations we have made, we are not seeking of course to interfere in any way with the Indonesian judicial process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 June, Senator Boswell asked a question of me as Minister representing the Prime Minister. It related to suggested talks with Mr Ole Jacobsson, Chairman of the Danish meat conglomerate Danpork. Let me just try to answer a number of subsidiary bits of the question. I have discussed Senator Boswell's question with the Prime Minister briefly. He did not meet with the Danish Minister for agriculture. He did meet with Mr Jacobsson. He says that any matter relating to his discussions with Mr Jacobsson was a private matter.
—Pigs might fly!
—Of course it was a private matter. All I can say about it is what in fact Mr Jacobsson said about it. I quote from a report in the Age which I saw. The report stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Jacobsson, who accompanied the Danish Agricultural Minister on the trip, said he met Mr Keating in private `just to say hello'. He said he could not recall whether the plans for the `revolutionary' pig abattoir were discussed. `He (Mr Keating) is not participating in any meetings on this,' he said.
On the other supplementary parts of the question, Senator Boswell asked me:
Does Danpork want to bring in pig breeding material from Europe?

I do not know the answer to that, but it is certainly not something which has been addressed in the press statements put out by the New South Wales Premier, the New South Wales Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs and, more recently, the comments of Mr Yabsley about their success in obtaining this venture in Australia. Senator Boswell also asked:
Is the Australian partner the New South Wales company Brown and Hatton . . .
I understand that there is a joint venture of which the Australian partner is the company Brown and Hatton. He also asked:
Has the Prime Minister's family company invested in Brown and Hatton?

The answer to that is, technically, no. The Prime Minister's family company has invested in the joint venture company, which is composed of Danpork and Brown and Hatton. The Prime Minister's returns and declarations of interest have been published in relation to that matter.

PARA.TAB: By way of conclusion, I think it is very encouraging to see this development. The New South Wales Government has been—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister is involved in the pig industry!

—No. I think it is encouraging to have a Prime Minister who invests his savings in a business which will lead to very substantial exports from this country, the introduction of new technology into Australia, and employment growth, which is what this investment will lead to. It is in sharp contrast to people who spend their savings on Ferraris, which are not exactly productive investments in this country. They are examples of conspicuous consumption, which is not something this country particularly wants at present. So they are the answers to the particulars of the honourable senator's question. It is a very good development and it has been—
—But everyone else is going broke doing it.

—Senator Macdonald always has half smart interjections. The New South Wales Government has been boasting from one end of New South Wales to the other about this development, because it will introduce a lot of new technology into the business by the people who run the business—the pre-eminent people in the business in the world. The New South Wales Government is very bullish about this project, and so it ought to be.

PARA.TAB: Old Macdonald had a farm, I know, but that is not the honourable senator. The fact of the matter is that technology in the pig industry in this country has not been up to scratch worldwide. There are enormous opportunities in developing new technology in this country, particularly in slaughtering. That is what is happening. I very much welcome it. I think it is a very sound investment. The Opposition in Canberra should welcome it as much as the Government in New South Wales, including the Liberal Party and the National Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the additional response given by Senator Button to the question asked by Senator Boswell on 3 June 1992, relating to pig breeding material and Pleuron Pty Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button said that technically the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, did not have an investment in this pig operation. I thank him for the word `technically', because that is the word that enables the Prime Minister to escape from a deliberate misleading of the Parliament in relation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: I did not say that. I said technically—
—That is not a point of order.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume is not going to make a speech on the basis of—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the Hansard.

—I note the Minister's sensitivity on this matter. This is a very serious problem indeed. The Prime Minister gave an indication, an impression, in his statement of declaration of interest that he had simply a small investment of little consequence, he was not a director of any companies involved and he had no control.

PARA.TAB: The facts which have slowly emerged from this matter, despite the fact that there have been no proper company returns from any of the operating companies in this group ever since they were formed—and about which we have heard nothing from Senator Tate in response to my question a fortnight ago—and which we have been able to establish quite clearly, are that Mr Keating effectively misled the Parliament by saying very simply, `I have no control and it is simply an investment'. The fact is that his family company has a half interest. He shares ownership and de facto control of Euphron Pty Limited which has a direct involvement through Brown and Hatton in this pig operation.

Not only that but Mr Keating, while technically not a director of Euphron, has appointed a nominee, the company secretary of Pleuron, to be the director on his behalf in Euphron, despite the fact that the person involved, Mr Coudounaris, has not one share and has no interest whatsoever in either Pleuron or Euphron. Here we have a situation where the Prime Minister has a direct and significant interest, has a nominee on the board, yet misleads the Parliament by pretending that the investment he has is something like a few shares in BHP.

The reason this is significant is that we now have an admission that he did have conversations with the Danish people in not only his private capacity but also the capacity in which he was acting when in One Nation he announced the change in foreign investment review policy:

SPEECH.PARA: First, the thresholds, below which foreign investment proposals are not examined in certain sectors of the economy, set out below, are increased to $50m, from below $3m for rural properties. . .
He then went on to say:
The Government will cease to examine proposals by foreign interests. . . in the sectors set out below. . . or establishment of a new business with a total investment of less than $50m.
Of course, the proposals set out below are rural properties and agriculture. The One Nation statement, which was issued just three months ago in February 1992, went on to say:
The liberalisation of the foreign investment guidelines will lead to new projects being established in the economy which would otherwise have started later, or not at all.

It is interesting to note that Mr Keating took out his interest in this pig operation in May 1991 while he was still Treasurer and the Minister in charge of the Foreign Investment Review Board. I wonder whether he was acting in his private capacity as a beneficial owner of a large slice of this pig operation when in the One Nation statement he changed the guidelines which exempted this matter from FIRB review or in his position as the Prime Minister of Australia. I wonder when he was talking to Mr Jacobsson whether he had the capacity to change hats with the same skill as he demonstrates when he enters this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: It is incredible that the Prime Minister of Australia, when making such a fundamental change to the FIRB guidelines, should not have disclosed his interest in this matter. It is a disgrace. It outlines clearly the farce of the present disclosure arrangements under which the Prime Minister has sneaked his investment through the cover of a claim that he had no control and he did not have an interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I am not sure of the number of the relevant standing order, but it is clearly a point of order. It is clearly against the parliamentary procedures to impute motive to other people, either in this chamber or in other chambers. Senator Michael Baume is quite clearly imputing wrong motive to Mr Keating.
—Order! I was worried about one word, but I will allow Senator Baume to continue.

—Thank you, Mr President. As I was saying, there was no declaration by this Prime Minister of his clear and significant interest in this matter. The revelations in his declaration of interest are meaningless in respect of this matter. No-one reading that declaration of interest could have had the vaguest idea that the Prime Minister would face the prospect of substantial benefit from the removal, in the One Nation statement, of the FIRB inhibitions in respect of this kind of project. This kind of scandalous behaviour by the Prime Minister, given the declaration he made, hides the reality of his family company's half-ownership of Euphron Pty Ltd, the front he has as a director of that company and the major benefit he stands to gain.

PARA.TAB: The last time the House of Representatives was sitting the Prime Minister managed to have a great deal of fun about the fact that his family company was three months late in putting in its return. During that week I asked the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) whether he would examine the matter of companies in that group not having put in a return for the three years since they were formed, and I mentioned a few of them. In fact, it is now evident that the whole group has not put in returns to the Australian Securities Commission, despite the fact that there are clear legal requirements to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —How far back does that go?

—Basically these company structures were formed in 1988 and 1989. It is clear that the Prime Minister has sought to hide the significance of his ownership. It is also clear that the companies, by flouting the company law, have sought to hide from the public the reality of their position. I do not know what the Prime Minister has to gain from maintaining this attempted secrecy. I do not know what the companies have to gain from flouting the corporate law. All I do know is that the Prime Minister is involved in this continual campaign of, let us say, reticence on the part of the companies. He is an influential shareholder. He has done nothing, despite our probing, to encourage that group to report properly and to meet the requirements of the law. Of course, apart from all of that, the Prime Minister has shown utter contempt for the Parliament by failing to declare his massive interest in this situation in the One Nation statement.

PARA.TAB: It is even worse than that, because in recent times there has been a volume of dumping of Canadian pork onto the Australian market—dumping that has destroyed the viability of large sections of the Australian pork industry. People in the industry have been going broke. Many people are wondering why the Prime Minister should be investing in a business such as this when so many of his fellow investors in this industry are suffering bankruptcy and disaster while the Canadian pork imports have been continuing.

The Government, no doubt, will consider what its actions will be about these pork imports. The Australian public has a right to know what benefit the Prime Minister will get from any change in that policy. When a statement like this is brought down, the public has a right to know what benefit the Prime Minister will get. The public has a right to know the status of the companies in this group, which has been hidden from the public gaze by a remarkable dilatoriness in its failure to submit any reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is the only one getting anything out of One Nation.

—That is a good point. As Senator Tambling says, the Prime Minister clearly appears to be the only person in Australia getting anything out of One Nation. He got his pig proposal through without its having to go to the FIRB.
—Whose snout is in the trough?

—As Senator Parer says, it is clear whose snout is in the trough, in keeping with the traditions of the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales. This matter is a disgrace. The Prime Minister's attempt to divert attention from it when we were last sitting is a disgrace. The failure of Senator Tate in this chamber to respond to my questions shows either monumental incompetence or a preparedness to ride along with the requirements of his Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: This matter will enrage, quite properly, the people of Australia. It will particularly concern those people who have gone broke in this industry and all Australians who take the view that they expect standards of behaviour far higher in their politicians than this Prime Minister is prepared to present.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a clear conflict of interest in the involvement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the pig industry. I ask honourable senators who are present: has the Prime Minister come clean in Cabinet and in Caucus about that conflict of interest? I ask Senator Cooney, who is looking very despondent on the other side of the chamber, and other Government senators: did the Prime Minister, before the One Nation statement, disclose to Caucus that he had a particular significant interest in the pig industry and, in particular, an exemption from foreign investment review for which he was the principal Minister, as Treasurer, when he took out this investment? Did he disclose to the Caucus that he would have this personal gain—that a company in which he had an interest had such a gain—and that he had this conflict of interest?

PARA.TAB: I ask Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate: did the Prime Minister disclose his personal interest to Cabinet before Cabinet presumably endorsed the One Nation statement? This is a conflict of interest that involved $400,000, which is a huge investment for most Australians, being put into one industry, one company—a half share in that company. Did he disclose that clear and significant interest of a personal nature before the One Nation statement was put to Cabinet?

I say to Senator Beahan across the chamber that we already have a clear precedent of a leader of a government who has pulled the wool over his Cabinet and Caucus. I am referring to the precedent of ex-Premier Burke, who made financial decisions in which he had a personal interest and in which the Labor Party had a direct interest. But he did not disclose those investments of the Western Australian Government to his own Cabinet. It came out only when the Royal Commission made findings of that fact. The Deputy Premier and his other Cabinet colleagues all said, `We were not told, and if we had even guessed at the time that there was such a personal motivation on the part of the Premier, we would have opposed that massive investment in Argyle'.

I say to honourable senators opposite: not only should there be answers for forthcoming questions, such as those that have been put very properly by Senator Baume, but also I believe that Labor Party senators ought to ask about their own procedures in Caucus and Cabinet to ensure that the profession of the avoidance of personal interests by Ministers in this Parliament ought to be upheld.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not disclose this publicly.
