—On a point of order, Mr President: that is a totally unparliamentary remark and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—I ask that it be withdrawn. I am going to say it for the last time: cease interjecting.

—I withdraw, but I do not know why that was taken the wrong way. I meant that Senator Walters is a professional parliamentarian. She has been interjecting for years. She does so professionally. I do not hold any grudge against her for that. That is what I meant. If Senator Short has the sort of mind which suggests that I meant something else, that is bad luck for him. What I was saying before I was interrupted yet again was that two weeks ago you tried to make capital out of the fact that the returns of this company had been filed late.
—The group's companies.
—I understand what you are saying. You fell on your nose about that, Senator Baume.
—Not at all.
—Order! Senator Baume, you have already spoken.
—He is addressing me.
—Order! All interjections are unparliamentary. You are consistently doing it.
—You led with your chin—

—I take a point of order, Mr President. I have been continually addressed by the Leader of the Government in the Senate—addressed personally. Everything is supposed to be through you, Mr President, not directed at members of the Opposition. If they respond, it is as if the Minister is tempting us to respond.
—Senator Button, address your remarks through the Chair. There are still too many interjections.

—This is not a debate without some political content; let us be frank about that. This is the kitchen in which we all have to reside, friends. It is sometimes hot in here. So do not let us run away from that. The fact of the matter is that two weeks ago—I will leave Senator Baume out of this—the Opposition fell flat on its face politically over this issue. Opposition members are trying to regurgitate this issue today. The essential issues in this are simply these: in terms of the requirements of the register, the Prime Minister has been absolutely diligent in declaring his interests into the register. That is something which is required of him and which he has done. That was done well before the third threshold issue was raised in One Nation. He had been declaring his interests regularly before then.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume tried to imply today that, in respect of this group of companies, the Prime Minister had been associated with them for three years, or four years—since 1988. I know, of my own knowledge, that that is not correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that.

—If you do not mind, I will handle what I am saying. If you have any intelligent contribution, you can offer it later—but I doubt it very much. The implication was clearly that the Prime Minister had been associated with these companies since 1988. That is not correct.
—It was 1991.
—You said 1988, Senator.
—The companies were formed in 1988. Why don't you listen.
—I know what you said. The implication was that he had been associated with them since then.
—No.

—It is all right for you people to say no. An implication is something which somebody draws from comments which are made. If you do not understand the English language, bad luck, but that is what it means.
—I didn't expect you to be so incompetent.

—Senator, really! I do not want to come back to your role in all this. I mean, I understand it, and you are very excited about it. But do not get excited about it; it is not a matter of great importance. The relevant matters are on the register, and that is the important thing. They have been declared, as I said, diligently by the Prime Minister. To attempt to drag all sorts of other extraneous issues into it has the flair of desperation which this Government—
—Ha, ha!

—I was going to say that this Government is used to this sort of thing from this Opposition—that sort of air of desperation about trying to extend an issue beyond its real merits. I will respond at a later stage to any points that Senator Baume raised which might purport to be factual. I cannot do that on the basis of my present understanding or knowledge. But I am able to respond in the way I have on the points that Senator Baume has raised and point to the incorrect assumptions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) did answer a question that I asked, but he omitted the answer to a very important part of it: does Danpork want to bring in any pig breeding material such as embryos or semen?
—I said I didn't know.

—The Minister said that he did not know. It is a very important part of the question because there is mystery swine fever in Canada and also in Denmark, where the Danish company, Danpork, has its headquarters. Brown and Hatton is half-owned by the Prime Minister, and Brown and Hatton owns a half-share in Danpork Australia Pty Ltd. So when Senator Button responds to the points that Senator Baume made, I ask him to take up this very important issue. He mentioned that he has spoken to the Prime Minister about his contact with Mr Jacobsson and Mr Toernaes. I also ask Senator Button to ascertain whether Brown and Hatton is bringing in any breeding material. Also, has Brown and Hatton made any application, or does it intend to apply, to bring any live pigs to Australia? If so, that would suggest a process that bypasses any normal quarantine procedures. I think those are two questions that require answers in this Senate.

—I wish to comment on what has clearly become a hugely embarrassing issue for the Labor Party—clear not only from the comments that Senator Button made today but also from the expressions on the faces of honourable senators opposite. What has been revealed is not only the conflict of interest issue that Senator Baume has raised and outlined so clearly to this chamber, but also—and this is also causing major embarrassment in the Labor Party—the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is a very wealthy man. We have a Labor Prime Minister who is a very wealthy man.
—Dear oh dear!
—There is nothing wrong with being a wealthy man. I know plenty of Labor lawyers who have become wealthy men. But there is something extraordinary—
—All your mates are rich.

—He is Senator Burns's mate. He voted him in as Prime Minister. He is Senator Burns's mate, and he is a wealthy man. The point I am making is this: we do not object to Mr Keating being a wealthy man; we object to a Prime Minister who goes around attacking people on this side of the chamber, and people in the wider community, for being wealthy. This whole debate has revealed that we have a Prime Minister who is certainly no Curtin, who is certainly no Chifley, and who is probably no Gough, to be quite frank. He is a very wealthy man. He has assets somewhere between $1.4m and $2m. We know that he has a major investment of $400,000 in this piggery. He has a very expensive home in Elizabeth Bay, and I have no problems with that. If Mr Keating has the money, he is perfectly entitled to it. On top of that, as he has been in this Parliament for a very long period, he has accumulated an awful lot of superannuation.

PARA.TAB: I say to those opposite that this Prime Minister has fallen in a heap because he has gone around portraying himself as a true blue member of the working class. He has gone around attacking people on this side of the chamber for what he alleges are their assets. We have found that we have the wealthiest Labor Prime Minister in history—a millionaire, possibly a number of times over. The public will at last be able to record what sort of man this person is: a silvertail; a man who postures around the community holding himself out as the person who is best suited to represent the interests of the toiling Australians of all classes. To use his own expression, he is a very wealthy spiv.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp got it wrong, I think. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) does not represent any particular class. We have heard the old class divisions argument from the other side; that is dead and gone. This Prime Minister represents all Australians—that is the test. If a person is to be taken to task for having money—as the Prime Minister has been on this occasion—where will that get us? If the other side persists with this attitude, any working person in Australia who happens to make a success of his trade and who happens to make a success of his profession, but who is not classified by the other side as a person worthy of being wealthy, will be condemned out of hand. What is wrong with the Prime Minister of Australia successfully carrying on a business enterprise? This is the man who, in conjunction with the ACTU, has brought a magnificent change to the industrial culture of this country.

PARA.TAB: I think the most pertinent speech from the other side came from Senator Boswell. That seems to be the issue. In effect, Senator Boswell is saying, `All right, if he wants to conduct a business, so be it—indeed, that is something to be encouraged—but make sure that when he is importing material it does not in some way affect what we have in Australia; make sure that quarantine provisions are properly complied with'. That is the issue in this case. Senator Boswell is saying, `Thank heavens we have an Australian who is producing, who is out there showing the way'.

Recently, in Victoria, Mr Kennett bought a knitting mill. That was put forward in that State as something to be proud of. Here is a person who hopes to be Premier of that State, who went into private enterprise—as the Prime Minister did on this occasion—and who made an attempt to get industry going. That seems to be a matter for condemnation from those on the other side. A person who is trying to give a lead is to be condemned for doing just that—for doing what Australia is meant to do.

Senator Baume says that in some way the Prime Minister should have made this patent. Of course, the whole point of the ASC, the whole point of our corporate law as it now stands, is to enable that to be done. That is what was done on this occasion. Those opposite found out about the Prime Minister and his activities because they read the public record, just as anyone else might do. Those opposite have said, `The Labor Party is a party where nobody is supposed to be wealthy. The Labor Party is a party that should not encourage enterprise in spite of its record and the fact that it does. Therefore, if we point out that this Prime Minister has money; if we point out that this Prime Minister has invested in industry; if we point out that this Prime Minister, through his own efforts, has made money and invested it in a successful enterprise, that will somehow be looked upon by Australians as wrong'.

Australians are proud of the industry that is properly conducted, and proud of somebody who actually produces things. They are not proud of the people of the 1980s who did not produce things, but they are proud of people who show them how to take something by the scruff of the neck and make a productive enterprise out of it.

What we have here, as Senator Button has so truly said and as those opposite so well know, is a political ploy to try to give a character to the Prime Minister that he does not possess. May I just develop that point. Is he a person who has ideas? Yes. Is he a person who can make things work? Yes. Is he a person who gives a great lead to Australia? Yes. Is he the person who will get Australia out of its present hole? Yes. Is he a person who is dishonest, not frank and who does not make transparent what ought to be transparent? No. We on this side are proud of the man who gives us a lead, proud of the Prime Minister of Australia, and we will be proud of him as Prime Minister after the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a couple of points. I do not think anybody on this side of politics gets any joy out of criticising the misfortune of anybody else. This debate is not about that; this debate is about the conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), his disguising of his commercial activities—
—It is about digging dirt.

—No, it is not, but I have noticed Senator Beahan smirk and laugh and cheer and jeer when his scungy mates are pouring buckets on this side of the Parliament. That gives you a real cheer, that gives a blush to your cheeks, but the moment the man whom you helped achieve the prime ministership of this country is even questioned on his commercial activities, transactions and disclosure of that conduct, you find yourself in a very uncomfortable circumstance.
—Order! Let us take the remarks through the Chair.

—Mr Deputy President, what I find fascinating is that this Prime Minister refers to John Hewson as `a traitor to his class'. He draws a distinction between having a Ferrari in the garage and a mantelpiece covered in French clocks as if one is respectable and one is not. The only difference is that John Hewson has not sold a Ferrari to Warren Anderson, it is still in his garage, and he sure did not make any capital gains tax from leaving it there. Perhaps driving a Ferrari suits him and perhaps having a pig farm suits the Prime Minister of those opposite.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to look at the economic record of this Government. We have a Prime Minister who, during his period as Treasurer, managed to make himself a multi-millionaire while at the same time creating a million unemployed. That takes talent; that takes real class; that takes panache and style—a dash and flair, as the Prime Minister of those opposite would say.

TALK.START.PARA: —It shows where the priorities are.

—That is absolutely right. The difference is that Dr Hewson brought his wealth with him; this Prime Minister had a capacity to generate it while he was in the Parliament. That takes a rare skill. This Prime Minister seems to be a real chameleon. I think it was New Year's Eve 1986 on Southern Cross III that this Prime Minister was celebrating at a lavish party with Alan Bond, Laurie Connell, Warren Anderson and all the people who are now called crooks and spivs by those on the other side because suddenly it is not respectable to be friends with them—fair-weather travellers.
—Was Richo there, too?
—Senator Richardson at a later date was out fishing with all those people and he thought that was pretty classy, pretty ritzy, pretty up-market and fun.
—Mates.

—They were mates then. I love the expression `mates'. They are mates when they have plenty of dough and they are rubbing shoulders with them and they are mates when they stab them in the back, as old Bill Hayden will tell us. It is a very adaptable word. I observed the indignation of Senator Cooney who, with a very difficult brief, valiantly struggled to find some justification for the conduct of the Prime Minister. It was very amusing to observe Senator Peter Walsh, when he was on the front bench, in various stages of sobriety attacking me, Senator Durack, Mr Howard or anybody else on our side who took his fancy that morning or afternoon. The only person who was not amused was Senator Tate, to his credit.
—Oh!
—I am sure that he would not be embarrassed if I told everyone that he came and apologised on one occasion for the conduct of Senator Walsh and some of his colleagues.
—I am embarrassed now.

—I am sorry, I misunderstood Senator Tate; he is embarrassed, but his preselection is over and it was a long time ago. It was before he was hardened that he had to grind a poor soul under his boot. Those were the days when he was not long out of the seminary and he understood what it meant to see people unfairly treated.

PARA.TAB: It is in that circumstance that I well remember how Senator Chipp, the honourable Democrat leader, joined us in censuring the then Minister for Finance for misleading the Senate by alleging that I was involved in some nefarious way with a fellow called Theo Christo Moll, a person whom I had never heard of. He could have waved at me from my Weeties and I would not have recognised him. The only thing Senator Walsh did not do was mention that this man was also supposed to be associated with Lionel Murphy.

That was all good fun; that was good sport. It did not matter that it was in the headlines; it did not matter that my family was being damaged; and it did not matter that it was affecting my kids at school. That was a big laugh; that was a big joke. Government members were all cheering and laughing. Walshie was down at the non-members' bar getting half cut and amusing people with his stories of what he had done in the Senate.

The moment this Prime Minister comes under a little scrutiny, the first time he is questioned not about why he put his return in late but why the returns were not in at all—and the distinction is that in one case we find out the facts and in the other they are disguised—and the moment there is any questioning of his propriety and conduct, there is a great deal of indignation and rage. Even Senator Button loses his cool and, in a moment of rage, says some very unkind, unfair and cutting things about the defenceless Senator Michael Baume, who is doing no more than exposing to the public the truth. I hope that the next time those opposite feel like a frolic with dishonesty, untruths, lies and criticisms of those on this side, and they think it is good sport, they will think again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My friend on the other side of the chamber Senator Cooney has alleged that we on this side are outraged that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) might be a wealthy man. Certainly not. We wish there were a million more wealthy men in this country.
—And women.

—And women. But what we on this side of the chamber and others are outraged about is that we have a Prime Minister who runs the risk of being seen to mix private profit with public practice. That is the shame of this whole scandal.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Baume has so eloquently said, we find that we have a Prime Minister who, just months before agreeing to a joint venture agreement with Danpork, a Danish company, comes before the Parliament and boasts in his One Nation statement of how his changes to the FIRB rules and the threshold on foreign investment will `lead to new projects being established in the economy which would otherwise have started later or not at all'. He must have known! It is the only thing the Prime Minister got right. The incredible prescience of the Prime Minister, because the deal was already in the bank.

Maybe it is all coincidental; maybe there is no conspiracy; maybe it all just happens to be a happy coincidence of events. Maybe. But on this side of the chamber we have our doubts. We have our doubts as to the suggestion that maybe this was all just fortuitous. We have our doubts that maybe the happy discovery of raising the Foreign Investment Review Board threshold had absolutely nothing to do with Danpork. We have our doubts about those things because we on this side of the chamber are disturbed gravely at the possibility that a Prime Minister could be seen to be doing this.

The Prime Minister was also concerned at the possibility that he might be seen to be doing this. That is why we do not find him saying in the One Nation statement, `Oh, by the way, people, I happen to be negotiating at the moment for one of these deals that would just happen to fall within this new threshold'. Of course we do not find him saying it in there. Why? Because he is as disturbed as we are by the possibility that he would be seen to be double dealing. We on this side of the chamber would like to give the Prime Minister the benefit of the doubt, but the only way we can do it is if the Prime Minister and the Government come clean over this Danpork deal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to enter this debate, but I think it is important to make clear a few matters. The constant allegation that has come from the other side is that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has somehow been disguising his business affairs—I think that was a term actually used by Senator Crichton-Browne—but, in fact, as far as the parliamentary registration of his interests is concerned, it is perfectly in order and impeccable, and he has made it known to the electors of Australia precisely what his interest is.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is extremely important to affirm, as I have done several times at Question Time, that the Australian Securities Commission is an absolutely independent body which will deal in an even-handed way with the question of the late lodgment of returns. The Prime Minister's family company, Pleuron, was said to have been late in the lodging of its returns. Some associated companies in which investments were held by Pleuron were also mentioned. Then it was disclosed that Dr Hewson and Mr Reith themselves had been associated with companies which had failed to lodge returns in a timely way.

What did that lead Senator Baume to say later in debate that same day or the next day? He said, `Maybe this could be properly regarded as being of little consequence'. Senator Baume will recall using that term. When it was seen in perspective, that both sides were involved and that this question unfortunately related to thousands of Australian companies which ought to have put in their returns on time, Senator Michael Baume suggested to the Senate, and I agreed, that this may be regarded as a matter of little consequence. That is exactly what Senator Baume said.

The latest phase is talk about the piggery. I believe that for once Mr Yabsley, the State Minister in New South Wales, has it right. He is dealing with this matter in a much cooler way, a way which is much more directed towards the employment opportunities of people in a country district of New South Wales—which should appeal to the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are objecting to it.
—They are not objecting. The local council is fully behind it—absolutely, fully, 100 per cent behind it. This morning's Sydney Morning Herald says:

PARA.TAB: Mr Yabsley said he had been aware Mr Keating had an interest in the piggery but the Government had "looked at the project, not the personalities. It will create 200 jobs, and the fact that Keating is involved is neither an advantage nor a disadvantage.''

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Mr Yabsley has quite well encapsulated the proper attitude to this matter: that, as Senator Boswell indicated, we look objectively at the situation and require that everything that ought to be done according to the law is done. That will be the case, even in relation to the piggery. Questions such as the environmental impact statement will be considered, which was the concern of somebody on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald. All that will be undertaken because the Prime Minister, through various companies, is engaged in trying to create a situation which will be wealth producing for Australia and will involve investment in very high technology, added to our natural advantage relating to primary industry. Food technology is a way in which Australia can create wealth, can earn export dollars and can have import substitution, which provides for jobs within Australia. I think honourable senators opposite ought to be encouraging those who have funds to invest to invest in precisely this sort of project. They should of course do it in accordance with the law—and I am quite confident that that is the case.

PARA.TAB: I believe we should look at the project, not the personalities. It is very unfortunate that this wealth creating, employment creating project is becoming the focus of such virulent attack from honourable senators opposite. We ought to leave the core original question about the late lodging of returns to the Australian Securities Commission to deal with the matter in an even-handed and independent way.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are pathetic.

—Is Senator Baume suggesting political influence ought to be brought to bear? I say that political influence should not be brought to bear and that the Australian Securities Commission ought to be allowed to do its job without this sort of an attempt to create a political atmosphere in which it is hoped some sort of penalty or fine will be levied. I believe it should be dealt with in accordance with the ordinary rules of process of the Australian Securities Commission. That will be the case, as it will be the case in relation to all other requirements of the law.

—in reply—I have never before heard Senator Tate either so obtuse or so deliberate in his refusal to deal with the substance of a matter. The substance of this matter is not what he pretends it to be. The substance of this matter is the potential for conflict of interest which has in fact gone beyond potential to an actual conflict of interest.

PARA.TAB: This debate is not about whether the project is good or bad, and Senator Tate's attempt to establish it as such was pathetic and childish. I cannot believe he would even try to do that. But he must have his own motives. Whatever they are, they are not ones that bring him any credit.This issue concerns the question of the conflict of interest of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who holds, in a deceptive way, a major interest—which he pretends is not major—in, and who pretends that he does not have a director on the board of, Euphron. This is the issue. When he introduces changes in One Nation and to the FIRB requirements from which he will get a clear benefit, this is also the issue.

People can ask, `Where did he get the money?'. That is a fair question. People who work as parliamentarians all of their lives are unlikely to end up with a spare $500,000 to whack into a family company to whack into a pig interest. But maybe some people have outside interests and, as well as being Treasurers of the nation for eight years, manage to be far more effective in their investments than they are in handling the Australian economy.

That may be the situation, but the fact is that this is a serious question of conflict of interest. It is extraordinary that two matters are being raised. One of them is this question of class war: why are we attacking poor, innocent Paul Keating for being rich? That is not the issue. Paul Keating has been attacking non-stop John Hewson and John Howard for being traitors to their class, while he has just been outed as a closet millionaire. That is the hypocrisy of it.

I want to say one thing about Senator Button's extraordinary contribution. He said that everything was on the public record; there was nothing that was not readily available. That is just bunkum. There was nothing in Mr Keating's declaration of interest to indicate his holding in Brown and Hatton. There was nothing in his declaration of interest to indicate that he would get a benefit from a multi-million dollar joint deal with a multinational—no indication whatsoever. For Senator John Button to pretend that this information was readily available is in fact entering into the same sort of high farce with which Senator Tate just entertained us.

The fact is that there was deliberately no indication to the people of Australia that the Prime Minister would stand to benefit from this multi-million dollar multinational deal. If it had not been for our searching of mountains of available material—most of it was not available, of course; but what was available through the Australian Securities Commission and through all of those corporate searches—we would not have managed to find out what share issues had been made. We do not have the full story because the returns are not there. They have never been submitted.

This is the issue that Senator Tate tries to keep ducking. He deliberately chose to avoid answering the section of my question which contained detailed substance about the companies in the group which had not put in returns for three years. He chose not to do that. I wonder why a man of Senator Tate's integrity would magically decide that that section of the question—which was the first thing asked—would not be responded to.

Who is the Minister who represents the ASC in this chamber? It is Senator Tate. He was capable of establishing pronto the state of the small family investment companies of various people in the Opposition. He was capable of establishing that pronto. But as for answering a question of substance about what the Government was going to do; or whether the Government was going to get the ASC to do anything about companies that have never submitted a proper return—I use the word `proper' because one of them submitted an unsatisfactory return—we have not heard a squeak out of Senator Tate. He comes in here endeavouring to be all sweetness, reasonableness and light and deliberately decides not to pursue this matter of substance because it would seriously affect the status and standing of his Prime Minister in the community. That is what it is all about.

That is why the exercise we have seen here today is almost as disgraceful as the Prime Minister's own activities. The Government has sought to cloud the issue with absolute nonsense. It has tried to generate other major issues, saying that we are attacking this industry. We have not established or even argued whether this industry would be a good or a bad one for Australia. What we have sought to establish is that the Prime Minister has a conflict of interest. That is clear and unarguable, and that is presumably why honourable senators opposite did not argue it, why they raised side issues, why they sought to mislead the public once again. They cannot answer the basic issue.

This Prime Minister misled the people of Australia in his declaration of interest. As we have seen, these declarations are totally phoney at the other end. He stood to gain a benefit from the change in the One Nation statement and did not disclose his interest. When I heard Senator Button say, `Oh, this is nothing of significance', I was reminded of similar comments from the Government at the time we raised the Mr Burke issue. For months senators on this side of the chamber asked non-stop questions about Mr Burke and were continually assured, `This is not a matter of substance'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Insignificant! And look at Mr Burke now.

—I acknowledge Senator Knowles's interjection. She is one of those who were asking these questions non-stop. It was portrayed as a matter of no substance, an insignificant matter. It might be appropriate that today the former Western Australian Premier, Brian Burke, was charged on five counts of false pretences relating to money allegedly taken from a bank account while Premier. I suppose this is also a matter of no substance.

PARA.TAB: When this Government says that a matter is of no substance—such as the Senator Richardson matter and comments about Mr Burke—one can have an almost inverse response. The more that the Government protests that it is a matter of no substance, the more likely it is to be a matter of major substance. That is what this matter is. I am certain that the people of Australia will judge Mr Keating on his deception of them and on his self-interest in this clear pork-barrelling operation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to Order of the Senate of 28 September 1988, I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Button—and he has received prior notice of this—to explain why answers have not been given to two of my questions on notice. The first is question No. 1893, of which notice was given on 29 April 1992, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . concerning the taxation of pensions paid to Australian residents originally from Italy, which are being taxed by both governments in contravention of Article 18(1) of the Agreement, and the representations made by the Australian Government to the Italian Government to obtain refunds of the Italian tax withheld at source for these pensioners, what representations were made to obtain these pension refunds.
The second question is No. 1922, of which notice was given on 7 May, which reads:
(1)Is the United States aggressive in pursuing its transfer
pricing audits in other jurisdictions, including Australia.
(2)As Australia also has its own transfer pricing rules, is there a possibility of doubling up of both sets of rules—
this is a real possibility—
and are measures contemplated to avoid double taxation being imposed on one set of income.
I intend to move that the Senate take note of the explanation, if it is available, from the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —The usual procedure is to give the Minister the opportunity to make an explanation and then, if there is no explanation, you can so move.
—The Minister was given the opportunity of responding. Undoubtedly, in the heat of the last debate, he saw fit to leave the chamber. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: That there be laid on the table of the Senate on or before Wednesday, 17 June 1992 answers by the Minister representing the Treasurer, Senator Button, to questions on notice Nos 1893 and 1922 together with an explanation for the delay in the response.
Both issues are of vital importance to members of the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I wish to ask you a procedural question, Mr Deputy President. This morning a senior officer of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories called into my office and made available to me a series of answers to questions with regard to the Christmas Island casino. He indicated to me that Senator McMullan would be tabling these answers—there are some 14 of them—at the end of Question Time today. On that basis, I was intending to move a motion and speak briefly to noting these important questions.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan took those questions on notice in the Appropriations debate on 1 June and made a commitment that he would give the answers before the end of the last sitting week. Obviously he was not able to honour that commitment. As I said, I did anticipate, as a result of the call to my office today by a senior officer, that these questions and answers would have been tabled by now. Mr Deputy President, I ask for your guidance. Would it be appropriate if I tabled a copy of the questions and answers that have been made available to me and then seek leave to move a motion in respect of them?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can certainly table them if you receive leave. Then you can speak to them either by way of leave or by way of a motion if you have the leave to do that.

—I therefore seek leave to table the series of questions and answers that were made available to me this morning by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories and seek leave to make a brief statement.
—Mr Deputy President, can I be clear whether or not the honourable senator has sought leave of Senator McMullan and this side of the House before he proceeds this way?
—There is no need to do so. Let us take them one at a time. Is leave granted for the document to be tabled?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I am in something of a quandary because I do not know whether in fact the questions that have been transferred to Senator Tambling's office—I take it in good faith—by an officer of the Department are in fact identical to those which have received the approval of Ministers for tabling by Senator McMullan, who I take it is probably in a conference somewhere on the superannuation matter. I wonder whether the chamber could give me another five minutes to try to find him. I think Senator Button wants to speak about a matter that has just occurred in the chamber. We will do our best to get an answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Baume moved a motion to take note—
—I thought you were coming in to answer Senator Watson's question.

—No, I am not. I am coming in to answer another matter. The Opposition has always been diligent in saying that if some misrepresentation were made in Question Time, Ministers should come back into the chamber and correct it. I am anxious to correct a couple of matters which have been alleged in the debate on the motion by Senator Baume to take note of the answer to a question which I gave in answer to Senator Boswell.

PARA.TAB: The burden of Senator Baume's remarks today was that, in the preparation of the One Nation statement, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had some conflict of interest. The suggestion was that the rules were changed at that time in order to accommodate particular people.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be seen that way.

—Yes. I want to put on the record that, in respect of the companies concerned, the FIRB application was made on 5 December 1991. It was dealt with and approved by FIRB on 24 December 1991, and the One Nation statement was made on 26 February 1992.
—The deed wasn't signed until this year.

—I am talking about the FIRB approvals. Senator Baume's allegation was that the FIRB rules were changed in order to accommodate this particular thing; that was the sort of allegation he was seeking to make—by innuendo if not directly. I want to put on the record the facts that the FIRB approval was on 24 December 1991 and the One Nation statement, as I said, was made on 26 February 1992—
—That is when he was Prime Minister.
—That is a new allegation, if Senator Baume wants to make it.
—You are raising new issues.

—I am not raising new issues; I am correcting a matter of fact about which directly, and certainly by innuendo, Senator Baume suggested some particular course of conduct had been taken to influence events in relation to the Prime Minister's business interest. That is not so, and I want to get that right because Senator Baume often gets these things wrong in this chamber; he did so a couple of weeks ago, and he has got things wrong again. I just want to make that clear. It is a matter which is of concern in terms of removing some of his anxiety and concern about this issue, and I am very anxious to do that at any time.
—You were sent back pretty quickly.

—No, I came back, because I said in the course of my comments—Senator Kemp may want to check the record—that there were some matters of information about which I was unable to make any comment but that I would find out about them. I said that, as he will see if he checks the record, and that is what I am doing. So let us not be under any misapprehension about that; I went away to check those matters.

—by leave—I thank the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) for coming back to let us know that, just a few days after Mr Keating became Prime Minister, magically the FIRB approval was granted to Danpork for a matter. We do not know what the matter was. We do not know whether it is the same deal that was signed, as I understand it, only recently in 1992—not in 1991. I wonder whether in that case, as obviously there is great public interest in the matter, Senator Button would table the FIRB approval indicating what in fact the scheme involved was, whether it did in fact cover the present arrangements as we understand them, and whether the removal of the restraints in One Nation could well have enabled massive expansion of the deal from that originally set up.

PARA.TAB: In other words, can the Minister at last get the Government to come clean on what the Prime Minister's interests are, what role the Government played in this, and, in particular, what sort of approvals this venture got while Mr Keating was either Treasurer or, according to the Minister's latest revelation, Prime Minister?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Let me be clear about one or two issues. First of all, it is not any government's practice to float around Foreign Investment Review Board applications and approvals, and Senator Baume ought to know that.
—That is the trouble when you get to this conflict of interest area.
—Senator Hill interjects that that is the trouble when you get into this conflict of interest. There is no conflict of interest issue if declarations are made as to any pecuniary interest.
—They were not made properly.
—I am talking about the declarations which are made on the register, which those opposite have never made.
—You must have been out of the room when I demolished that point.

—I was not out of the room when Senator Baume demolished any point. I heard what he had to say. What those opposite have done is to start on a course of action into which they will fall deeper and deeper as they go on because it is the same sort of exercise they indulged in a few weeks ago. He uses this pejorative language: Will the Prime Minister come clean? One comes clean on the record in this Parliament and it is available for inspection.
—He has not. That is the trouble.
—Yes, he has.
—He has not done it. That is the problem. Go away and read the Hansard then if you do not understand.
—Senator Baume then asks: what are the Prime Minister's interests? The interests are those which have been declared. That is what I have said in the earlier remarks and I repeat them.
—They tell you nothing about Brown and Hatton.

—I am sorry, Senator Baume has to do his own work on that, I suppose, and he has clearly done it. The fact of the matter is that there is no obligation under the rules to, as he put it, tell him anything.
—Exactly. Conflict of interest does not end with your Government's rules.
—Don't you lecture me on conflict of interest, Senator Hill.
—Senator Button, it might be better if the remarks are made through the Chair and the interjections are ignored.

—I was simply making the point, Mr Deputy President, that we had a government for eight years in this country where approximately half the Ministers in the Cabinet were substantial landholders, substantial graziers and farmers, with no declaration of interest system on the public record at all throughout that period. Senator Hill comes in by implication and lectures me about what conflict of interest means.

PARA.TAB: We introduced conflict of interest rules which were adopted by both parties in the House of Representatives. They were not adopted in here because those on the other side of the chamber got cold feet about it. I understand why in some cases the Opposition did that. The fact of the matter is that they were not adopted here, but they were adopted and agreed by both sides of the House of Representatives and have been abided with by Ministers and members of the House of Representatives. It is appropriate that they should be. I certainly cannot undertake to give Senator Baume any FIRB documents. I will not do that, but I will certainly—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not expect you to.
—Why did Senator Baume ask the question?
—To see whether in fact you would come clean and you will not.

—Senator Baume asked a question presumably out of ignorance, because none of those documents would of course be available to people, and Senator Hill wants to introduce a new rule which says that the guidelines in respect of commercial confidentiality and so on of FIRB documents are to be kept by everybody but they do not apply to the Prime Minister or somebody whom Senator Hill sees as a political opponent. So those opposite have to decide whether the vice they complain of is in the conflict of interest rules which we have or whether it is in the FIRB rules which we say are rules which protect everybody making investment or involved in business, and that is the case.
—Did the Prime Minister tell the Cabinet or the Caucus of his interests?

—What the Prime Minister told the Caucus is totally irrelevant to Senator Short. It has nothing whatsoever to do with him. Senator Short rings up businessmen and tells them how they should conduct their affairs with the Labor Party—the biggest embarrassment he has ever suffered because all over the country they laugh about him and his conduct. He interferes in business affairs and then comes in here and tries to tell people what they should say at Caucus meetings. For goodness sake! That is really stretching his shadow capacities to an enormous extent and it is something which he really should not do. I want those facts to be put on the record and Senator Baume can look at them in due course.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Tambling has sought to table answers to questions which were provided to him by a departmental officer, apparently as a copy of material which Senator Tambling thinks would have come from the Minister's office via Senator McMullan, if Senator McMullan had been present.

PARA.TAB: On that basis, and acting in good faith on all sides, I believe that Senator Tambling ought to be allowed to table those particular documents and then, if he wishes to make some remarks about them, he could do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for the tabling of the documents?

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: These are an important series of questions and answers. They were asked on 1 June. Senator McMullan gave an undertaking on that day to have the answers made available as soon as possible. He said:

Senator Tambling was asking for prospective information—information available when certain things are concluded. I cannot give him a time commitment on that but I will be as prompt as I can be. For that which already exists, I will do my best to make sure that it is available this week.

Unfortunately, Senator McMullan obviously was not able to make that information available in the last sitting week. As I said earlier, I was informed by a departmental officer this morning that Senator McMullan would be tabling the questions at the end of Question Time today, which would have enabled me to then take the action I am now taking.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley did ask earlier whether I had sought the normal courtesies of consultation. I indicate that at the end of Question Time I approached the portfolio Minister, Senator Collins, and indicated to him that I was proposing to speak on the particular questions and answers, and asked him to acquaint Senator McMullan of any of the portfolio issues that might subsequently arise. I subsequently telephoned Senator McMullan's office and spoke to the Labor Party Whip, Senator Jones, about this matter before I raised it with you, Mr Deputy President.

The issue that I want to address is that, whilst there is a lot of information on the shareholding and ownership of the proposed casino on Christmas Island, a couple of the answers give me cause for concern: firstly, with regard to a question that originally appeared in Hansard on page 3186, part of the answer relating to investigations by the Australian Federal Police be made available to the Committee or an appropriate Senate committee. The answer, in part, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: My Department has contacted the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority with regard to releasing their reports in relation to this project.
Both have provided advice that it would be inappropriate to do so on confidentiality and privacy grounds.

Similarly, with regard to a question originally asked in Hansard on page 3187, relating to investigations of the Australian Federal Police concerning any current activities of principals of the proposed project, a similar answer was given:
As stated in the previous answer, the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority have provided advice that it would be inappropriate to do so on confidentiality and privacy grounds.

I noted an article in the West Australian of Monday 16 June under the heading `Work halts on Island Casino'. The issues raised in that West Australian article are very important. The first two paragraphs state:

PARA.TAB: The Indonesian backers of a $48m casino development on Christmas Island shut down the site of the nearly complete project at the weekend.
The move is believed to be at least partly in response to the WA Gaming Commission's decision to hold an inquiry into the suitability of the project's backers to hold a casino licence.

SPEECH.PARA: The article then pursues a number of other issues relating to the building, project activity and the inquiries and various reviews that the Federal Government is obviously now undertaking in the answers to these questions provided to me today. Some of the information that appears in that article has also somehow been made available either to the journalist or to other interested parties in advance of it being made available in the Senate, as I would have thought would have been the case.

PARA.TAB: The project on Christmas Island is an important one and it has been ongoing. The answers to many of these questions set out very detailed consideration of the overseas foreign ownership of the casino and the various reviews and processes of approval by a number of Federal Government Ministers over the past few years. This, in turn, raises a series of questions that should now be asked. What are the implications of the stopped work on the building site for the Government's proposed expenditure of $132m on a community infrastructure program, which was recently approved by the Federal Cabinet and is subject to current consideration by the Public Works Committee? What are the implications for the legislation which is currently before the Senate and which drastically alters the legal regimes that are to apply to Christmas and Cocos Islands from 1 July, if the legislation passes this Parliament next week, as is the current program?

I believe we also need to know what assurances, agreements and deals have been struck between the Labor Government, the Indonesian casino developers and Christmas Island Resorts Pty Ltd. In particular, in view of the information that is now obviously before the Government and the Department, is it proposed to alter any of the existing agreements in light of the information that has been given to the Australian Federal Police, the Foreign Investment Review Board or the National Crime Authority? These are issues that certainly arise from these questions and answers. I hope that in the course of this week and next week the Government will be in a position to make a statement on the future of Christmas Island, the future monitoring of the gaming activities on that island and the future of the tourist development that is to take place.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert (from 563 citizens), Senator Macdonald (from 54 citizens), Senator Parer (from 208 citizens), Senator Reid (from 52 citizens) and Senator Short (from 40 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—the petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. the petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: maintained national unity in a federation

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 51 citizens), Senator Bishop (from 20 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 48 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Forces, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pay TV
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: That the draft Broadcasting Services Bill does not prohibit extremely violent or pornographic films/videos being carried by Pay TV;

That the Bill fails to ensure the permanent removal of blasphemous, indecent or obscene content on television and radio but leaves the ultimate decisions on standards and codes of practice to an unelected Australian Broadcasting Authority.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remedy these defects and to provide for decent standards in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, I give notice that, contingent on the Senate concluding any item of business before the question for the adjournment of the Senate is first put on any day, a Minister may move:

SPEECH.PARA: That standing order 64 be suspended to allow new business to be commenced after the question of the adjournment is first put.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, as a consequence of today's explanation by Senator Cook, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)requests the Government to:

TAB.TAB: (i)abandon the proposed inquiry by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) into the awarding of the Advanced Australian Air Traffic System contract to Thomson CSF as the preferred tenderer, and

(ii)set up a genuinely independent inquiry, free from any input from or association with the CAA, at which full protection is provided to witnesses and which inquiry, while proceeding with due expedition but not constrained by any arbitrary time limits, shall inquire into all aspects of the selection process without being constrained by more detailed terms of reference; and

PARA.TAB: (b)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the unusual and irregular procedures followed by the CAA are the reason why such an inquiry is necessary,

(ii)the CAA has refused to honour its responsibility to account publicly to the Parliament, through Senate Estimates hearings and in the consideration of the Appropriation Bills and to the Public Works Committee,

(iii)full protection of witnesses against litigation arising from the hearings is absolutely essential given the history of legal actions taken both in Australia and New Zealand by parties in the CAA against their critics, and

(iv)to proceed with an inquiry by the CAA into its own actions, where it selects the chairman, all the technical advisers and sets the terms of reference and the time schedule, is a grossly fraudulent exercise designed to protect the CAA from being brought to account.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate recommends to the Working Group to Develop a Code of Conduct for Senators and Members that it gives priority to developing a Code of Conduct for Ministers, and that the terms of such a Code of Conduct be transmitted to both Houses of Federal Parliament on or before the first day of sitting in 1993.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to notice of motion given on the last day of sitting on behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I now withdraw the Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1 for this day standing in my name for the disallowance of the ministerial guidelines made on 5 February 1992 under section 44 of the Student Assistance Act 1973, and Business of the Senate notion of motion for eight sitting days after today standing in my name for the disallowance of determinations Nos 1991-92/12 and 24 made under sections 10GI and 10F respectively of the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act 1954.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)that there are now 906 000 Australians officially out of work, and on the Government's own estimates this disgraceful figure is expected to rise to about one million,
(ii)the unemployment rate is now 10.6 per cent, predicted by the Government to rise to 10.75 per cent, and estimated by many commentators to rise to over 11 per cent,
(iii)the absolute tragedy for young people, 34.1 per cent of whom are unable to find work,

(iv)in Victoria, 46.1 per cent of young people are out of work due, in large part, to policies of excessive State Government intervention and spending which even the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has now admitted are damaging, and
(v)the collapse in private investment to its lowest level in five years, which is the basic cause of high unemployment;

PARA.TAB: (b)deplores the arrogance and stupidity of the Prime Minister who boasted that this recession is the one we had to have; and
(c)condemns the Government for failing to understand the consequences of its polices and for failing to take corrective action to restore investment, growth and jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)condemns the decision of the Reserve Bank board to remove Caroline Chisholm from the $5 note;
(b)expresses its concern that such important decisions about which notable Australians serve as national symbols should be determined by such an unrepresentative body; and
(c)establishes a committee of eminent persons drawn from a broad cross-section of the community to select suitable Australians to be represented on the nation's banknotes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)in May 1992, 341 700 Australian women were officially unemployed,

(ii)an unknown number of Australian women, possibly numbering 103 650, are also unemployed but have not registered as such because they are ineligible for job search allowance and they know there are no jobs for which to apply,
(iii)additional Australian women have had their working hours reduced,

(iv)the Federal Labor Government has indicated that it intends to woo the women's vote at the next election and yet introduced no measures in the One Nation statement to assist women in employment; and

PARA.TAB: (b)warns the Government that no amount of media management or slick campaigning will rectify their woeful image in the eyes of Australian women who, as a result of the Government's failure in managing the economy, have not been able to find the jobs they so desperately need.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That leave of absence be granted to Senators Burns, Crowley and Loosley for the period 17 June to 25 June 1992, on account of official Parliamentary business overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)deplores the fact that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate increased to 10.6 per cent in May 1992, bringing the official number of unemployed in Australia to 905 900,
(ii)in May 1992 more than 19 000 Australians joined the jobless ranks, whose number is likely to rise further, and

(iii)the national tragedy of youth unemployment continues to worsen, reaching the devastating and totally unacceptable level of 46 per cent of youth unemployment in Victoria, 45 per cent in South Australia and averaging 34 per cent throughout Australia;

PARA.TAB: (b)notes that not only has employment fallen for the last four months but over 100 000 full-time jobs have been lost in Australia since February 1992;
(c)condemns the Government for:

TAB.TAB: (i)its lack of effective action to arrest rising unemployment, and

(ii)continuing to exacerbate unemployment by increasing the cost burden to business through legislation such as the Superannuation Guarantee Levy Bill 1992, the Training Guarantee Levy, and the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992; and

PARA.TAB: (d)calls on the Government to act immediately to stop the insidious erosion of this Nation's confidence and job base, and enable Australians to get back to work.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Code of Conduct for Senators and Members

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate calls on the Liberal Party, as a matter of urgency, to appoint a Senator to the Working Group to Develop a Code of Conduct for Senators and Members, as it was requested to do in 1991, thus allowing the Working Group to meet for the first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)acknowledges the fact that unemployment is the single most important issue in Australia today;

(b)expresses its strongest possible concern that the unemployment figures released Thursday, 11 June 1992 revealed that 905 900 Australians or 10.6 per cent of the labour force are officially unemployed;

(c)registers its disgust that these record unemployment figures mean that nearly 680 000 Australian children have neither parent working, resulting in unacceptable levels of child poverty, family breakdown, youth homelessness and domestic violence;

(d)notes that Victoria's youth unemployment rate of 46.1 per cent is the worst in Australia and that during May 1992, another 15 000 Victorians became unemployed as the State's unemployment rate rose from 11.2 to 11.8 per cent; and

(e)calls on the Government to have the courage to implement the economic reforms contained in the Coalition's Fightback! package which will resurrect business confidence and create two million jobs for Australian workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)an unemployment rate for May 1992 of 10.6 per cent in the resource rich state of Western Australia constitutes an indictment of the economic policies of the Federal Government,

(ii)the 81 000 Western Australians now in receipt of unemployment relief constitute a rise of 15 per cent on the already disastrous figure of 12 months previously, and a rise of 30 per cent in the two years from May 1990,
(iii)the tragedy of 12 700 young Western Australians, 29 per cent of those aged from 15 to 19, looking for full-time work, is a rise of 21 per cent over the last 12 months, and

(iv)unemployed Western Australians in receipt of New Start as opposed to Job Search Allowance now constitute 34 per cent of those employed, compared with 24 per cent six months ago, showing the continued insidious rise of long-term unemployment; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to:

TAB.TAB: (i)abandon job-destroying policies in the fields of taxation, compulsory superannuation levies and industrial relations, and
(ii)adopt the reform initiatives of the Fightback program of the Liberal and National parties that will cut business costs by 20 to 50 per cent and enable the massive creation of jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force survey for May 1992, the only state in Australia with an unemployment rate lower than 10 per cent was New South Wales (NSW), at 9.8 per cent,
(ii)NSW is the only state that has had the benefit of a non-Labor Government for any length of time,
(iii)the two worst states in Australia for unemployment are the mismanaged Labor states of Victoria and South Australia with unemployment rates of 11.8 per cent and 12.2 per cent respectively,

(iv)while youth unemployment in NSW remains below 30 per cent, it has reached over 45 per cent in the Labor-governed states of Victoria and South Australia according to official figures which do not reveal the full extent of the massive level of hidden unemployment and under-employment,

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns Mr Keating for his disastrous mismanagement of the Australian economy, both as Treasurer and Prime Minister, in bringing about this recession he admits he engineered and which we had to have, along with the unemployment we had to have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that unemployment in North Queensland is still at catastrophic levels despite assurances from the Government that the recession is over;
(b)notes that there are:

TAB.TAB: (i)10,856 people receiving the dole in the Cairns region, 1,581 more than a year ago, a 17 per cent increase,
(ii)8,790 on the dole in the Townsville region, 1,721 more than a year ago, a 24.3 per cent increase,
(iii)1,203 on the dole in Mount Isa, 251 more than a year ago, a 24 per cent increase,
(iv)5,784 on the dole in the Mackay region, 1,183 more than a year ago, a 25.7 per cent increase,
(v)5,571 on the dole in the Rockhampton area, 735 more than a year ago, a 15.2 per cent increase, and
(vi)7,559 on the dole in the Gladstone/Bundaberg region, 1,636 more than a year ago, a 27.6 per cent increase; and

PARA.TAB: (c)calls on the Government to address this crisis by immediately abolishing wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, fuel tax and the training guarantee levy, to boost business, encourage investment and create long-term jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes that—
(a)the present taxation system distorts business and financial decisions, impedes economic growth and places an unfair burden on low and middle income earners;
(b)the current wholesale sales tax regime must be abolished along with other nominated indirect taxes and replaced with a goods and services tax; and
(c)the reforms in the Liberal-National Parties' Fightback! package provide a fully costed and practical means of addressing these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that Australia's unemployment rate jumped to 10.6 per cent in May 1992 with just over 16 000 full-time jobs disappearing during the month;
(b)deplores the appalling rise in teenage unemployment in this nation which now stands at 34 per cent;

(c)notes that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, representing the Prime Minister (Senator Button), in his answer to Senator Hill on 16 June 1992, displayed that the ALP Government did not have a clue about how to solve this problem;
(d)condemns the Government for creating this intolerable situation that is leading to despair and disillusionment among our young people;

(e)expresses dismay at the revelation in the week beginning 7 June 1992 of the doubling of the teenage suicide rate since the beginning of the Great Recession, from one to two teenage suicides per day; and
(f)calls on the Labor Government to adopt the Opposition's employment and youth policies immediately so that our young people again have some hope for their future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Private Interests of Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government parades the great virtue of its requirement on Ministers to make declarations of their private interests and those of their spouses. Yet we have seen again today how easily the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been able to run rings around that requirement and how lacking in any transparency he has been with his own personal return. The value or otherwise of declarations such as these has to be assessed in the light of those other people in the political process who have no such requirement to lodge a public return, but who exercise enormous power in the political process.

PARA.TAB: I turn, for example, to journalists who have enormous power and the ability to present an issue or an individual, or, indeed, by smothering a story to bury an issue or an individual, so that the nation can be very ill-informed or even misinformed. When it comes to journalists, their financial, their personal or their spousal connections can be of enormous importance in assessing what they have written, the influence they exercise, and who is related to whom by one means or by another.

An example of a very cosy, financial connection of the media with business, rather than in the political scene, was demonstrated last night by Stuart Littlemore in Media Watch, in relation to the special editorial page benefits given to Ford in the Sunday Herald and the Herald-Sun, to L. J. Hooker in Business Review Weekly, and Carlton and United Breweries in the Herald-Sun. This was all apparently in exchange for advertising arrangements. How can there be any expectation that this special treatment that is given to commercial organisations is not also handed out to political friends and favourites?

The exercise of power in the political process does not stop with the media. Unseen, except perhaps on Yes, Minister, is the army of influential decision makers in the Public Service—those who boast that governments come and governments go but they go on for ever. These are the people who actually decide the mass of government contracts, for example—the procurement contracts and the construction contracts. Yet we know nothing of their financial interests or those of their spouses. Many ministerial staff are also in influential positions and very likely to so position their Ministers that decisions are made in accordance with their staff's recommendations. Yet we know nothing of the staff's connections or interests.

Finally, I point to the growing band of consultants, one of the most recent of which has been the appointment of Dr Anne Summers as a consultant to the Prime Minister on women's issues. Dr Summers was recently described by a friend in an article in the Australian in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: What's important for her is to be close to power. It's not so important to her what the person in power thinks because you can always manipulate that.

Richard Farmer has also been quoted as saying that Dr Summers will have a massive influence on what Labor does between now and the next election. The Prime Minister is to be manipulated and massively influenced, yet we will have nothing on the private interests of Anne Summers. Consultants of such acknowledged power go unscrutinised while the Government gives itself credit for making public the interests of the puppets. Meanwhile, we know nothing of the puppeteers or the Svengalis of the Government. Perhaps when proper attention is given to these matters, the returns of Ministers will be given more credit than they currently are.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of returns of private interests of Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries is of some concern. Clearly, the object is to provide the people of Australia with information about the potential conflict of interest of their Ministers. I understand that was why the Government introduced it.

PARA.TAB: As I mentioned earlier, there is no indication here of the significance of the holding of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the pig empire that is now entering a multi-million dollar scheme with a multinational company. Senator Button has said that the scheme was approved by the FIRB before the One Nation package got rid of the limited requirement under which such a scheme would have to get FIRB approval. From this declaration of interest, we have not the vaguest idea that the Prime Minister had any involvement whatsoever in these matters—in the multinational deal or in Brown and Hatton. It would not have emerged but for a whole series of searches of company records. Almost every one of the companies involved changed their name at some stage or another. There is simply no indication in this return of the significance or otherwise of Mr Keating's holding in pigs.

I do not know to what extent it is significant that the Prime Minister should have a bank bill from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. I guess mortgages and bank overdrafts are the normal sorts of things people have. What interests me is that one of the companies in which he has a major interest, the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, formerly Denvalt Pty Ltd, had a significant indebtedness in 1989—we do not know what has happened since because we have not had a return—to the Commonwealth Bank one way or another, by way of a bank bill, which I understand was converted into a $1.5m mortgage by way of re-financing. What emerges from this is that the applicant company, as part of the mortgage documents, undertakes as proposed to reduce overall trading bank borrowing by $3,120,000 gross by the sale of three piggery companies situated near Tamworth, New South Wales, among other things.

We simply do not know whether, in fact, this group in which the Prime Minister has such a major investment is also very heavily indebted to the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. In other words, is there a potential for conflict of interest here as well? It is quite clear that we get no indication whatsoever from these declarations of interest. As I said earlier, surely it seems important that if this Government really believes in these declarations of interest, it should make them meaningful. If Mr Keating has a half-interest in the company which is a major investor in the Brown and Hatton group, then that half-interest surely should be declared, as should be the fact that he has a nominee on the board of that company—as I said, a nominee who has no beneficial interest in the matter whatsoever.

Until these declarations of interest are meaningful, they may as well not exist. That, of course, was the position we took at the time. We said that there is absolutely no need for meaningless declarations of interest like those now being presented to this Parliament, particularly by this Prime Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
