DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance--May 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Advance to the Minister for Finance for May of this year shows that an amount of approximately $20m is being sought. That is, again, a very significant amount, although it pales into insignificance when compared with the $80m that was sought in April. I do not propose to go through all the items in the May advance, but there are one or two to which I particularly wish to draw attention. The most significant of those, not in money terms but in terms of requiring an explanation, is an amount of $400,000 being paid through the Advance to the Minister for Finance to Ausmusic.

PARA.TAB: As the Senate may recall, Ausmusic is an organisation that was set up back in about 1988. Ausmusic, which stands for Australian Contemporary Music Development Company, was established by the Department of Employment, Education and Training in June 1988 as a non-profit company for the development of the Australian contemporary music industry. Since June 1988, Ausmusic has received a total of $1.65m in Commonwealth funding from the DEET portfolio through the training aspects of its charter.

But the Government recently decided to transfer responsibility for assistance to Ausmusic from DEET to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. The application for funds from the Advance to the Minister for Finance states:

Following this transfer, Government also agreed to provide $400,000 in additional funding to Ausmusic in 1991/92, subject to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce being satisfied with Ausmusic's business plan in relation to the use of the additional funds. That plan has now been received and accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: The application goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: As both of the Government decisions concerning Ausmusic were finalised following the additional estimates process, this proposal clearly meets the unforeseen criteria. The matter is now urgent as Ausmusic will cease trading if funds are not received before the end of the current financial year.
Furthermore, as Cabinet specifically agreed to provide the additional funding in 1991/92, AMF remains the only funding source available.

SPEECH.PARA: That is quite an extraordinary application because, although I have not had time to check out the full details, my recollection of the matter is that the Parliament was told some time ago that Ausmusic was to become self-sufficient in its funding. It was originally provided interim funding only on the basis that it would eventually become self-sufficient with money raised from the blank tape levy. That has since been the subject of a High Court challenge which has prevented Ausmusic receiving funding from this source.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General's report No. 7 of 1991-92 expressed concern about the Ausmusic company. It found that, unless Ausmusic received continued funding, it would be forced to go into voluntary liquidation. It said that it would require a Government policy decision on whether it wanted to continue funding. It appears that the Government has taken that policy decision, but it also appears that that decision has been taken in the dark without any announcement publicly—or certainly not to this Parliament.

The Executive Director of Ausmusic is Mr Peter Steedman, the former member for Casey in Victoria, and a member of the very hard Left of the Victorian Labor Party. He has been in that position now for several years. In fact, I think he was the inaugural Executive Director. It is about time that the Government came clean and told this Parliament and this Senate how long it proposes to continue to allow Ausmusic to run on the public purse. It is obviously not a viable operation of itself, and what it is doing for Australian contemporary music is highly questionable. There is no evidence that it is doing anything at all in that respect. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak to the Advance to the Minister for Finance and to note that in it the Australian National Maritime Museum has been obliged to seek a substantial increase in funding for a variety of reasons, which is of course unfortunate. As the document explains, the National Maritime Museum is seeking funds to cover a shortfall in revenue, unexpected maintenance costs and higher than anticipated exhibition fit-out costs. This was evident some time ago and was raised in Senate Estimates hearings.

PARA.TAB: As the document indicates, the shortfall in revenue is due to a lower than anticipated visitation level since opening on 30 November 1991. Visitor numbers and revenue are only around 50 per cent of the original estimate. We know that there is a recession in Australia and that New South Wales is the State least affected, judging by unemployment figures. It seems extraordinary in those circumstances that there should be such a dramatically lower than anticipated visitation figure. I wonder on what basis a forecast of visitors was made that was so dramatically wrong.

Quite frankly, I have a high regard for the National Maritime Museum and I am a member of it. I wish more Australians would go to see this significant place. But I am very concerned that the basis on which funding has been given was obviously in expectation of substantial numbers of visitations which simply have not taken place. The Government and the museum itself must address this problem.

One thing that really concerns me even more about this substantial additional fund requirement of more than half a million dollars—$572,000—is that unavoidable extra maintenance costs are associated with the museum. The document states that the work is for `essential maintenance for the proper preservation and functioning of the Commonwealth's asset'.

This is simply the latest instalment of extraordinary cost burdens in the construction and now the maintenance of this museum. It was grossly unfair that the New South Wales Greiner Government had to pick up the bill of about $40m as a result of an agreement made by a previous Labor Minister for works with the Commonwealth to construct this building for the Commonwealth at a fixed price. That fixed price was massively overrun. The taxpayers of New South Wales had to pick up that bill.

There is now a much higher maintenance bill. I regret that the amounts relating to both the higher maintenance and the volume of shortfall of tenancies are not stated in this request for additional money. We have a continuing problem with public works which may be seen to be exciting and grand in conception but in which there has not been proper regard for financial restraint and the harbouring of financial resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Also, the access is very difficult.

—As Senator Teague says, the access is difficult. All we can hope is that this very expensive asset, which is costing so much more to maintain than expected, will one way or another attract a greater number of visitors. I hope that the Board of the National Maritime Museum, which has some outstanding Australians on it, will be able to address this matter effectively. It is not good enough for this kind of half a million dollar handout to take place in a situation in which the Government is finding it has more and more people unemployed and in need of major assistance. It is a vital matter that organisations such as this should one way or another be pulling their weight rather than demanding more and more out of the public purse.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report by the first day of sitting in August 1992:
(a)the probity and propriety of accommodating Government departments in property owned by the political party of the Government in power;
(b)the process of negotiation leading to, and the terms and conditions of, the agreement for lease between the Commonwealth and John Curtin House Ltd; and

(c)whether that process of negotiation and those terms and conditions were in accordance with the principles which should govern dealings between government and private bodies in relation to commercial arrangements such as the lease of office space.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for wishing to refer this particular matter to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration relates to the leasing of premises owned by the Australian Labor Party to the Australian National Audit Office. It was raised with me some months ago because of concerns within the Public Service about the propriety of going down this track.

PARA.TAB: When I first raised this matter publicly in January by way of a press release, it brought a somewhat violent reaction from the National Secretary of the ALP, Mr Hogg. He used some rather extravagant language, saying that what I said was near defamatory, simply because I raised the issue of property owned by the ALP being used to house a government department, in this case, the Audit Office.

The day after that press release, a Mr Mike Seccombe wrote an article in the Sydney Morning Herald. It was one of those fairly innocuous sorts of articles, but it was a half-smart type of article. In it Mr Seccombe said that my statements had enraged a lot of people, not only people in the ALP but also staff in the Auditor-General's office. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: They are, after all, supposed to be the independent people who monitor Government accounting, to make sure no wastage or rorts are taking place.
Mr Seccombe must have had a great night the night before, because he went on to say:

PARA.TAB: The knives were out for Parer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hell!

—I agree, Senator Brownhill. I shivered and shook when I read this in the Sydney Morning Herald: `And yesterday they struck'. What wonderful journalese we have these days. If one read this article, one would think that somehow the Auditor-General had taken great umbrage about what I had done—that is, simply raising an issue that is of great importance. Under no circumstances and at no time over this whole issue have I or my colleagues made any remarks that would criticise the Auditor-General in any way. We hold the Auditor-General in the highest regard. He is, after all, the man who oversees the financial matters relating to the Government. I think all of us would commend him not only for that but also for the efficiency audits which he does with such expertise for the Parliament of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General wrote me a letter which I think is worth quoting from, not only for the benefit of the half-smart journalist who wrote the article but also for the benefit of the Labor Party which carried on at great length when this matter was raised by my colleague Senator Bishop in Estimates Committee B. The letter from the Auditor-General, Mr Taylor, dated 17 January, states:

SPEECH.PARA: I write to thank you for the support you have given to this Office in the Parliament over the problems we are having. We need all the help we can get and I have been greatly heartened by what you and other Senators have done and said on our behalf—in the interests of better public administration through effective parliamentary scrutiny. Thank you very much.
He then went on to say:

I would like to take this opportunity to mention another matter. An interstate colleague has drawn my attention to an item in today's `The Sydney Morning Herald' which suggests that this Office was `enraged' by your statement about a proposed new building for the ANAO, and from which the implication possibly could be drawn that we had our `knives. . . out for you' and that the ANAO had briefed `The Sydney Morning Herald', as a result.

While the article in question was not very serious, I wanted you to know from me directly that the ANAO is not guilty! Of all organisations, the ANAO is the least likely to find fault with a parliamentarian ventilating anything involving the spending of taxpayers' money. We were not enraged. Indeed, if DAS can get a better deal for our accommodation as a result, you will have done us and the taxpayers a service. Nor have we been briefing the press on the matter.
Yours sincerely,
Auditor-General.

I think it is worth recording that little item. An agreement was negotiated between Lend Lease, on behalf of the ALP, and the Australian Property Group. What concerned us was, first of all, the probity of actually entering into an agreement in 1992 to house a government department within premises owned by the government of the day.

PARA.TAB: It has been put to me that this occurred 20 or 25 years ago with regard to John McEwen House and the National Party. I am quite aware of that; I think everyone is aware of it. But it is a different climate. The question I raised, again with this gentleman Mr Seccombe with his half-smart article, was what his reaction would be if a couple of years ago the National Party Government in Queensland had put a major government department into Bjelke-Petersen House. There would be people quite rightly protesting about that. There would be journalists crying `foul' and `corrupt'. Yet what is the difference? I submit to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there is no difference. Hence, the first item that I wish to refer to the Committee: the probity and propriety of accommodating government departments in property owned by the political party of the government in power. That must be determined. When the Democrats come in here they start talking about ethics, yet I do not believe they will support the motion to refer this matter to a committee. I will come to that in a minute because I suspect I know why.

Then we talk about the process of negotiation leading up to and the terms and conditions of the agreement for lease between the Commonwealth and John Curtin House. When the conditions became known we were more concerned. When we have an oversupply of property, when there is a recession, and when, as a result of that recession we had to have, we have an incredibly high unemployment rate—brought about by this Government and in particular the ex-Treasurer and now Prime Minister, Mr Keating—we see that there is an agreement that runs for 15 years. That is very unusual. I do not think there is another instance of a Commonwealth government renting or leasing property for that period.

The lease agreement provided for some $1.8m in rent, retrospective to 1 January 1991. What that means, of course, is that the rent increases at 10.5 per cent per annum going back to January 1991 until the date of completion, and from then on at the rate, I think, of 9 per cent for the balance of the 15 years. But there is more. The tenant, the Auditor-General, is to pay all the outgoings to the owner, which is the Australian Labor Party, for the full period. There is a provision in the contract to look at the market after five years. If the market rate is higher, the tenant will pay more, but if it is lower, the tenant will not pay less rent; the tenant will pay continuing increases in rent at 9 per cent per annum. Is it any wonder that we have expressed concern, not only about the probity of the matter but also about the terms and conditions? I challenge anyone in this place to talk to anyone in the community about a deal at $1.8m a year guaranteed with a 10.5 per cent escalation going backwards in time to 1 January 1991 and then a 9 per cent increase plus paying all outgoings. That is a bankable contract; that is like money in the bank.

The final item was whether the process of negotiation of those terms and conditions was in accordance with the principles that should govern dealings between the Government and private bodies. I would have thought that, in this day and age when people are concerned about probity, when we have seen the WA royal commission and the Brian Burkes of this world—

TALK.START.PARA: —Arrested today.

—As Senator Bishop said, he was arrested today. We have seen what went on at the gold lunch. We can go on and on. It is of absolute importance that this matter be referred to the Committee for some sort of determination, to give some credibility back to a great parliamentary system which has been brought into disrepute by a few grubs.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the Democrats will not be supporting this motion. I ask myself: why not? Are they frightened of something? I found out that the Government over recent weeks has been inquiring about what happened to the block of land given to the Australian Democrats for their own purposes; in other words, for their own head office in Canberra—

TALK.START.PARA: —Given to them!

—Yes, Senator Brownhill. As a national organisation the Democrats are entitled to that, the same as any other organisation. But there are certain conditions relating to it. The Democrats were given a block of land in 1986. That is fair enough, if it was to be used for the head office of the Democrats, but we find that the person who was responsible at that time for the purchases of the Democrats was a senator-elect, one Sid Spindler. He went off and spoke to a group around town. They negotiated and got into a deal. The deal was that the Democrats would sell their block of land, with a 99-year lease, for $1m—a $1m profit.

PARA.TAB: These are the people who came in here to keep everyone honest, honourable senators might recall. Is this the reason they do not want to support this motion—because they do not want this sort of thing to come out, to be regurgitated, during the investigations by the Committee? They may well come in here and argue, `This is not new; we have argued this one before'. Yes, they have, but let me remind honourable senators what it was. If it were just a case of getting rid of the property, one could say, `Okay', but the Democrats found that, if they were not careful, they would have to pay capital gains tax. The Democrats went to extraordinary lengths—these people who are in here to keep everyone honest—to avoid paying capital gains tax. There was a wonderful interview in October 1988 between Senator-elect Spindler and Pru Goward when she said to Mr Spindler:

SPEECH.PARA: Okay, you've made a million dollars out of it. . .
Mr Spindler said, `Well, there's nothing wrong with that. We've still achieved the purpose for which it was given to us. We are going to get a little bit of space in it which we can use'.

PARA.TAB: There is another requirement if one goes down this track and gets such a property in the Australian Capital Territory, and that is, some 50 per cent of the building has to be occupied by the original person who was granted the lease, or by a similar non-profit organisation. This would have meant not a very good deal for the Australian Democrats who, we know, are so scrupulously honest. They did not want to do anything but avoid a bit of tax and maximise the amount of money they would get from the sale of this property. They entered into a devious method and a company, AD Pty Ltd—I suppose the AD is short for Australian Democrats—made some payment to the developer over a 10-year period which avoided the capital gains tax. But, more importantly, they wrote to the government of the day and said, `Would you absolve us from the requirement of 50 per cent occupancy because we can get a better deal?' The government of the day wrote back and said, `Yes, we can make it 35 per cent'.

The question that must be raised is whether the Democrats are occupying the 35 per cent—which, incidentally, must become 50 per cent after eight years, to go back to the original purpose—or whether they are in breach. I do not know the answer to that, but it puts the question in my mind as to why they are not supporting this motion to refer what I believe is a very important matter to a standing committee for report back to the Parliament in the first week in August.

I do not intend to keep this chamber much longer. We are going to be running short of time for the debating of legislation. However, I again point out to those people who are interested in this matter that here we have something which I believe is against everything that is right. It is an attack on probity and propriety. A government department—it does not matter which one in fact—has been put into premises owned by the Australian Labor Party under the most generous terms and conditions that I have seen in recent months, whether it be the ACT or any other capital city in Australia. The beneficiary is undoubtedly the ALP. It has been able to take a document to a financial institution and, with that document, construct a building with a value of some $20m which over a period of time will end up belonging totally to the Labor Party without any outlay whatsoever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been in this Parliament for about 11 years now. I suppose the realisation one comes to is that politics is a bit like sport and sport a bit like politics. In both walks of life, there are some pretty grubby performances, some pretty grubby incidents. The performance of the geriatric Bonnie and Clyde on the other side of the chamber in the last six months has to be amongst the most pitiful we have seen.

PARA.TAB: There is a concept in this Parliament of parliamentary privilege. It is interesting to refer to that for a minute, because I am genuinely irate about this. Those who may be listening to this debate, either in this chamber or on the monitors, should pause for a moment after that last performance and reflect on what I am about to say. There are a lot of people out in the community who have been involved in this process, in this leasing arrangement, who are decent honest people—whether they have been involved in organising or in building the project. I can understand why they are concerned at the moment at the buckets coming up from the other side on this. I say to them that there is a concept of parliamentary privilege. Page 633 of Odgers states the position quite clearly. I think it is worth putting this on the record. I contend that we as parliamentarians have not only rights but also responsibilities. One of those responsibilities is to get to the truth. Odgers states:

SPEECH.PARA: While the purpose of privilege is to enable Members fearlessly to speak their minds, it is not to be taken that the law of privilege confers complete immunity on a Member of Parliament in respect of anything said or done by him in the course of proceedings in Parliament.

There has to be some responsibility. What we have seen on this particular issue in three incidents this year is absolutely no fire but a lot of puff from the other side. There has been a gross abuse of the procedures. There has been a gross abuse of parliamentary privilege and those who are damaged by it are those innocent people outside who have been involved with this.

PARA.TAB: When Dr Hewson took over the leadership of the Liberal Party he asserted that he would be a new wave politician. Dressed in white, gowns flowing, he would come in and clean up the system. What we have seen on this particular issue is a total abdication of responsibility on his part. We do not expect it from Senator Hill because, quite honestly, Senator Hill does not get involved in too many things; he is bit too lazy for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order—

—I withdraw it. We do expect it from the Opposition leader. If he is to raise the standard of political debate in this community, then he has an obligation to pull Senator Parer and Senator Bishop right back into their boxes because they have been running on this issue with absolutely no substance for the best part of six months. They have been driven by total hypocrisy. They complain about the Australian Labor Party building this office. Not once do they refer to the fact that the Liberal Party was so keen to build this office block that they beat us to the tender process by three days. Talk about hypocrisy!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members got stuck into the Democrats tonight over their obtaining a certain block of land in the ACT. They did not mention that the Liberal Party and the National Party have had premises in the ACT which have been made available to national organisations, as is the custom and law of the place. They did not mention that at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —We said that. How about telling the truth.
—The hypocrisy is just overawing in this respect.
—You little grub.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I insist on that being withdrawn.
—I withdraw.

—What we have driving this debate is a person who is dead certain that he is going to lose his position on the front bench and another who, in a ballot last week for the deputy leadership of the Opposition in this place, managed to come fourth in a field of four candidates and probably got only one vote. Those are the sorts of people driving this debate. The accusation from the start is that there has been political involvement in this particular process. I rebut that.
—Who said that?

—`Who said that?', asks Senator Parer. What I suggest Senator Parer does before he comes into this place and debates anything again is to read his own press statements. On 15 January this year he called it `Labor's Fifteen Year Rort'. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is pressuring the Australian National Audit Office to relocate to the new ALP headquarters. . .

That was in the press statement of 15 January. Not to be outdone, on 2 June he put out a press statement entitled, rather curiously, `ALP favours itself in lease to Government'. One cannot understand what that means, other than to infer that the Labor Party is doing deals for itself. It then went on to accuse the Government of impropriety.

PARA.TAB: When people accuse the Government, the Labor Party, it is pretty clear that they are accusing those in ministerial positions. The truth, and Senator Parer knows it well—it has been driven down his throat so many times in the last process that we had—is that not one Minister, not one Parliamentary Secretary, has been involved in this process. That is an established fact and it is something that Senator Parer knows. But it does not stop him from going out there and distorting the truth.

It has been established, for instance, that I knew of this particular proposal the day after Senator Parer put out his first press statement on 15 January. The advice I have had from my Department is that both formally and informally it had not brought it to my attention, and that is already on the public record. It is already on the public record that Senator McMullan was not involved at any time in this particular process.

So despite there being absolutely no evidence to confirm or to support the proposal that Ministers have applied pressure regarding this proposal, we got a press statement which is totally full of lies. There is absolutely no respect for the truth; there is absolutely no respect for the public interest; and there is absolutely no respect for honesty in debate. It is no wonder that out there people are saying to Senator Parer and his colleagues, `Get back on the main game'. So there has been a dishonest abuse of the process.

Let us accept—we should not accept any other assertion on this point—that there has been no political involvement or intervention. There has been nothing to indicate that there has been. Let us see whether there was any other irregularity. Let us see whether, as Senator Parer says, what we are talking about here, as he put out in his press statement on 15 January, is a `deal of incredibly generous conditions'. On 15 January he also made the assertion that `the Government is prepared to turn a blind eye to the issues of conflict of interest, probity and honesty'. Those are the charges made. Again, on 2 June he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . terms and conditions were extremely favourable to the Labor Party.
He made another assertion:
. . . 15 years which is unheard of for a Government building. . .

He went on to call this an unprecedented leasing arrangement. He waffles on saying, `They are, they are'. Two contentions are made here. Essentially, the first is that these are extremely generous conditions and the second is that there is some degree of impropriety. The second point is extremely easy to dismiss, because nothing has been adduced by the Opposition—and nothing has come out of the copious documents that the Government has been willing to table—that would lend any support to that proposition at all. The honourable senator knows it. Why does he not just give up on it?

PARA.TAB: Let us go to the other point about generous conditions. What has been established quite convincingly here is a normal commercial proposition carried out by honest people without interference. It is and was a normal business arrangement. The truth is that Senator Parer should give it a break and get back to the real issues of the day. No wonder the Opposition's reputation is going down. I must say once again that I really feel sorry for those people out in the electorate who are involved in this. Quite respectable people from Lend Lease who have organised this, property managers in my Department and those who are doing the building are being besmirched by this bucket which has been thrown by the Opposition.

Let us look at the process and the details of the proposal. The land in question was purchased and sold to the Labor Party by a Kaine Liberal government in the ACT not for $1m but, I am told, for some $2.2m, half a million dollars of which was to go to off-site preparations. That should be placed on the public record. This has been conveniently ignored by the Opposition when it tries to build its little castles in the air.

Let us have a look at the process. Between 27 October and 14 November 1990 expressions of interest were invited for a 3,000 to 8,000 square metre office block. The closing date was 16 November. The Department received 14 responses, one of which arrived on 15 November. That was from Lend Lease on behalf of the Australian Labor Party. But, as I said earlier, the Liberal Party beat us to the punch by some two or three days. Tony Eggleton got its proposition in on 13 November.

On 21 November a brief was sent to the National Audit Office detailing the expressions received. One on the list was the Lend Lease proposal on behalf of the ALP. But, as we established in the previous debate on this matter some two or three weeks ago, Domonic Collins—who has now retired but who was handling this matter for the Australian Property Group—advised that he withheld that proposition from the list to the National Audit Office because he wanted to avoid a `dutch auction' by the potential tenants. Eight days later, on 29 November, the 14 propositions were presented to the Australian National Audit Office and thereafter everything proceeded on the basis that there were 14 propositions on the table.

Some point has been made about whether the National Audit Office did or did not know—and if so, when it knew—whether the Labor Party was behind the Lend Lease proposal. As I said on 28 May in this place:

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed by my Department, and through it by National Audit officers, that they recall discussing the proposal at a meeting on 29 November 1990, which is some two weeks after the close of expressions of interest. The Audit Office people cannot say whether the ALP involvement was discussed or not. However, they indicated that they also do not recall learning anything about it later, although clearly they did know about it by March 1991 and did not consider it a concern. I am advised that they probably did know at the November 1990 meeting about the ALP involvement in the proposal. At all material times they were aware of it. As I say, they did not consider it a concern.
So much for that particular point.

PARA.TAB: The other point that should be made is that it was the Australian National Audit Office itself which chose the particular site. This was pretty well documented in this place on 28 May and on days around that time. One of the reasons the National Audit Office chose it is reflected very clearly and simply in a report of this Parliament—the 296th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. On page 246 of that report the Committee made it very clear that there was some merit in the proposal. The Committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Audit Office plan for a new building either within the Parliamentary Triangle or on State Circle adjacent to the new Parliament House, and that the building be called Audit House.

A Committee of this Parliament felt it was important for the National Audit Office to have a building in the Parliamentary Triangle or on State Circle, and this Lend Lease-Labor Party proposition was the one that fitted within the requirements. The Audit Office made the choice, independent of ministerial interference. There was none, and the property was chosen on good grounds and for good reasons. The other ground on which the property was chosen, and on which my Department advised that it should be taken, was the proposal that was put to the Audit Office. It was a good commercial transaction, as I say, with no external interference. We are talking about an arrangement that was entered into some 12 months ago in a different market. On 8 April 1992 the final documents were signed by AGS on behalf of the National Audit Office.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at some of the details of the proposal to lease. It was alleged by Senator Parer in his press statement of 15 January 1992 that `it is incredibly generous'. On 2 June 1992 he called it an `unprecedented lease arrangement'. As I said earlier, in his press statement on 2 June he continued to assert that the terms and conditions were extremely favourable to the Labor Party.

Let us just look at them. Let us see the reality of the situation. Let us see the degree of distortion that the Opposition is involved in. Let us see the degree of dishonesty in this debate, with absolutely no respect for people's reputations. The proposition as agreed to provides for a charge of $280 per square metre as of 1 January 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —Escalating at?

—There is an escalation rate of 10 1/2 per cent until occupancy, with outgoings of $47 per square metre: an all-up figure of $322 per square metre per annum. That arrangement was entered into with the firm advice of the Australian Valuation Office, an independent arm of government.
—Another arm of the ALP.

—Senator Walters should go back to Tasmania and leave us alone. She has nothing to do with this debate—absolutely nothing. She knows nothing about it. That has not stopped her from participating in debates before, but this time she might actually do herself some good by listening. In fact, if she listens she might even take Senator Parer's place on the front bench. She might even jump over him.
—They tell me you had a very good time in Darwin.

—A good time it was. The honourable senator should have been there. The charge was $322 per square metre. The advice from the Australian Valuation Office was that the going rate of rental for Barton properties, where the chosen property was located, was $330 per square metre. Not only did my Department negotiate a proposition that was within the going rate but it also negotiated a free fit-out of $400,000 and, further, that no rent be paid during the fit-out period. They are further benefits to the Commonwealth and to Government funds because of the arrangement entered into and the work done by people acting on behalf of the Government. It was a good arrangement for the Government, it was below market rates and it was quite defensible. Senator Parer says, `Tell us about the duration of the lease'. I have a document here which deals with that.
—Fifteen years.

—Of course it was a 15-year lease, with the first revision—Senator Parer made a mistake earlier—after four years and the second after nine. Let me reiterate what I put to the Parliament on 28 May. I was advised by professionals who enter into such arrangements. The advice is on the public record, but Senator Parer chooses to take no notice of it, for his own grubby little interests.
—Oh!

—There is no other way to describe it, and Senator Kemp knows that. I was asked what the average term for leases in the ACT was. The advice from the Department was, and is, that `the lease terms vary according to client departments'. I put that on the record then. In fact, nothing that has been put on the record tonight by either speaker is new. I went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Most major leases provide for a minimum base term of 10 years, with two options for an additional five years each . . . in the current real property market where there is a scarcity of investors, developers are now requesting lease terms of 15 years before commencing work on new programs.

I am told that we have an 18-year arrangement for the Tuggeranong offices. My memory tells me that, although we were proposing a 10-year arrangement for one of the offices of the Australian Taxation Office in Adelaide, the financiers were requesting a longer one and, if my memory is correct, at the end of the day they got a longer one. The reality is that the market is seeking more and this is, once again, within market conditions.

PARA.TAB: Then Senator Parer went on to mention rental growth rates. This is where it all comes glaringly unstuck for Senator Parer, because only a fool could go to the next contention that he makes. We were told that the market growth rates are such that with a 9 per cent increase after occupation and a 10 1/2 per cent increase in rental before occupation, this is a good deal for the Labor Party. On what basis did officers of this Department and the National Audit Office make their assessment and come to a decision? The Senate knows already because we went through it last time. Once again, the Opposition has chosen to ignore this.

The Australian Valuation Office advised us that the long term growth rate for property in Barton—it advised us that $330 per square metre per annum is the appropriate rental—was 11.61 per cent. Those opposite are talking about a mechanism that ensures that the rate of increase is not automatically 11.61 per cent; it is below that. The rate is 10.5 per cent until construction completion, which should be within the next eight or nine months or so, and 9 per cent thereafter for at least the first four years. That is not generous. It is within the advice of the Department and the Australian Valuation Office. What is the public told about this? This is quite amazing. The public is told that this is a generous deal. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: This is in direct contrast to a lease signed recently for a prime site in Collins Street Melbourne of similar size for about $150 a square metre without any incentives, rent holidays or assistance for fit-out.

That is from a press statement of 2 June from this financial wizard from the Opposition. No wonder the Opposition is looking shaky! Any mug in the market knows that the vacancy rates in Melbourne, Perth and Sydney are about 25 per cent. Anyone who is about to go into an arrangement in the ACT would know that the vacancy rates here are one-eighth of the vacancy rates in Melbourne, Sydney or Perth. They are 3 or 4 per cent. That has to have some impact on the price.

PARA.TAB: One would have thought that someone who professes to have had experience in the private sector could see that there would be a difference between leasing a property in Collins Street, Melbourne, where the vacancy rate is 25 per cent, and in Barton, Canberra, where it is 3 or 4 per cent. No wonder we got a fit-out, no wonder we got a rent-free period and no wonder the electorate is wondering what the Opposition is on about!

As I have said, the terms and conditions are within the prices advised by the Australian Valuation Office. If Senator Parer wants to compare the going rental of a property in the Parliamentary Triangle with one in Collins Street, Melbourne, he is exposing himself to the electorate and it obviously would not be that receptive of it.
We have had a number of claims about this particular proposal. As I jokingly said to someone this afternoon, I was quite tempted to come in here this evening and just say to the Senate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the party in the Northern Territory.

—It was a good one; Senator Parer would have enjoyed it. The Greek community would have liked to have had him up there, but he left it to Senator Tambling, another second-rater. In the meantime, the Federal member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon, and I enjoyed our time that we spent with the people of the Territory, particularly the Greek community in Darwin. It is quite pertinent that Senator Parer raised this matter because only a few months ago Senator Parer came in here and alleged that I was involved in some grubby arrangement with some leading Greek business people in Darwin to once again get government departments—
—I did not.

—Sorry, it was Senator Tambling who alleged that—to get government departments into their property. Once again, we found that I was not even the Minister at the time. Anyway, we have this assertion here tonight.

PARA.TAB: If the Opposition really wants to know how generous this arrangement is and whether the Labor Party, as Senator Parer claims, is involved in a 15-year rort, it should just have a look at John McEwen House. It is down the road from this office and it is about 20 years old.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than that.

—More than that. What rent does the Opposition believe the Government is being charged for those particular premises? I will tell the Opposition what it will find out when it checks: it is more than the Labor Party charged in this lease to the Government. It is around the vicinity of $330 per square metre and it is a much older building; it is an old age building. If the Opposition really wants to pursue this, it should get some people to advise it who have some idea about the commercial market and propriety.

PARA.TAB: We have had a series of interventions by the Opposition, spurred on by spurious arguments. The ANAO chose the office block; it got it on a good arrangement. There is not one iota of impropriety or corruption. In this particular debate there has been a gross degree of irresponsibility by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you would expect.

—As Senator Faulkner says, as one would expect, but I would not since in this particular instance there is not one iota of evidence of any impropriety. It has been established that Ministers have not been involved; it has been established that this is purely a commercial deal; and it has been established that this is a good deal for the Government. There has not been one iota of evidence to spur those opposite on, but they have embarked upon a grubby exercise, desperate because of their positions on the back bench. No wonder Senator Bishop rings former colleagues to ask them why they do not vote for her and why they do not like her. I will tell those opposite why they do not like her. It is because she and Senator Parer have wasted time in this place time and time again pursuing an issue in which there is absolutely no substance.

—I shall not detain the Senate long. I am concerned, in contrast to Senator Parer, about the substantive business that this House should be conducting. But I rise briefly to make a couple of statements on some of the remarks that Senator Parer made about the establishment of the Australian Democrats' national secretariat building in Brisbane Avenue, Barton. The land in the golden triangle that is granted as a lease to national organisations which represent a significant section of the electorate, and that includes political parties, is for the very specific purpose of establishing and running in that building a national secretariat.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the Australian Democrats cannot rely on the sorts of donations that the Liberal Party can command from its donors, from its supporters, for whom it then comes into this House and rides shotgun on legislation to preserve the interests of its backers. We made the arrangements on a commercial basis. We have finished up with a national secretariat at 12 Brisbane Avenue, Barton, which was the original purpose of the granting of the lease.

We made approaches to a number of builders and developers. We finally selected a builder and developer who was prepared to put up a building, to grant a space and to enable us to run a national secretariat at that address. The transaction was an arm's length transaction. It was made on a commercial basis. The telling factor is that the Australian Democrats now run a national secretariat at that address, which was the purpose of the original lease. I will let rest our case there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, could I just—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Senator Walters, is this a point of order?

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, sort of. I just want to—
—Senator Walters, perhaps you could clarify what it is you want to do.

—I have a point of order. I just thought that it probably would be a good idea if I were to tell Senator Spindler that he said the golden triangle rather than the Parliamentary Triangle. He may mean the golden triangle as far as the Democrats are concerned but—
—There is no point of order, Senator Walters. I do not want to be unkind, but I suggest that you know that.

—I rise in this debate only to declare an interest before the Senate moves to vote on this matter. I would like to indicate to the Senate that I became a director of John Curtin House Ltd on 27 May 1992. I would also like to indicate to the Senate, as far as I understand it, that directors of John Curtin House Ltd are precluded from any remuneration under article 15 of the articles of association of the company. I also indicate to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that obviously I fulfil this role as a director in my capacity as a member of the National Executive of the Australian Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: When a previous matter was debated and voted upon in this chamber, I mentioned a similar interest—an interest that is shared by a number of other senators. I place that matter before the Senate. But I indicate that, because there is no pecuniary interest involved or nothing to preclude my voting on this matter, I will be participating on behalf of the people I represent in the vote that will, I assume, occur in the chamber in a few moments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to declare an interest. I am a director of John Curtin House Ltd. While I concur with all that Senator Faulkner has said, I also have received no return for my directorship or any remuneration of any sort in the whole time that I have been a director of the company. I believe I have a right to vote, much more so than members of the Opposition who have voted on many issues here when they have had direct pecuniary interests.

—in reply—The two honourable senators who have just spoken are both overpaid. Senator Bolkus came in here earlier and made all sorts of counterclaims about a matter that definitely must be raised by people in the Parliament. It is about probity and propriety. It is about whether an incumbent government in this climate displays probity and propriety, bearing in mind what we have seen in recent years by a few politicians—I say `a few'; it is by far a minority—who have brought the Parliament into disrepute. I might say—and I think I made this remark in previous debates in this place—that it could well be that we are at a stage where, irrespective of whether it is a good deal or a bad deal, an incumbent government cannot even contemplate going down this sort of track. That is the sort of situation that prevails in this country.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that this deal is a particularly good deal. I do not know anyone involved in any of these businesses who would not grab this with both hands—a 15-year lease and 10.5 per cent. It is all very well for Senator Bolkus to say that growth rates are projected to be higher. We talk about rates of return. We are talking about an inflation rate which is down because of a recession we had to have, from a Prime Minister we did not want. Hopefully, one of the things that may come out of this is continuing low inflation. Yet we see a deal done which has a guaranteed a 9 per cent inflation rate for the balance of the contract. That is per annum; the rent goes up every year 9 per cent from the date of completion of the building. It is 10.5 per cent retrospective to 1 January last year, even though the deal was made only in the last month or two months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Comparable with any other similar situation.
—This is where I disagree with Senator Beahan. Senator Bolkus made the same remark. I kept saying to him, `Tell me about Tourism House'. Tourism House is in Barton.
—Talk about McEwen House instead.

—I am happy to talk about McEwen House; we did debate that before. Tourism House is in Barton. If we compare the two, Tourism House has a gross rent of $306 per square metre. John Curtin House is currently, with the escalation figure, about $320. Senator Bolkus said $302, but if we take 10.5 per cent of the lease plus the outgoings—Senator Bolkus conveniently forgot the darned outgoings; it is an easy one to forget, is it not?—we end up with a figure currently, with the first year's escalation, of about $358 a square metre. The gross rent of Tourism House, which is in the same vicinity, is $306 with a 3 per cent CPI increase per annum. At the end of year one, it is $315.

PARA.TAB: The questions I am asking are, firstly, is it right and proper for an incumbent government in 1992 to contemplate putting a major government department within premises owned by the Australian Labor Party? Maybe the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration will say it is. Secondly, was the process of negotiation on the terms and conditions proper? I do not know, but the Committee will probably find that it was. Thirdly, were the terms and conditions in accordance with principles which should govern dealings between the Government and private bodies? In other words, was it a good deal or a bad deal? There are two quite distinct issues: the first deals with the probity and proprietary of doing it and the second is whether it was not a good deal.

If, as Senator Bolkus says, there is no problem and it is all above board, why is the Government opposed to sending it off to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration to report back by August? That question has not been addressed. I still believe that we have to go back to the probity and propriety of the matter. As I pointed out earlier, I think the general public is at a stage, because of a few bad apples that run around this country, where it is not prepared to accept that at this time in history and probably well into the future. I believe that this motion should be supported and that this matter should go off to a committee which could report back in August, at which time the whole thing would be put to rest.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Parer's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
