SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I might as well get this debate started because, not surprisingly, we are angry and disappointed by this regrettably predictable action of the Government. I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent debate taking place on the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the debate about urgency. At the end of practically every session now, the Australian Democrats conspire with the Government to curtail debate on critical legislation. This is despite the Democrats year after year promising that they will never do it again; that they will support freedom of speech in this chamber; and that they recognise that this is the only chamber in which there is any real legislative accountability. Despite those promises, time and again at this stage of the session they conspire with the Government to lock us out of the proper opportunity to debate these matters. What is before the Senate tonight is deplorable. I think there are over 30 packages of legislation. I have a few things to say about the Government, too—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Faulkner, you do not have the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I condemn the Democrats. They say that they are here to keep the bastards honest and yet they disprove that by their actions every year.

PARA.TAB: The Government cannot keep its House in order. It keeps changing the Manager of Government Business. Senator Ray had a go; Senator McMullan had a go. Each came in and promised to do better than the last. Each promised to put the program in order—and each failed just as deplorably as the other.

This situation is awful. With two weeks of this session remaining, there are over 30 major packages of legislation still to be debated. It is not our fault because we have kept pace with the Government's program from the start. Perhaps the program slipped a little bit during the Appropriations debate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is not rubbish. By and large, we have been on pace with the Government's program. In fact, at times we have had to find matters to deal with to fill the Government's program for it. We have had to do so because the Government cannot competently get its program in order.

PARA.TAB: The ultimate result of that failure of proper management will be that legislation will not receive the proper debate that it deserves in this chamber. We are talking about important

SPEECH.PARA: legislative packages such as the superannuation levy package and new taxation legislation. We have to deal with industrial relations legislation which the Government wants to use to curtail subcontractors. The Government wants to restrict this demonstrated efficient way of doing business in this country.

PARA.TAB: We also will have to debate the wholesale sales tax legislation which would impose further imposts on business and lead to further tragic levels of unemployment in this country. Perhaps the Government should recognise that there are nearly one million Australians out of work at the moment as a result of the recession that it said we had to have. Thirty-four per cent of young Australians seeking jobs cannot get jobs. In my State of South Australia, 45 per cent of young Australians who want jobs cannot get jobs. This Government wants to push through this legislation. It has done deals with the Democrats to enable it to put through pieces of legislation that will add further imposts on business and will further restrict the opportunity for young Australians to get work. It is an absolute disgrace and Government senators ought to hang their heads in shame.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —On each occasion in the four years that I have been in the Senate when a motion such as this has been moved, the same level of false indignation has been expressed. Senator Hill was the first person I have ever seen to make an angry speech with a smile on his face, because he knew that most of those opposite want this motion carried as much as we do and for exactly the same reason.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite all know that there are only three alternatives to this motion: firstly, that we sit for another week; secondly, that we sit late nights; and, thirdly, that we fail to pass the legislative program. Those three alternatives are all equally unacceptable. Let us look at the merit in this great posturing about why this matter has come up.

Senator Hill started to get excited and drew out a speech from some other occasion when it may or may not have been true that there had been all these gaps in the legislative program. A look at this session will show that there has not been any gaps, because we made the arrangement to have legislation in here at the start of the session, and it was here. The House of Representatives, whatever its many other faults may be, has passed legislation on schedule so that it can come in here. We have made appropriate arrangements to have legislation introduced in such a way that we have a flow of legislation all the time.
It is true that we have spent some time talking about pecuniary interests. We are going to do so again on the first day of the next sittings, in response to a request from Senator Hill that we do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator Walters should not get excited. He asked for it and we are going to do it. It is an important matter and we are going to deal with it until we get it finished. There will not be matters lying around waiting to be dealt with. It is not a question of failing to deal with the Senate's business. That is the Senate's business. It is a matter that should be dealt with, and it will be dealt with on the first day of the next sittings. I do not in any way apologise for taking up a bit of time to deal with that. It is important.

PARA.TAB: The other suggestion is that in some way any delays and the extent to which the program might be behind schedule are the fault of the Government and that the Opposition has been cooperative. Some members of the Opposition have tried very hard to be cooperative and I have appreciated that. In particular, the work of the Opposition Whips in trying to facilitate the work has been appreciated. But let us get it clear: we have this new outbreak of what is called `taking note of answers disease'. It is catching. It is like a lot of other diseases: it generates a lot of heat in the patient but it does not generate much light to the community. All we get is the flush of outrage, a lot of enthusiasm and a lot of time taken to no good purpose whatsoever.

Somebody has come up with this clever new tactic; we all have our theories about who, but it is not for me to say. It does take a lot of time. If the Opposition takes an hour and a half moving motions to take note of answers every day, we cannot be surprised if perhaps a bit less Government business is dealt with than would otherwise would have been the case. Alternatively, we get a situation such as we had with the industrial relations Bill of a list containing 20-plus speakers. We heard only about one-third of them. There was one speech seven times and 13 more people were listed to give it. This is hardly the mechanism that anybody would say was the basis of a cooperative arrangement to get the legislative program passed. That was the straw that broke the camel's back.

Here we have a much more generous guillotine motion than the Opposition ever introduced in all the time it was in government. It will get the Government business passed and allow a substantial amount of legislation to be debated and a substantial amount of debate on all the legislation. The minimum amount for any Bill is one hour, which is the most generous minimum there has ever been in such a motion. If it is to be criticised for anything, it might be that it is too generous. It will get the business done without our having to sit beyond midnight on any night unless we have some outrageous time wasting over and above that which we have already had. That is why we are moving the motion and that is why we do not support the suspension of Standing Orders.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion we are debating at the moment is not about posturing; it is about the prostitution of the parliamentary process that Senator McMullan and his Government have been all about. It is absolutely appalling that yet again the Senate is being subjected to jackboot, brutal treatment of the proper processes of government and decision making in this country. It is absolutely appalling, first of all, that the Government sees the need for this action. It is perhaps even more appalling that the Democrats propose to support it. There is not one Democrat in the Senate chamber to defend their rotten record of support for the Government in the last couple of years and what they are doing again tonight.

PARA.TAB: The Government has absolutely botched its legislative process in the same way that it has botched the whole of its performance in policy making and proper processes in the last few years. It is not true—and Senator McMullan knows it—that the Opposition has not been cooperative with him. He paid tribute to the Whips and, through that, to the coalition for what we have done. We have played the game straight with the Government. We have not at any time frustrated its legislative program. When we started this sittings, the Government was scratching for things for the Senate to do. It did not have a legislative program in place so it could have a proper process of legislation.

Several times during the period exactly the same thing has happened. Senator McMullan was away for the odd day or so, and on the odd day he was away there was virtually no legislative program at all. The honourable senator accused us of taking note of answers as a new gimmick, I think was the term he used. That process has elicited a lot more information than his Ministers were prepared to divulge through the normal Question Time process. It has enhanced the democratic process, not the reverse. In no way has that caused a delay in the Government's legislative program.

Quite frankly, the reason for this guillotine is bad government, sloppy government, incompetent government and, above all, appalling mismanagement. The sooner those opposite get their act together in the dying months of this Government, the sooner we might get a little improvement in the efficiency of the operation of this place.

As a result of the Government's sloppiness, major Bills will be passed with little or no consideration—and not just by the Senate. Because of the Government's mismanagement, it also had to guillotine something like 40 Bills through the House of Representatives. These are major Bills dealing with the future of this country. They are dealing with the two million people that the Government has caused to be unemployed or underemployed; they are dealing with the whole tax structure of the country; and they are dealing with the gamut of industrial legislation and a whole raft of major matters affecting rural industry. No consideration will be given to those Bills because of this guillotine process.

That is the most anti-democratic situation that one can have in a parliamentary system. There will be a cost to business and an impact on jobs as a result of the legislation which the Government will jack-boot through this place in the next few days. More than 60 Bills which are subject to the guillotine will be put through with virtually no consideration at all.

The Australian Democrats sit here and try to tell us that they are the party that is going to `keep the bastards honest'. That is what the Democrats have said. But in the last two years and more we have seen the Democrats become simply political mouthpieces for this Government. They said that they wanted to see proper processes of government pursued. That was one of the reasons why they were here. They said they wanted to see the integrity of the Senate preserved. Instead, the Democrats have become partners in crime with the Government and they have frustrated the proper processes of government and the proper processes of this Parliament. The Liberal and National parties object totally to this jack-booted, arrogant, anti-democratic approach by the Government and its acolytes to the Australian people.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —When Senator Hill was getting excited, he said that this side of the House had had a lot of managers. I would like to put the record straight: in fact, we have had four in nine years. That is about average.
—Who was the best?

—Senator McMullan happens to be the best. Senator Jones and former Senator Robinson were the two Whips during that time. We have heard those opposite bleating, `Look, we haven't really tried to delay the legislative program; we've tried to cooperate'. As Senator McMullan has said, there has been some degree of cooperation and I think he listed that. No-one is accusing the Opposition of an organised filibuster because it is an inadvertent filibuster. Those opposite do not know what they are doing half the time. They note questions, debate this, argue about that, spend 40 minutes giving notices of motion—at least twice this session 40 minutes was spent on rubbish notices of motion—and waste time.

PARA.TAB: We have the interjectors here as usual, but a lot have been cowed out of the debate this time. As I look around, I see that there are really only two left. Seven or eight Opposition senators used to come in here and say, `This Government is being anti-democratic when it decides to guillotine'.

When we go through the Senate Journals from 1975 to 1981 we find that the old recidivists—the guillotiners and the gaggers—are there, not Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine would remember that Senator Durack walked into this chamber many times and declared Bills urgent. He would also recall that he did not have the privilege of this debate because when the mob on the other side of the chamber moved a guillotine motion they would gag the motion so even that could not be debated.

We are slow learners over here; we still let the debate go for 2 1/2 hours. Senator Durack nods in assent because when he walked in, he would move the guillotine and then he would move the gag and with him was the hat-trick of pathetic Tasmanians—Senator Walters, Senator Watson and Senator Archer—who voted for every guillotine and gag that was put up by those opposite. So did Senator Teague, Senator MacGibbon and Senator Lewis. They all came in here and voted for the guillotine and the gag with great joy. Yet most of them now have the decency to absent themselves from the chamber and not interrupt my speech as they have when I have delivered exactly the same speech on two or three previous occasions.

Then we have Senator Short opening his mouth. Have a look at the record in the House of Representatives when he represented Ballarat for five years. Time and time again Senator Short voted for the gag and the guillotine. But he learnt a lot when he went out into the wilderness for three years. He has come back in here renewed as a real democrat and of course he is never going to vote to gag again. It is the same with the missing Senator Baume, who also voted consistently for gags and guillotines.

If senators on the other side are serious; if their road to Damascus conversion is absolutely sincere, they should sign up now and say that in future years they will never vote for a guillotine. Come on, I want an indication from any one of them sitting there—from Senator Boswell, through to Senator Short, up to Senator Crane, around to Senator Campbell. I say to those opposite, `Put up your hands if you will never vote for a guillotine'. They will always reserve that right. We will probably come in here and fulminate against them if they are ever in government, if they have the absolute temerity ever to move a guillotine motion.

Of course, deep down, those opposite want this motion to go through. Deep down, they love guillotines. It orders the debate; it makes their contribution concise; and they can all be home for seven weeks, out of the terrible winter that is afflicting us here. Not only is this good for those opposite, but also it is good group therapy because they get all their frustrations out and they get them out without bothering us on the adjournment debate or in other ways. So this is a wonderful debate for those opposite. They get what they want, which is a guillotine, an ordered debate, and they also cleanse their souls of all sorts of frustrations. But they will not do the final thing I ask them to do: will they give me an assurance that they will never vote for a guillotine motion as long as they live? No, they will not. They will not give me that guarantee, so the only word that describes the collective approach of the Opposition is hypocrisy. When those opposite are in government they vote for the guillotine and when they are in opposition they oppose it, and if they ever get into government again, they would support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard the catalogue of the history of the Opposition. When those opposite were in government, they were very prepared to make sure they got their legislation through using exactly the same methods that the Government wishes to use now. They believe that, following the next election, they will be in government again. Mark my words, the Australian Democrats will still be in this chamber holding the balance of power and those opposite will be relying upon us to help them get their legislation at least debated, and that is the point at issue here. We take the position that the Government at least has the responsibility and the right to have its legislation debated—not necessarily passed, but at least brought up and debated. That is what we are ensuring by supporting this motion here tonight.

PARA.TAB: I think it should be obvious to everybody who walks even in a most cursory fashion through this chamber that the so-called second reading debates are not debates at all. In the case of the so-called resource security legislation we saw 17 Opposition speakers going over and over exactly the same material—already having made up their mind exactly what they were going to do—and completely wasting time in this chamber. The effective debates that go on in this chamber are those in the committee stage, and they are a much smaller part of the debating of legislation.

We believe, as I have said, that the Government has a right at least to have its legislation debated. We are giving no guarantee that we will pass any of this legislation, but at least the Government has a right to have it debated. I remind the ladies and gentlemen of the Opposition when it becomes their turn—and we will still be here on these benches—that they will be relying upon us at exactly the same time in each session to get their legislation at least debated. I say the same thing to them: we will give no guarantee that their legislation will necessarily be passed. But at least we will give an undertaking that they will have a right to get their legislation brought into this place and have it debated. That is what we are offering to the Government on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. I believe that what we are debating is the suspension of Standing Orders so as to enable Senator Hill and the Senate to debate the guillotine motion as moved by Senator McMullan.

PARA.TAB: I have never supported, and do not intend ever to support, the guillotine. The situation that we are faced with in this chamber is virtually a denial of the rights of individual senators to exercise their primary function. That primary function is the expressive function; that is, to express the views of constituents on the legislation that is before us.

I refer to only three or four of the Bills that are before us—I think there are 57—that are now subject to the guillotine. We have a mere three hours to debate the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill and a mere three hours on the Broadcasting Services Bill and the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. The broadcasting legislation is to set in place provisions relating to free-to-air television and other broadcasting categories, including pay TV. It will set them into concrete. Frankly, what that legislation does is to give legislatively to the industry a power which is not warranted. It is industry friendly and is the enemy of the consumers. I will, of course, be going into that. What it will do, of course—and I want people who are on the Government side to listen to this—is remove ultimately the provisions applicable to free-to-air television relating to content which is blasphemous, indecent or obscene.

The Government has given only three hours for that particular debate. The legislation goes into ownership and all other mechanisms. This debating time is an absolute disgrace. We are talking about freedom of speech. We are talking about giving the right to certain people in the television and radio industries to make money. The Government has given to the industry the right to prepare codes of conduct which involve program standards and complaints procedures.

There will be a great backlash against any Government member, or indeed any member, who might vote against proposed amendments that I intend to move to this particular Bill to protect the public interest. Government members may not have time to debate them, but that is their fault. If they vote against them, they will be blamed by every TV viewer who is offended by certain material that comes across broadcast television. I certainly will be pointing the finger of shame and blame at them for not supporting them.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Coulter.

—They may support it; I do not know. The Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill 1992, a very important Bill, has been given one hour for debate. The Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 has been given only four hours.

PARA.TAB: Tonight I have before me a document which, apparently, the Government has agreed to. It represents a sell-out of the workers of this country and will give to the Industrial Relations Commission the power to offset wage increases because of what the Government is going to do with superannuation. Why does the Government think that families cannot now maintain their standard of living on one income? It is because of the decline in real wages; it is also because of the taxation discrimination that the Government imposed upon one-income families. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a pleasure to follow Senator Harradine, who made some very pertinent remarks. I will support this motion. The Government wants desperately to get out of this place. It wants to get out of here as fast as it can because it is getting a hiding on unemployment; it is getting a hiding on the Marshall Islands affair; it is getting a hiding on superannuation; and it is getting a hiding on industrial relations, where it cannot even get an agreement with the unions. The unions are going one way and the ALP is going the other. All that Government members want to do is to go home. I do not blame them. If I were getting a beating around the ears, as Government members have been getting over the past two weeks, I would want to go home too, put a pillow over my head, and forget it all.
—Why don't you?
—Because the Government has one million people unemployed and all it wants to do is get out—
—Order! The time for debate on the suspension motion has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question put:
That the Bills be declared urgent Bills.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the time allotted for consideration of the Bills be as follows:

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice that Senator Robert Ray is leaving the chamber before he even hears the debate. What a preconceived arrogance! The matter is not even open to debate. Having repeated the same speech he has given on half a dozen occasions, he pompously marches out of the chamber without being prepared to debate the issue.

PARA.TAB: It is quite outrageous for Senator Robert Ray to suggest that in some obscure, perverted way the Opposition gets some satisfaction out of this motion. Absolutely nothing is further from the truth. We are prepared to stay here as long as it takes to have a proper, democratic debate on all 69 pieces of legislation which are before the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had none at the beginning.

—We had none at the beginning, and I will come to that in a minute. We are prepared to stay as long as is necessary to ventilate our views, participate in meaningful debate and expose the legislation for what it is. Of course, the Government wants to pack its bags and run. It is terrified that there may be some public scrutiny, public examination or public criticism of its legislation.

PARA.TAB: We do not want the Government's program; we do not want the Government's legislation; and we do not want its Bills. We are prepared to stay here as long as is necessary to make that point clear. Senator Patterson interjected a moment ago to observe that at the beginning of this session there was no legislation. There was an absolute vacuum. This Government could not run a chook raffle. For days we had to filibuster and invent debate so as to ensure that the Senate could continue to function in some way.

Unlike the Government, we do respect the forms of the Senate and the Parliament and we are prepared to go through the proper processes to ensure that legislation is introduced and read a first time, debated and read a second time, the clauses are debated and then, if necessary, a debate on the third reading. It has not dawned on the Government that this is a House of second consideration and second contemplation. This is the chamber where, in the event the Government makes mistakes, whether deliberate or in drafting, mistakes are corrected. This is the chamber where amendments can be effected and where legislation can be changed.

How often have we seen legislation introduced into this chamber from the House of Representatives to find it is deficient, defective or wrong and the Government is obliged to amend its own legislation? We now have something like 39 hours in which to debate 69 pieces of legislation. This is legislation of great moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —They'll all come back to be amended.

—That is right. In due course, as Senator Patterson quite sensibly interjects, most of this legislation will come back to us to be corrected and have the defects amended accordingly. The legislation before us is not without significance. They are major pieces of legislation affecting the daily lives of most Australians. Of course, with the Government's cavalier disregard for the rights of the Opposition, for the forms of the Parliament and for proper processes and proper debate, this legislation will be rushed through the chamber without an opportunity for it to be scrutinised and examined. For instance, the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 fundamentally changes the common law premise upon which our legislation thus far has stood. We now have legislation where contractual relationships between two private parties can be interfered with, changed or cancelled at the whim or the wish of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. We have legislation before us now which will ensure that the cost of the ordinary private home to the ordinary average Australian will go up by $20,000 per unit simply to satisfy and placate Senator Peter Cook's old mates in the Builders Workers Industrial Union. We have legislation before us which will choke off the modest beginnings and the spluttering start of some stimulation in the housing sector. Because of the bloody-minded determination of this Government to bend and bow to the wishes of its trade union master, that growth will be choked off.

PARA.TAB: We have a situation in Australia where about 85 per cent of workers are employed under industrial relations agreements, yet only 42 per cent are members of unions. That demonstrates that the average worker does not want to be in a union, does not want to be intimidated and does not want to be party to a union. Yet we have legislation before us which will coerce and cause people to be signed up to join unions irrespective of their wishes.

We have all sorts of other legislation before us to debate. We have the wool Bills. As I remember, the wool Bills are amending the original legislation which imposed a 15 per cent levy on the woolgrowers of Australia. We managed to reduce it to 12 per cent. Now it will be reduced to a much more reasonable level—our original level. In a very vain, crude, artificial way the Government proposed that there be a refund, a tax cheque, in hand. That legislation will not be debated in a proper way. It is subject to a one-hour debate. There are five pieces of amending legislation which we will have one hour to debate.

The Customs Legislation (Tariff Concessions and Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill is to be debated. In that legislation the Government is looking for political efficiency, not economic efficiency; the Government is bowing to short term political pressure which will impose an added tariff on this country at the cost of the rest of the taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —$12,000 on a car.

—Yes, that is right—for short term political gain, for long term economic loss! We also have to debate the Sales Tax Assessment Bill and five associated pieces of legislation—a vain attempt to restructure the ramshackled wholesale sales tax legislation. It would have been an ideal opportunity to have debated the goods and services tax and to explain to the Australian people why Paul Keating's 1983 proposal to introduce a goods and services tax was found to be wanting.

PARA.TAB: We also have to debate the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 and four pieces of complementary legislation. This legislation will impose an added cost, an added burden, on the employers of Australia, significantly reduce employment and, naturally, increase unemployment. It is simply an addition to payroll tax. We also have to debate the Taxation Laws Amendment Bills and the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill. All this legislation is vital to Australia, yet members of the Government are prepared to guillotine the legislation through for no good reason other than that, at the end of this fortnight, they want to get up and go home. They are not prepared to involve themselves in a proper debate simply because they are not prepared to allow the public to have the opportunity to scrutinise their legislation. I know it is a vain hope, but I hope the motion before us is defeated.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—I call Senator Macdonald.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—I am sorry, I call Senator Aulich. Senator Macdonald will get the call next, as speakers are called evenly from each side, one after the other.

—Nice try, Senator Macdonald. Anyone in this chamber who has had any experience in politics would realise that running Parliament in the way it should be run is a question of balance. It is a question of trying to work out how governments can be made accountable; how to get debates on major issues that may not be on the legislative agenda put before the Senate and before the Australian people; making sure that sufficient legislation gets through this Parliament to enable the Government to run smoothly; and ensuring that it is debated appropriately.

PARA.TAB: That balance is something that every government has to try to work out. The Government cannot simply force its way through this chamber, where it does not have the numbers, where it has to negotiate and where it has to talk with either of the other two major parties. It will not have its way all the time. Everyone knows that we have to talk to the Democrats, the Liberal Party and members of the National Party, when the Liberals let them off the leash, if we want to ensure that we get the passage of legislation.

We all know that ultimately in this place there must be some form of compromise in order to make this Parliament work. The Government cannot enforce its will willy-nilly on this chamber. We all know that. Let us not pretend that for some reason or other tonight the Government has said, in a capricious and arbitrary manner, `We are going to impose this time schedule on you'. The Opposition knows that the Democrats, who have had a fairly consistent policy about the use of guillotines, have come to the end of their tether. They know that there is significant legislation that must be considered. They know that without the use of the guillotine on occasions, the Opposition will take every advantage to fill in all the available time so that proper review of legislation is not possible in this chamber.

It always amazes me that oppositions in some States and in some Federal parliaments, particularly this Opposition, see some disadvantage in discussing and debating government legislation. I would have thought that if philosophically and practically the Opposition wanted to examine legislation in a thorough, detailed and rational way, it would have ensured that at least half of those elements of parliamentary trickery that it has been practising in the last few months were not practised and that it left most of the time for Government legislation.

The Opposition has Question Time every day to make its views known and to get information out of the Government. It has a number of parliamentary techniques which allow it to discuss issues that it wants to discuss and to make the Government accountable in that ad hoc way that those particular parliamentary techniques allow it to do. Yet what has it done? It has lacked self-discipline. Members of the Liberal Party and the National Party cannot talk to each other, but they are in coalition. The Nationals and the Liberals hardly talk to each other when it gets down to big issues. For example, did they talk to each other over tariffs on sugar? They cannot tell me that they did.

We should look at the times that the Opposition tried to get a rational view about debates in this chamber. It knows what goes on in its party rooms. Those opposite who want to have a rational arrangement of the legislative program of the whole processes in this chamber—those who believe in that—have been rolled simply by the pig-headed ones in their party that they have no control over. They are always the same people.

Senator Walters always voted for the guillotine when she was in government. She never once crossed the floor on a guillotine motion. Every time Senator Durack and others walked in and said, `We move the gag now', she voted with it. Her high principles went out the window. When she was not voting for the guillotine when she was in this chamber in government, in opposition she used every trick in the book to ensure that rational, reasonable debate did not occur in this chamber. Talk about democracy!

Who is the loudest interjector in this place? Who always interjects on every speech? Who cannot stop herself calling out? Who, when she has problems not understanding what other people are saying or when she disagrees with them, calls quorums on any member of the Government trying to make a few points? The more effective they are in the points they make, the more likely Senator Walters is to call a quorum on them. I remember many occasions when Senator Walters would call a quorum and then walk out of the chamber, having disrupted the flow of someone's speech and the debate in the chamber. On many occasions Senator Walters and, I might say, Senator Newman have called two quorums during a 10-minute speech.

How can those opposite come into this House and talk about their concern for democratic procedures when they, on many occasions, have abused those procedures, not only when they were in opposition—and they have been there for nine years or so—but also when they were in government? I really cannot believe that Senator Walters could sit in this debate hoohing and howling about how anti-democratic this Government is because it wants to get on with some quick debate about some major legislation.

What legislation are we looking at? Let us have a look at it. First of all, there is the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill, which refers in particular to independent contractors. That is a very important part of that Bill. It was an issue that was raised in 1985.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne was heard in reasonable silence. I ask honourable senators on my left to give the same privilege to Senator Aulich.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is true that those opposite have attempted to disrupt my speech in a most anti-democratic way. I am not hurt by it, and I accept your protection. But, at the same time, I understand that the same old patterns of behaviour are occurring again—those who shout interjections and then walk out of the chamber. Those sorts of things are happening even before my very eyes.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt, when we look at the legislation that this Government is putting through now and that we want to discuss tonight, that there are some major issues contained in that legislation. I want the debate; I want the opportunity, for example, to debate with Senator Crane and Senator Calvert these issues relating to independent contractors. Those issues have been around since 1985 when the Hancock inquiry brought forward its views about what should happen to the industrial relations system in Australia. I look forward to that debate.

Many things have occurred in this chamber to prevent us from getting to that particular issue. We have already examined that issue in our Committee. It has been referred back to the chamber. I am saying tonight: let us get on with it. Those opposite have strong views about it. Their views contrast markedly with ours. There is no doubt that that debate should be heard. It should not be put off until the late hours of this evening or early into the next morning, continuing the stupid sitting patterns that we have been following in terms of the hours that we have had to sit in this chamber. It should be heard, for example, when members of the press are around, so that they, and through them the people of Australia, are aware that there are major differences between the major political parties on this issue of industrial relations.

At the end of the day, this forum is the only one that we have. Rather than, for example, saying, `Let's fill in our time with stupid motions that are coming across to make the Government look silly' and wasting time on that sort of thing, why not do the alternative thing, which is to look at Government legislation so that, through an analysis, study and debate about that legislation, those opposite can get their points across? It is a more effective way for an opposition to work than the way those opposite have been working in the last few months. The way they have been working in the last few months has been simply to waste time and to delay legislation when, in fact, they should be in here having the courage to debate that legislation. Those opposite do not seem to have the courage. They run away using all these other techniques in the Parliament to waste time. They should come to us now and debate with us. We are very glad to debate our Bills with them. I am sure, if they really allowed themselves, they would enjoy the debate as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator Aulich leaves the chamber, I would like to bring one point to his attention. He said that we have been wasting time and not getting onto legislation. Can anyone tell me how long it has been since the 60-odd Bills on the list before us went through the House of Representatives? If we have been delaying—and I wish Senator Aulich would listen to this—this heap of legislation, why is it—
—Stupid notices of motion—you bring them up every day.

—It has just come up from the House of Representatives? Are we holding up the House of Representatives? I think Senator McKiernan is more stupid than he looks if he reckons that. That is the point. This evening Senator McMullan told us in shock-horror that we are at it again. He is the Manager of Government Business—or `Mismanager' of Government Business. We started here after the summer break on 25 February and sat for two weeks and then we had two weeks off; we then had two weeks on and three weeks off; we then had two weeks on and two weeks off; and then we had two weeks on and one week off. We are now at the beginning of a two-week sitting period. The point is that we lost three weeks in one lot and two weeks in another when the Government was out trying to sell the One Nation package and getting nowhere with it. That is where the time was lost. Senator Aulich has the hide to stand up—supported by Senator McKiernan—and say that the Opposition is delaying legislation. The legislation went through the House of Representatives sausage machine two weeks ago. How could we have delayed it? This is our first week back. Senator Aulich cannot say that we have delayed this package of Bills. The Government needs a lesson on how not to run out of time.

PARA.TAB: We have been spoken to about taking note of answers at the end of Question Time. If Ministers told the truth in their answers and did not misrepresent what is in the Hewson Fightback package, there would be no need for us to get up and put the record straight that there will not be 15 per cent added on to everything that is sold in Australia. Time and time again, in answer to a backbencher's question, a dorothy dixer, Ministers finish by saying that it will cost 15 per cent more. The Opposition has to take note of those answers. We get up and tell them. That is the whole point.

Other things have happened this session which have wasted time. If Senator Richardson, the former Minister for Transport and Communications, had not had selective amnesia like a few of his colleagues in Western Australia, if he had not been injudicious in the Marshall Islands affair, we would have saved hours and hours and hours. When he was caught with his fingers in the cookie jar, for want of a better saying—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit unfair.

—I will take that back and describe it some other way. When he was caught out on the matter, if he had come in here and, instead of pretending not to know anything, said, `Yes, I plead guilty'—if I am allowed to use that term; I was called up for using it before—we would not have wasted the time that we did. We then had Senator Sibraa with his injudicious letter to our Ambassador in New York. If that had not happened, we would not have wasted time chasing answers on that one.
—What about Gareth Evans?

—I thank Senator Walters; I nearly forgot Senator Gareth Evans. He gets up and answers questions as though he would never think of putting a foot out of line. If Senator Evans had come clean and said, `Yes, I did make a mistake, I apologise; let's get on with it', it would have taken the wind out of our sails and we would have got on with legislation—the legislation that was not here, incidentally. That is the situation. Hours and hours went into extracting the truth. It was like pulling teeth out. That is where the time was wasted. Let it not be said that the Opposition wasted time. In the early days of these sittings the legislation was not forthcoming. We sat for two weeks after Christmas and then had two off; we then had two weeks on and three weeks off while the Government was off on its wild-goose chase of trying to sell its One Nation package. That is the situation. The Government and the Manager of Government Business are blaming us for things that we did not do.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the Democrats—the pure whites. Senator Kernot was described on television tonight as playing hard to get. I have known those who have played hard to get, but I will not go into that right now. The Democrats are supporting the guillotine on the superannuation levy Bill—one of the most important and costly Bills to ever come before this Parliament. It will send umpteen employers out of business. How much time has the Government allocated for that?

The Democrats have played hard to get for about the last week or two and tonight they have folded up. They reckon they have a victory, saying that it is only 4 per cent with the rest coming in later. To me, all that represents is a stay of execution. If one is to be executed and is aware of that fact, one may as well get it over and done with—although I would never want to be in that position. We will let those employers linger on for probably another 12 months and then we will send them down the tube. So the Democrats, with Senator Kernot playing the lead role, have now agreed with the Government to sell 100,000 jobs down the drain soon after this legislation goes through. That is how the Democrats see keeping people honest in this place—and that is how they have always done it.

The Democrats then talked about the Opposition wasting time in second reading debates! How many times have my colleagues seen a Democrat—in this session or last session or ever since I have been in this place—take less than half an hour?

TALK.START.PARA: —Very rarely.

—They have rarely taken less than half an hour. Furthermore, we will be restricted in some of these debates to half an hour on the second reading. If a Democrat gets onto the speakers list on one of those one-hour Bills, I will bet my bottom dollar—and I do not do that very often—that he or she will use up that half an hour. So, if there is an hour on any Bill, the Democrats will still use up half of that time. Yet they come in here and tell us to stay honest!

PARA.TAB: I now look at the time allocations for the most important Bills that we are to debate. For instance, for the coal Bills we have the allocation of one hour. Coal is worth $6 billion of export income so badly needed by Australia. We have major legislation, major amendments, and the Government allows us one hour.
Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill, as Senator Schacht knows, is going to put the cost of housing up 30 per cent and do away with jobs. The Government's own research has shown that and there are no two ways about it: labour costs will go up 50 per cent, so at least half of that will be on the cost of housing—25 or 30 per cent. That Bill has been allocated three hours.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, I do not mind it going up 30 per cent, because everything I own will go up 30 per cent with it. We also have legislation affecting the wool industry. The wool industry is still worth $3 billion. We have major amendments to fix up the legislation from last year—and the Government has allocated one hour. That is what the Government thinks of the wool farmers of Australia—it has allowed one hour.

PARA.TAB: What has this Government allowed for debate on the superannuation guarantee levy legislation where there are 100,000 jobs at stake? It has allowed four hours of debate; in other words, one hour for 25,000 jobs which will go. We have the sales tax amendment Bills. Sales tax raises $10 billion—and the Government has allowed four hours for debate on that legislation. And so it goes on.

It is utterly disgraceful that so much legislation is cut back to such a short time. We did not hold this legislation up. It has only just gone through the House of Representatives. This is an utter and total disgrace and I believe it should be put where it belongs—and that is aside.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. You did some time ago indicate that you would call me to speak. You have now called three other speakers since you indicated that to me.
—He recognises quality, obviously.
—If he recognised quality, he would not have called you, Senator Schacht.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you have called other people after indicating publicly that you were going to call me and after an arrangement had been made, as I understand, with the previous occupant of the chair. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, I approached you about this and you indicated something to me along the lines of, `If you act like that, you will never get called'. I take some umbrage with that and I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to indicate what you are going to do. Are you simply going to continue ignoring me when I rise to seek the call?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to speak briefly to the point of order. While it is a matter for you under the Standing Orders which Opposition senator you call when it is the Opposition's turn, the reason you gave Senator Aulich the call ahead of Senator Macdonald on that occasion and Senator Schacht on this occasion is that the Standing Orders also indicate, as do the normal processes of the Senate, that the procedure should be one speaker from the Opposition and then one from the Government. That is why Senator Aulich and Senator Schacht have been given the call.

PARA.TAB: As to which senators you call within the Opposition, Mr Acting Deputy President, that is a matter for you to decide. If you chose Senator Panizza rather than Senator Macdonald, that is not a matter about which I have any influence or would wish to exercise influence. In fact, I thought there was a case for Senator Boswell getting the call in the circumstances notwithstanding. But, once again, that is a matter for the Opposition; I do not wish to interfere in its sequence of speakers. Although three Government senators have been chosen, two of them have been for the reason that it was the Government's turn in the normal procedure. That Senator Panizza was chosen over Senator Macdonald is not a matter about which I wish to make any comment one way or the other, because it is not a matter for me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! Senator Schacht was the first speaker on the point of order. Everyone will get a chance to speak to the point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to respond briefly to that point of order.
—No. I suggest that Senator Schacht has the call. He was the first to rise.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order—
—It is side to side.
—It is a point of order. As I understand it, Senator Schacht was the first on his feet on the point of order. No-one will be denied the opportunity of speaking.
—It is side to side.
—As I understand it, points of order are not a debate. They are matters to be raised to be adjudicated on.

—I would be more than happy to assist in this debate, because I do not think the order on this matter will be the end of Christianity, motherhood or free society. I am more than happy to waive the call to give it to Senator Macdonald because I will enjoy going after him.

—I want to speak to the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. If you threatened Senator Macdonald as Senator Macdonald has claimed you did, and if he behaved like that in bringing to your attention that you had called him, made a mistake and called Senator Aulich when he appealed to you, and you then threatened him that if he behaved like that he would never get the call, that is certainly against standing orders. You are there to be fair and just to all parties and, indeed, to be impartial. I do not believe that your comment was in any way impartial, fair or just.
—Senator Walters, would you please get to the point of order. What is your point of order?
—If you have not understood, the point of order is that you are meant to be impartial and you are not being impartial.
—Senator Walters, please resume your seat. I will take all points of order and answer them altogether.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a somewhat different point of order. I totally support Senator Walters's comments. The point I want to make is in support of Senator Macdonald's remarks to you. With great respect, there is an arrangement about which you are aware. Senator Macdonald was to be called next. The arrangement was firstly with the President and he passed it on to you. You called Senator Macdonald when Senator Aulich stood, and you took the other side of the chamber; I understand that point. I want it to be left in no doubt that there was a firm agreement that Senator Macdonald was to be called.

—My ruling is this: it is true that the President did say to me that Senator Macdonald had the call. My impression was that people from the Government were not going to rise in the debate until a later stage. When Senator Aulich sought the call, he was entitled to it on the basis of fairness, one from either side. So he got the call. Senator Panizza was very quick on his feet, so I called him. If the Opposition cannot organise their own speakers so that Senator Macdonald could get the call with its agreement, that is its problem. Therefore, I called Senator Panizza; I do not resile from that. It would be my intention to call Senator Boswell, who has claimed some priority as Leader of the National Party, unless he wishes to defer to Senator Macdonald.
—I defer to Senator Macdonald.
—That doesn't deal with my point of order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—There was no point of order at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think you owe this chamber an explanation of Senator Macdonald's assertion that you intimidated him and said that he may never get the call under the circumstances that he has raised with you. You have not explained that, and I think the Senate deserves an explanation of it immediately.

—That is no point of order, and I do not respond to scurrilous accusations. I had been sitting in this chair adjudicating. Senator Macdonald came up to me in a very aggressive fashion and was insulting in what he said to me. I suggested that he resume his seat.
—Is that all you suggested?
—Yes, Senator Walters, it is.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, do I have 10 minutes?
—I suggest it would be fair that everyone agree that you have 10 minutes.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I do not like being beholden to Senator Schacht. I accept Senator Boswell's kind gesture to allow me to speak in this debate. I wish to start my speech on this matter by clarifying what you have just said. I stood as quickly as Senator Panizza did, and you saw that. When I went over to speak to you, I said, `What happened to me? What happened to the arrangement?'. You said to me, `If you act like that, you'll never get called'.

PARA.TAB: I just want that on the record, Mr Acting Deputy President. I do not know what it is that you have against me. Is it the fact that I continue to show up Labor people in Queensland as being absolutely hopeless and being ignored by this Government continually? What is it that you have against me? Every time you are in the chair, you treat me in a way which is different from the approach of any other Acting Deputy President, the Deputy President or the President himself. I say that at this point because I hope it will prevent that sort of mistreatment in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Macdonald, I wish to state categorically that that is not true.
—That is out of order.
—No, it is not really. I am trying to defend myself.

—It is the sign of a dying government in its last days that it has to bring forward guillotines to curtail legislation so that it can get across to all its mates all of the deals it has promised and it knows it will soon no longer have the opportunity of giving out. That is why we on this side are so incensed that the very important legislation that is before the Parliament, possibly the most important legislation in the two years I have been in this chamber, is now being rushed through the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, never said much that made any sense, but the one thing he did say that has been proved correct is, `If you can't govern yourselves, you can't govern the nation'. This Government in its dying days is proof positive of that. It simply cannot manage the legislative program before it. It has no idea of how it would get these Bills through if it were serious in any way about trying to get them through. It chooses to fiddle around for the rest of the sittings, leaving very little business before the Parliament, and to leave it right to the last minute to bring in this very important legislation, much of which has a lot of influence and many positive effects for its mates, the people it has always supported while it has been in government—the unions, the ACTU, the big businessmen, the big newspapers and the media people. They are the sort of people who will benefit from this legislation.

This legislation will not be properly scrutinised because of the way the Government has deliberately mismanaged its business in this chamber to curtail the proper review of this legislation by us. The Government will use every trick at its disposal, even the sort of thing that happened to me earlier tonight, to make sure these matters are not brought to the notice of the Australian public. The Government will stop at nothing and stoop to no end to stop us properly discussing this legislation.

I suppose we have grown to expect that from a government in its last days. But we have cooperated; we have tried to make sure that the Government would get all of the legislation through. As Senator Aulich mentioned, we have taken note of a lot of answers after Question Time, but that is simply because Ministers continue to abuse Question Time by making long public statements and ministerial statements and depriving us of the use of Question Time to bring forward our points of view. We have cooperated, but those opposite have rejected that simply so they could continue to give away benefits to their mates in the dying days of their Government.

We have come to expect that, but what we have not come to expect—what I still cannot get over and what I want to address the rest of my remarks to—is the behaviour of the people on the left-hand side of us. They are the ultra-left wing of the Labor Party; a group that those opposite would not have even in their Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are pointing at Ronny Boswell.

—No, I am pointing at the Australian Democrats—the ultra-left wing of the Labor Party. Even it would not have them because of the way they carry on. Time and time again they say that this is a House of review. I wish Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter were here to look me in the eye and tell me about all the speeches they make around the countryside, saying how marvellous they are, how beneficial the Senate is as a chamber of review, how legislation is debated only in the Senate and what a good thing it is, and how they are the custodians of that democracy at work.

PARA.TAB: But what do they do? When the first opportunity arrives to discuss important legislation, they go to bed with the Government again. They are prostitutes of the Parliament. As has been said very often: one cannot buy them any more, one simply hires them by the minute.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! Senator Macdonald, I suggest that you withdraw that remark about prostitution. I think it is a rather harsh word to use and I ask you to withdraw it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a word that has been used quite often, particularly in relation to the Democrats. I will withdraw the word and use the phrase `ladies of the night' which I have used quite often. If you want me to use that, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will use it. That is what they are. Their favours are bought time and time again by this Government. You go into the back rooms and do the sleazy deals with this lot here all the time. You are available for hire by the Government. Why you do not have the courage to go and sit with Government senators all the time, I do not really know. You should at least have the courage to go and sit with them all the time.
—Order! Senator Macdonald, could you address your remarks through the Chair please.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The Democrats are a scourge upon democracy in this Parliament. Whenever important legislation comes before us which should be debated here, the Democrats will go into the back rooms and sell themselves to the Government.
—What is the price?
—We continue to see what the price is as we go: a few extra staff, a little extra consideration in the chamber, free advertising—
—$1m worth of advertising.

—That is not a bad bribe. Yet the Democrats go around the countryside telling everybody how they are looking after the Parliament and how they are looking after the people. The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL

The proposed amendments to the Industrial Relations Legislation Bill 1992 are yet another example of the influence of the unions and the ACTU over the Federal Government. Or to put it another way, they display what little input the Federal Labour Government has in the formulation of its own policies.
We have before us a set of legislative amendments which seek to entrench union "participation" or what I would call interference in two vital areas of industrial relations: namely-
a) in respect of independent contracts; and
b) in the area of certified agreements.

We have a set of amendments that give the AIRC an unfettered power to review contracts for services, including those contracts of independent contractors. This may be at the behest of a party to the contract itself or at the request of a union, even where that contractor is not a member of the union in question.

We have a further set of amendments which claim to facilitate and further extend enterprise agreements and extend their use—but in reality they increase the role of interfering unions and much to the chagrin of industry, they will impede agreements being struck and presented to the AIRC for certification.

And why is Senator Cook seeking these amendments? Not at the behest of industry and employer organisations. Not even at the request of independent contractors. But because of Cook's relationship and the relationship of the Federal Government, with the ACTU.

We can see a direct relationship between the introduction of these amendments and the failure of the BWIU in the Troubleshooters decision to obtain AIRC constitutional coverage of independent contractors in the commercial/industrial building sector. Having failed to achieve such coverage via the High Court, the BWIU and the ACTU have sought to lean on the Federal Government to achieve union dominance in the workplace via legislative means. The unions are petrified that the High Court decision will further reduce their control of the workplace and they have decided to take action. That is originally why the amendments were drafted. That is why we are here. Not because of some policy initiative of the Federal Government.

The Government has now withdrawn the specific provision giving the AIRC jurisdiction over industrial disputes involving independent contractors. However, we can still see the union motivation for the amendments. We are also left with an impossible situation where the AIRC has jurisdiction over contracts relating to independent contractors (not only in the commercial/industrial sector but also in relation to the residential building sector and indeed in respect of all contract labour). The amendments further provide for unions to have plenary power in enlisting contractors, in demanding reviews of contracts and in even having the final say in whether a certified agreement will be struck.

Let us make no mistake, this Bill in both its original and its present form, is all about union control and union dominance. It bears no relation to a law for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth. It has nothing to do with what is in the best interests of the Australian people. It is a naked, cloying gambit by a dying Federal Government in the clutches of the ACTU, to salvage flagging union memberships. It is an attempt to drive large, highly efficient non-unionised sectors of the workforce into the claws of unions. Having failed to do this in the courts, the pendulum has now swung to Federal Parliament.

And why? Because union memberships are declining and unions are losing their grip on their power base; they are losing their blackmailing power. In an era where 85% of workers work under awards and only 42% of those workers belong to a union, that means 43% of workers do not voluntarily belong to a union but they are still controlled by the unionised wages policy of the ACTU. By entwining independent contractors into the web of union power and union dominance, the proposed legislation is exposing what has been to date, a largely untapped source of union power.

However in extending this power base of unions, the Federal Government has shown no regard for individual rights and freedoms. The rights of the collective have precedence over the rights of the individual under this regime.

We see that the amendments allow the AIRC to review contracts of independent contractors to determine whether they are unfair, harsh or against the public interest. Further, the AIRC has the right to vary, amend or set aside those contracts altogether. In this way a party may be hauled into the AIRC by a union or a disaffected contractor to justify the contract and to explain that it will not threaten the integrity of the existing award system which the unions are seeking to extend to contractors. This is simply outrageous.

Yet, what is even more insidious, is the Government's flagrant disregard for individual freedoms. The amendments are an assault on the Common Law freedom of contract—a right which allows an individual to dictate when, how and on what basis he will provide his services. This is a right which has been enshrined in our Common Law for over 200 years. In one fell swoop, the Government is prepared to abrogate that right and seriously erode the right of Australians to enter into normal commercial arrangements. It shows the Government's unbridled, undemocratic contempt for a right which has developed by our courts with measured thought for the benefit of all individuals.
And while the amendments show contempt for our laws and our democratic rights, they show reverence for the role and the rights of unions—to the detriment of our economy.
We see "union control" stamped all over the provisions of this Bill.

We see the deletion of provisions from the original Bill, prohibiting the AIRC giving preference to any parties, which effectively allows the AIRC to grant preference to employees over independent contractors or vice versa.
We see that unions will have standing to seek a review of a contract of an independent contractor, even where the contractor has yet to become a member of the organisation of employees.

We see that a review of a contract on the ground that it is against the public interest may include a comparison to award conditions, thereby enforcing award conditions to independent contractors at the request of unions.

We see that union coverage is extended to independent contractors, affording unions the power in non-union areas regardless of the wishes of an individual. In short, union power will be foisted onto independent contractors who have to date been just that: independent.

We see that a right of appeal exists to the Full Bench of the AIRC concerning orders made in relation to contracts where an organisation or person is aggrieved by the decision or act concerned or bound by the award or order made.

And what is the cost of this union dominance for the Australian community? It is a considerable cost. Not only will we lose our democratic freedom to contract with whomever and on whatever basis we choose, but we will see considerable financial loss to the Australian people as a result of this legislation.

Many highly efficient and productive businesses, (especially in the home building industry), that rely heavily on independent contractors for labour, will see unions enrolling independent contractors, forcing them in to the AIRC where their contracts will be amended and the costs of labour will increase. The housing industry alone has claimed that the price of the average Australian home being built will increase by between a staggering $10,000 to $25,000. This is a result of an increase in labour costs of almost 40%.

As a result of the amendments, industries that rely heavily on independent contractors, such as the transport industry and particularly the residential building industry, will be at the mercy of unions in much the same way as the commercial building industry has fallen victim to abuse. Over the last 30 years the commercial building industry has been subject to union thuggery, sweetheart deals, cost over-runs and missed deadlines. Moreover, the unions have stymied all attempts by employers to achieve more competitive and cost efficient operations. This is what waits in store for independent contractors under this proposed legislation.

Senator Cook has claimed that the independent contractor amendments will only reach "sham contacts" that have been designed to avoid the proper reach of individual awards. This is arrant nonsense. These amendments will extend to all contracts involving independent contractors.

In an economic climate that would benefit from less regulation and more flexibility, the independent contractor amendments are a disaster for Australia and will thrust yet another group of Australian workers into the clutches of unions and under the rigid control and regulation of a centralised award system.
The independent contractor amendments smack of compulsory unionism and a denial of free bargaining. They are an affront to individual liberty and must be rejected.
This same stench of union control permeates the amendments in the Bill relating to certified agreements.

We see the Government provisions with noble objects of facilitating the making of enterprise agreements and encouraging their use in the prevention and settlement of disputes. This is quite commendable. However, amongst all that nobility and good intent, are the unions. These are industrial organisations whose leaders have polled 3rd last in a recent survey of the occupations which most Australians regard as the most ethical and honest.
And where do the unions feature in the certified agreement provisions? Well I think the question is where do they not appear?!
We see that in order for the AIRC to make a certified agreement, the parties must be in dispute, and lo and behold, one of those parties could include a union.

We see that the requirement for unions to consult members only when negotiating an agreement, excludes non-union members from the consultative process. This means that employees who are not members of a trade union will have no say in the terms and conditions of agreements which will govern their employment. This is a disgrace.
We see that in the case of a single business enterprise agreement, it is a requirement that all possible union parties are included in negotiations.

We see once again that in the case of a single business enterprise, the requirement to name a union party when that enterprise is not covered by an award, is a clear barrier to enterprise agreements for non-unionised employers and will preclude from enterprise agreements most professional enterprises because the employer must negotiate with a union organisation that is capable of covering non-unionised employees.

We see that the AIRC must not certify an agreement where it disadvantages employees and further that an agreement is deemed to disadvantage employees if it reduces award entitlements. What will transpire from this you ask? Well certified agreements will end up being a duplication of awards. This will play into the hands of unions that want to impede any review of restrictive award provisions.

Again, we see that under the appeal provisions in the Bill, unions will have the right to lodge appeals against an AIRC decision to certify an enterprise agreement, thus holding-up the implementation of an agreement that is not to its fancy.
What do all these legislative amendments suggest? Union control and union dominance.

And apart from preventing the extension of the use of certified agreements because of union "participation", the amendments represent an unwarranted and repugnant Government interference into aspects of labour relations where governments do not belong.

We see provisions allowing the making of agreements settling two or more disputes that could facilitate the making of common agreements across a whole industry. This is destructive as it may foster common settlements at a time when our national interests call for diversity, and it is exactly what the ACTU desire.

We see vague and ill-defined terms such as "contrary to the public interest" that by definition, cannot include a consideration of the objects of the IR Act 1988 and what the state of the economy might be. This makes a complete nonsense of the term.

We see a dangerous and intrusive right given to the Minister to intervene on the vague basis that the agreement relating to a single enterprise, if certified, would "seriously jeopardise the public interest". What that means, is again a mystery. However, there is no doubt that this unwarranted right of the Government to intervene, extends not only to a single enterprise where it happens to be the Government, but also extends to the private sector which is perfectly capable of determining what is in its own best interests.

We see other repugnant aspects of the amendments that allow lapsed agreements to become awards, capable of being varied and built upon once in force. In this way, we have a set of amending provisions that frustrate the whole alleged purpose of a large component of the Bill. The whole point of enterprise agreements is that they are flexible enough to respond to the economy to ensure maximum efficiency and productivity in an industry at a particular time. This will not be possible where certified agreements simply become awards automatically.
The amendments to the certified agreement provisions are unworkable, to the obvious benefit of unions and will not facilitate the increased use of certified agreements.

The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 is an odious and blatant attempt to extend union control and union dominance. It is about power and crumbling union empires, and not about furthering the sorts of changes that will bring industrial peace and prosperity to industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the situation, I am to reply to the speeches made by honourable senators opposite in the second reading debate. If I might exercise that right and deal with the amendment at the same time, it might help us get quickly to the committee stage of this Bill and aid the efficiency of the Senate and the opportunity of those opposite to deal with the matters in the committee stage. If I am right about that, perhaps I should proceed in that way.

PARA.TAB: By any test, this is quite significant legislation. It involves five major changes to various pieces of industrial legislation. The first and most significant change is to section 115 of the Federal Industrial Relations Act. The second—and the one which has drawn the most public attention—is the change introducing a role for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in dealing with harsh and unreasonable contracts for independent contractors. The third change is a social justice measure to enable people to pursue wage claims to which they are entitled but for which the cost of pursuing them at law would be too high. It provides a small claims tribunal mechanism so that they can in fact obtain their rights easily and with the minimum of legal problems. The fourth and fifth changes are changes respectively to the duties of the Vice-President of the Industrial Relations Commission and the representation on the NLCC.

This Bill took a long time in its gestation. It started life as a gleam in the eye of the Hancock report which was delivered to Parliament in 1985. In 1990, upon being given the authority as Minister for Industrial Relations, I advised the parties that we would review the Hancock legislation put down in 1987 and go through all of the provisions of that report and the existing Industrial Relations Act. As a consequence of that, at the NLCC level—the proper recognised forum for tripartite consultations between unions, employers and government in this country—we started on a long process of discussions about most of the elements in this Bill, and certainly about all of the elements of the controversial section relating to independent contractors.

Following the introduction of this Bill, I have had some 52 separate meetings with various employer organisations on the matter of subcontractors. In the end, there was no agreement. That puts the Government in a position of having to make a decision and, having exhausted every reasonable avenue for possible compromise, we did so. We have made a decision and the result is the Bill before the Parliament. In putting forward this Bill to the Parliament I believed it was necessary for the Government to put the Bill down as quickly as possible, because the Government was being abused and misrepresented quite dishonestly by some—although not all—of the parties which had been consulted by us in the process of the evolution of this Bill. So it was important in the public interest to have the real legislation we were proposing—not legislation which was argued by some of the parties to be what we intended—put down in our name as soon as possible so that we could demonstrate by declaring our hand the lie that was being perpetrated about our intent by some of the parties with whom we had consulted.

As a result of our putting the Bill down, further discussions have ensued and we are now proposing a series of amendments to reflect the outcome of those further discussions. It is fair to say that we do not have 100 per cent approval from either of the major social partners; certainly not from the ACTU and certainly not from the employers.
