What we have been able to do with the Bill as it now comes before this chamber, and with the amendments that I propose to make, is to have an outcome which, while not reflecting a perfect solution from either side, captures the vast bulk of the middle ground and is, in the exercise of responsible government, an outcome that is reasonable by any test and one which privately, if somewhat grudgingly, would be conceded as an appropriate one by most of the major protagonists here. That is not to say that everyone can fit the description of being reasonable, because—and I will deal with this in a minute—there is disgraceful, dishonourable and disreputable behaviour by two organisations, the Housing Industry Association and the Australian Small Business Association. I will deal with them in a minute.

I will now turn to the significant features of the debate in the second reading and do so with some amazement at the content of some of the second reading contributions. In the notices of motion session earlier today a couple of honourable senators gave notice of motions referring to the levels of unemployment and mentioned a number of things as possible causes of future unemployment, including this industrial relations legislation. They included that as an item which might create further unemployment.

All I can say is that that reflects a situation of supreme ignorance on behalf of those proposers which, I might add, was also reflected in some other speeches at the second reading stage. So those senators are not alone. It could also reflect a situation in which they know only too well the economic significance of the changes to section 115 of this Act.

While the independent contractors' section has been the section that has attracted most public controversy, there is no doubt that any fair-minded, independent commentator would say that the changes to section 115 are the most profoundly important changes to industrial relations law in this country for almost a century; they are changes which introduce a new era of workplace or enterprise bargaining; and they are changes in which the social partners in the workplace will be encouraged to develop a new workplace culture for Australia, a culture that is cooperative in nature and not conflict-prone, dispute-ridden and representative of the old class, caste, occupational, trade or craft connotations that have bedevilled this society and that of British speaking and British inheriting societies in the past.

The section 115 changes are sweeping and profoundly significant in terms of industrial relations law reform and are profoundly significant in economic terms, too. The common ground between the major political parties in this country is a need to decentralise industrial relations more to the enterprise or workplace level. While that need is a commonly supported objective by employers and unions—and, in October, by the national wage case bench of the industrial relations system—the major political parties differ about the way in which that objective should be introduced. We have a view of an objective, but a difference about the means of implementing it. This Bill introduces the objective.

I would have thought in the healthy forum of parliamentary debate, with industrial relations designated as the cornerstone of the Fightback package by the Opposition, the one thing that upholds its whole philosophy, it would have seized upon the opportunity to debate section 115 and proposed an alternative means to the one that the Government has proposed to introduce workplace or enterprise bargaining. Did those opposite do that? The answer is no, they did not.

From the speeches of Opposition members at the second reading stage, it appears that they are in the peculiar situation of not commenting to any extent at all on enterprise bargaining, refusing the obvious offer by the Government to engage in the clash of ideas that makes democracy in this country work, refusing to trot out an alternative proposal as to how workplace bargaining should be introduced. The fact that those opposite declined to even debate section 115 in any significant way is a telling condemnation of the efficacy of their own ideas or the paucity with which they have given thought to industrial relations policy development.

When this Bill reaches the House of Representatives, I challenge the Opposition spokesperson on industrial relations, John Howard, to make a comprehensive statement on the Opposition's industrial relations policy, to explain to the electorate of Australia the details of the centrepiece of the Fightback program, and to answer a number of significant questions which are blowing in the wind—questions to which constituents of the Australian electorate want answers.

How will the Opposition's policy work? What specifically will be the protections and preventions for ordinary people? How will the Opposition's policy prevent workers from being forced out of the protection of the award stream by an employer who wants to put an employee on a contract? How will scrupulous employers compete with the unfair advantage that is offered by the Hewson unscrupulous employers? With no more national wage cases, how will workers in weak bargaining positions ever get a wage rise? If industrial disputes are to be dealt with under the common law instead of by the Industrial Relations Commission, how will ordinary workers have the time and the resources to take their employers to court? How long will it take the courts to hear the cases? How will the Opposition's model of industrial relations protect living standards? How will it make everybody a winner?

I look forward in anticipation, but not in much expectation, to the Opposition at least having the decency to declare its position on this important and significant economic reform. To the proposers of the notices of motion I say this: if the notices of motion are ever declared formal, please do not raise this issue. We are now presiding over a massive economic change which will produce a productivity surge through the economy as more and more workplaces under our style of workplace enterprise bargaining introduce the concept and develop a cooperative teamwork ethic in place of the confrontationist one that so typifies the Opposition's industrial relations policy. With the successful passage of this section of the legislation tonight, we are about to see a boost to the Australian economy, which is bad news to the Opposition but good news to Australians.

The most controversial section of these amendments relates to the independent contractors. Had it been possible to have described them as `sham contractors' or `quasi employees' and hold significant legal meaning by the use of those terms, I would have preferred that. The term `independent contractors' has been exploited to make it appear that things which were never intended and which were explicitly denied by the Government may be intended. Last night and tonight it has been the subject of a despicable, dishonest and untrue campaign by two employer organisations for which they must be condemned, not only by the Government but also by other employer organisations which have had the decency and honesty to recognise a fair outcome when they see one.

From the beginning, the question of independent contractors was shamefully misrepresented. As a consequence, we agreed that this matter should go to a parliamentary inquiry in order that the arguments could be teased out. They were, to some extent, yesterday. The fact that they were found hollow and empty is in itself the reason why the Senate should not support the motion moved by Senator Brownhill at the beginning of the debate tonight. That motion is fatuous in the extreme and one which would deny the effectiveness of the inquiry held by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training.

The independent contractors section is not a means by which an award can be obtained. It is not a means by which independent contractors will be forced to join trade unions. Those things were said in the second reading speech. They appear not to have had any weight or significance placed in them. This provision, in a more tightly and narrowly drawn sense, simply reflects legislation that applies in New South Wales, introduced by the Greiner Government last year, at a Federal level. The most damning condemnation of the critics is that, when the Greiner Government did it, they raised no objections but, when a Keating Labor Government did it, they funded disreputable and lying television campaigns to oppose it. That explains their motive, their intent and their purpose. Those employer organisations do not represent the interests of their members; they are simply political adjuncts to the Opposition and are acting politically against the interests of their members and against the interests of other well-conducted employer organisations.

I was a bit surprised to see a media comment on public radio today in which Dr Ron Silberberg of the Housing Industry Association was asked by the interviewer whether his media campaign was an appropriate one, given that the National Employers Forum had reached an undertaking with me and that his organisation was a member of the National Employers Forum and took part in those negotiations, in which I, in good faith, reached an agreement with employers. Now we find, despite that agreement, that this organisation is conducting a campaign. Dr Silberberg said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have been advised by the Confederation of Australian Industry that since the National Employers Forum has removed its threat of a media campaign in return for its compromise deal individual organisations have been free to pursue a media campaign if they so wish.

That is what Dr Silberberg said on public radio station 4QN on 15 June. As a result of that I wrote this afternoon to the convener of the National Employers Forum, Mr Ian Spicer, to ask him whether that was true. In my absence last week he had provided to the Acting Minister for Industrial Relations, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis), a letter saying that the National Employers Forum, on behalf of all its members, accepted the outcome of its negotiations with the Government. The letter was dated 12 June and signed by Mr Spicer, Chief Executive Officer.

PARA.TAB: We cannot have a situation in which the Government negotiates in good faith with an umbrella organisation and achieves a settlement with it on behalf of all its members and then finds that some of the members of that organisation, under their own banner, disavow the agreement and conduct themselves in a way that opposes what they committed themselves to through their national umbrella organisation. It is only because I have not received a reply to my letter this afternoon to Mr Spicer that I have to assume, in good faith, that Mr Spicer has acted properly and that Dr Silberberg is in fact misrepresenting the situation. I assume that the Spicer letter of 12 June does represent the situation, and the Government will press forward with the amendments that were concluded in good faith with the National Employers Forum. I make that assumption based on the fact that Mr Spicer, in his letter of 12 June, indicated that the package was acceptable to the Forum and its members.

I now turn to the television campaign. I have not seen the advertisement, but I have been told of its contents. It suggests that following the passage of this legislation the cost of housing in Australia will increase. It is a campaign intended to frighten electors, suggesting that industrial legislation will impose extra costs. That campaign is a lie, a damned lie, and is known to be a lie by the people who are promoting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know it is true.

—I know the campaign to be a lie, a damned lie, and it is known by the people who have promoted it to be a lie. I have asked them to produce evidence of their assertion, but they have failed to do so. They have not produced any evidence whatsoever, and the reason they have not is that there is none. There is no evidence at all. When the Master Builders Association, which covers small builders and people in the same field as is covered by the HIA, was asked before the inquiry yesterday whether some of these allegations were true, it said—its words are in the Hansard—that in its view there would be `no industrial mayhem' as the HIA had indicated there would be and that because it had agreed to the deletion of section 127A it would be `highly unlikely' that there would be an increase in housing costs at all.

PARA.TAB: So all I can do is repeat, in the somewhat conservative, restrained language of the MBA, that there is absolutely no support for this disreputable, dishonest and lying campaign now going to air around Australia as paid advertisements to try to scare Australians into believing that this legislation holds extra costs for them in the housing area. It does not. What it does do is enable people who are victims of unfair contracts, where they have been found to be unfair, to have some form of redress. That is a measure of social worth and justice, and in its own right it reflects, as I have said, the legislation put down by the Greiner Government in New South Wales just last year. As I say, the campaign being run against us now was not run then. We never heard a squeak out of anyone then, so one must say that this is simply a politically inspired act with no basis in fact. The campaign has been undertaken for the purpose of creating mischief, and it does not have the support of major employer organisations in this country. It is therefore an act by a few extremists, and it ought to be seen as such and condemned by ordinary Australians.

I now turn to the other amendments that we are proposing. I will spend just a minute on them. The other amendments are significant in themselves. Where the cost of using lawyers to right a legal wrong is greater than the value of the money to be gained, there is an in-built deterrent to actually recover money that is justifiably the property of people who have been gypped of it. That is a way of saying that if it costs us more to get back what we are rightfully owed the tendency is that we do not spend the extra money to do so.

Our proposal on small claims puts within the reach of every person, no matter how poor, an easy, non-expensive route to obtain moneys that have been illegally withheld from them. It is done through the courts on a small claims basis that is typical of consumer legislation in this country. It is a social justice measure which I think will be recognised in the future as being a significant change for those people at the lower end of the wage spectrum or working in areas of the market where they can be treated, because of poor skills, somewhat more reprehensively than people who have high skills and, therefore, a marketable skill and get respect from employers. Where there is low skill on low wages and high unemployment, the tendency is for victimisation. This measure means that those people can now be protected.

The other two measures are about making some greater sense of the duties of the Vice-President of the Commission. I think that is unexceptional and widely supported. The final measure makes changes to the NLCC representation to recognise the role of other principal organisations.

I conclude by saying that most of the debate has been about independent contractors and has reflected the swallowing of the big lie argument promoted by an extremist few. The majority of employers have now reached an accommodation with the Government. It will be interesting to see where the Opposition comes down. Will it support the mainstream employers in this country and, therefore, the outcomes which have been negotiated or will

SPEECH.PARA: it run along, as it did in the APPM dispute, with the extremists, paint itself into an extreme corner and not be relevant to the major industrial relations debate in this country? I hope that the Opposition shows sense and supports the major and mainstream employer organisations. I suspect that it will not and that it will stick with the extremists as it did at Burnie, Tasmania, just a few weeks ago.

PARA.TAB: I ask for the motion moved by Senator Brownhill to be defeated. Senator Brownhill's motion is hollow, false and fatuous in the extreme. It makes a mockery of the proper considerations of the Committee which sat just yesterday. I look forward, with the support of the Senate, to moving the amendments that I have foreshadowed in the committee stage of the Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Brownhill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a statement of legislative intent which makes clear the purpose of many of our amendments.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition and some employers have continually portrayed the provisions of this legislation which deal with independent contractors as being something that they are not. I wish to answer some of the more extreme claims. This Bill is not a charter for converting independent contractors into employees. It is not intended to upset fair contractual arrangements made with genuine self-employed entrepreneurs. It is not intended to affect people who have made a free and informed genuine commercial decision to enter into a contract for services. It will not be a blueprint for massive cost increases in industry. But the Bill has been framed to prevent exploitation of those people in the work force who have been forced by unfair pressure to adopt a legal arrangement that disguises the substance of their position.

PARA.TAB: The Bill contains three distinct elements relating to independent contractors. Some of the misunderstanding and misrepresentation of the Bill arises from a lack of comprehension of how these provisions are framed and are intended to operate.

A preliminary point that should be made is, as I stated in my Second Reading Speech, that an independent contractor is an individual performing work under a contract for services. Let me make that quite clear. It does not mean an incorporated body, as many subcontractors are. It means an ordinary individual. The legislation was deliberately framed in that way because it is such people who are commonly subjected to the type of unfair treatment that this Bill is designed to address.

The first element of the Bill involves expressly giving the Australian Industrial Relations Commission jurisdiction over industrial disputes about the use of independent contractors rather than employees to perform work. That jurisdiction is, under the Bill, qualified in various ways, to make it focused on the primary objective of the provisions concerning independent contractors. That objective is to ensure that the Federal industrial relations system provides appropriate remedies and protections in relation to those independent contractors who are in a position of quasi-employment. Appropriate balances are struck between the interests of genuine self-employed entrepreneurs and quasi-employees, and between those of contractors and employees.

I will not dwell on those provisions concerning such industrial disputes, because the Government proposes that they be withdrawn from the Bill. This follows extensive consultation with employer bodies. Agreement has been reached that the Commission's existing jurisdiction should be clarified through the mounting of a test case before the High Court.

The second element of the provisions permits independent contractors to join federally registered unions. This is a practical and sensible provision. It permits those workers who, on a narrow, legal definition, are not employees, to choose to belong to and be represented by unions which have coverage of their work. It is a right which will be subject to certain limits and protections. It will only apply to individuals. Federally registered unions will be restricted to representing independent contractors who perform work of the same kind as the employees whom they represent. There will be wider prohibitions on discriminating against independent contractors for their membership or non-membership of unions. Unions will be prohibited from coercing contractors to become members.
The right of independent contractors to join federally registered unions will balance their existing right to join federally registered employer bodies.

The third element of these provisions allows the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to review contracts which are unfair, harsh or against the public interest. The primary focus of this part of the legislation is the situation where there is inequality of bargaining, in cases where a worker's economic dependence makes the worker's position one of quasi-employment.

The Bill is deliberately not expressed to apply only to quasi-employment. A basic feature of problems in this area of the law is the difficulty of definition. Any attempt to define "quasi-employment" in the Bill would invite avoidance by artificial legal devices. The Government is not going to draw a precise boundary line and then watch workers being pressured to sign ingeniously-constructed contracts that put them slightly outside the boundary.

I reiterate that the Government's firm legislative intent is that this legislation not affect genuine, even-handed commercial arrangements with true independent contractors—that is, those individuals whose status as such is clear, not only in law, but also in social and economic reality. For example, the Government has no reason to believe that the Bill will affect the widespread use of subcontractors in the home building industry. Employer representatives have pointed to the absence of problems in this field. But it would not be appropriate for the Bill to give a blanket exemption to this area, nor to any other. If unfair contrived arrangements are found in any industry, it is proper that this legislation be available.

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission is entrusted with the task of distinguishing between such unfair, contrived arrangements and proper commercial bargains. The Commission is to be free to make a commonsense decision based on the facts of each case. The Commission is to be able to deal effectively with new legal arrangements as they arise. The Commission will not be forced to work within a definition of "quasi-employee" that could force the Commission to deny fair treatment because of legal technicalities.
The Government has confidence in the Commission's ability to ensure fairness in the workplace. The Government, unlike the Opposition, has faith in the Commission and is enhancing its role.
The legislation will provide guidance for the Commission when reviewing contracts.
Section 90 of the Industrial Relations Act will apply. That section specifically requires the Commission, in exercising its powers under the Act, to have regard to national economic conditions.
The Commission is also bound, by section 110 of the Industrial Relations Act, to act according to equity, good conscience and the substantial merits of the case.

These considerations will guide the Commission away from routinely extending award conditions to contractors who are genuinely different from employees. To suggest that the Commission would behave in that way shows contempt for the Commission. It can be trusted to exercise its discretion properly.
The new provisions themselves include criteria that will help the Commission to give effect properly to the Parliament's intention.

Proposed subsection 127B(4) will point the Commission to a number of specified factors that go to the genuineness of the arrangements. The relative bargaining strength of the parties, and whether there was undue pressure, are matters for

SPEECH.PARA: the Commission to consider. These are obviously of particular relevance to the situation of quasi-employees in an economically vulnerable position.

PARA.TAB: The Commission will also be able to decide whether there has been any attempt to evade obligations that an employer would owe to an employee. For example, the contract might be a device to avoid training obligations or occupational health and safety obligations. In this context, the Commission is asked to consider whether the contract may adversely affect skills of employees in the industry concerned. It is worth noting that the term "industry" is defined in the Industrial Relations Act in a way which ranges from an industry in its widest sense to the activities of a single employer in an industry. The meaning of the term depends on the context in which a particular matter arises. How this criterion applies, in a particular case, will depend on the circumstances of the case. The Commission will be free to decide whether a contract affects training and skills development in any way and, if so, whether it is of relevance to the particular case.

The same is true of the criterion relating to remuneration. The Commission may consider whether the total remuneration payable under the contract is less than that of an employee performing the same work. That is obviously relevant to a quasi-employee working under artificial arrangements. It is not relevant to a genuine commercial arrangement.

Finally, I wish to make it clear that the legislation does not provide a basis for a class action over contracts, nor any similar process. Under the proposed legislation, an application can only be made by an individual, or by a representative organisation or association on behalf of the individual, with his or her consent, in respect of that individual's contract. The provisions clearly relate only to a particular contract and the orders which the Commission will be able to make will relate only to a particular contract.

If a number of contractors claim to be party to unfair contracts, they could seek to have their applications for review heard together. Even so, each application will have to be made separately and the Commission would have to decide, after giving all parties the opportunity to be heard, whether it was fair to hear some or all of the applications together. If the Commission decided to conduct its proceedings in that way, the Commission would have to make its decisions in relation to each contract individually. In other words, each applicant would have to persuade the Commission on the facts of his or her individual case, and any orders made by the Commission would have separate application to each contract.

I have made these remarks both to clarify certain questions which have been raised about the purpose of the legislation, and so that the Government's intention can be referred to in any proceedings before a Court or Tribunal in which questions about the operation of the legislation are raised.
Clauses 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 4, paragraph (d), page 2, lines 28 to 36, omit the paragraph.
(2)Clause 4, page 3, at end of clause, add the following paragraph:
"(g) by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsection:

TAB.TAB: `(1A) To avoid doubt, it is declared that a reference in this Act to an independent contractor is confined to a natural person.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 1 is probably the most significant of the amendments I will be moving tonight. It deals with the removal of clause 4(d), which is in the definitions section of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill. Amendment No. 1 deletes from the Bill the provision that would give the Australian Industrial Relations Commission jurisdiction to resolve disputes about the use of independent contractors instead of employees for the performance of work. The Government has received legal advice that the Commission already has a large part of this jurisdiction and it will be part of the Commission's normal jurisdiction to resolve disputes about the relationship between employers and employees. It would be appropriate for the High Court to be asked to clarify the interpretation of the present Act.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 1 takes out of the Bill that section which would have clothed the Commission with the power to decide which class of worker, a contractor or an employee, should conduct what sort of work. That is the major change we intend to make. It amends clause 4(d) on page 2 of the Bill by taking out lines 28 to 36, which are in the definitions section of the Bill and deal with the powers of the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whereabouts do you believe you have the power?

—The reason I am prepared to make this amendment is that I think the Act as it stands, taken and read together with a constitutional head of power, enables an interpretation, should the High Court be presented with a case for a ruling, that the powers of the Commission are sufficient to cover the question of independent contractors as we are seeking in our Bill to amend them. It is because I believe that—and I am led to believe it on the advice I have received—that I am happy to remove the explicit proposal in our Bill to—
—You don't think you are giving anything away?
—I do not think so.

PARA.TAB: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I resume where I was up to prior to the last division, I should do one necessary mechanical thing. I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum circulated on 4 June 1992 and a replacement supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government's amendments and the new clause to this Bill.

PARA.TAB: Prior to the last division I was explaining the purposes of our first amendment. I had picked up an interjection from Senator Crichton-Browne which sought a better explanation than I had given up to that point as to the significance of our amendment. I thought it was a worthwhile interjection. I will complete my explanation and then yield the floor.

In the independent contractors section of our amending Bill there are two effective areas of change. One is about the ability of the Industrial Relations Commission to review contracts which it finds are harsh and unfair. That section, by and large, remains intact and we are not proposing to amend it significantly. The second area of change was a part which clothed the Commission with express power to make a determination and issue an order on what type of worker—an independent contractor or an employee engaged under an award—should be employed on what particular work. It is that section that amendment No. 1 deals with by removing from the definitions part the expanded definition of the powers of the Commission.

I think the interjection from Senator Crichton-Browne—my having explained that I thought the High Court might find, if a particular case were presented to it, that the powers of the Commission were at least as extensive as the amending Bill had sought to explicitly provide for—was, `Well, as far as you're concerned, you're giving nothing away then', or words to that effect. That is true. As far as I am concerned, I do not think I am giving anything away. I think if a particular case is taken to the High Court, the High Court will so find.

The Government is removing the explicit amendment that is proposed here in major part because on reflection and on advice I think that that is the probable outcome of such a case to the High Court, but as well because I think it is probably necessary for the High Court to be given a chance to make a decision about that before there is a legal ruling. My reading of the High Court is mine and not that necessarily of the employers or of any other group. If there is such an opportunity, I am sure the High Court will make a decision and we will all be enlightened as a consequence.

Amendments 1 and 2 are the result of extensive consultations with employers and the Australian Democrats. I think that they are quite important amendments in terms of the understandings I have with the social partners on the employers side.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment on the removal of this amendment to the Bill. This highlights—and I want to pick up some of the comments that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has made—the haste with which this Bill has been put together. We now have before us a Bill that is significantly different from the one that was originally brought before us. Tonight the Minister tabled a further explanation of this Bill. None of us on this side of the chamber have even had an opportunity to look at and assess what that application is.

PARA.TAB: I want to correct a couple of things that have been said here tonight. The first relates to the MBA. It is well recorded in the evidence that was taken yesterday—and that was the MBA's documented evidence in terms of the type of housing in which it is involved—that unionisation of sites will increase costs by at least 25 per cent. That is in yesterday's Hansard of the legislation committee for the Minister to see.

This highlights the haste with which this Bill has been put together. It also begs a number of questions in terms of the removal of this particular clause at the beginning of the Bill. It also relates to challenges to the High Court and what might come out of them. I have no doubt—particularly after the ACTU's announcement today and from what the employers who appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training yesterday said—that this Bill will end up in the High Court. That is a poor reflection on the Minister in terms of putting this legislation together. Of course the Minister is trying to achieve an increase in union power. That is what this Bill is about, and that is precisely what it will do.

I wish to comment on one other aspect relating to this increase in union power. The Minister, in his comments, referred to the position of the Housing Industry Association. Before commenting on that, I will quote what Mr Spicer said yesterday. Mr Spicer made it quite clear, as did all the other employer organisations, that he was totally opposed to the Bill, even in its amended form. All Mr Spicer said was that they were not going to continue—that is, those who are left in the NEF—with the advertising campaign, but they reserved their right to oppose the Bill to the very end. I bring this up because of the haste and the enormous number of amendments that have been made to this Bill. Mr Hamilton, the industrial officer who was with Mr Spicer, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Basically, the issue died between 1988 and April 1992. There was no activity and our views in opposition were well known on this issue.
Mr Spicer then went on to say:
And it was a surprise to us on 1 April.

Any talk being bandied around about the Hancock inquiry and other matters is totally irrelevant to the Bill before us tonight. I want to make the point that many, if not all, employer organisations—certainly all that have spoken to me—have said that this clause is not required as it is already covered in the Bill. That view was certainly well and truly publicly canvassed, and I am sure it was canvassed with the Minister. So it need not have been there in the first place.

PARA.TAB: I want to make another point about the removal of this clause, and I will be speaking on some other clauses at a later stage. I point out that the Bill and this clause are not about sham contracts. The Minister mentioned today that he would have preferred that to have been addressed. But when he was asked yesterday to define a sham contract, he could not do so. He was given the opportunity to do so. Of course, we on this side of the chamber have known all the time that a definition of `sham contract' was never in this Bill. We also knew that it was never going to be in this Bill because that is not the main object of this legislation.

What we are now dealing with in the committee stage debate is just one of the enormous number of changes to the legislation that is before us. It is ill-conceived legislation—legislation that is going to lead to increased industrial disputation and to increases in costs. No matter what the Minister or anyone else may say, there is no way that he will be able to quarantine the housing industry, or any other industry for that matter, from this legislation. The Minister knows that; I know that. Despite assurances that were given initially, and comments that were made publicly—I emphasise the word publicly—that this would not impact on the housing industry, it most definitely will impact on the housing industry. My final comment is that it really matters nought if this clause is removed from the legislation because this legislation is going to end up in the High Court of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I say at the outset that I do not pretend to be an industrial relations expert. I never have been, and I am never likely to be. But I have been an employer most of my life. I have never sacked anybody in my life—perhaps I should have done—but I have had a close association with contractors and subcontractors through my farming operations and through building a couple of houses. Many of my friends are engaged in such operations.

PARA.TAB: As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which looked at this Bill yesterday, I did approach this matter with a somewhat open mind. I think what impressed me was the general consensus amongst most of the people who appeared before our Committee. As my colleague Senator Crane has said, they opposed the Bill in its entirety. Even tonight the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) said that the National Employers Forum had reached agreement with him about certain matters. I quote from the executive summary that we received yesterday in which the Forum said:

SPEECH.PARA: Employers oppose all provisions of the Bill which seek to give trade unions rights and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission jurisdiction with respect to independent contractors.

I read in the Australian this morning that it has already been mooted by the union movement that it is ready to run off to the High Court in a bid to prove that the Industrial Relations Commission has the power to deal with independent contractors. That is not what the contractors want. All the different organisations that spoke to us—the Master Builders Association and the Housing Industry Authority, which the Minister seems so critical of—stated that the IRC was not the appropriate place to deal with this and did not want contractors to be bound by the IRC.

PARA.TAB: The Minister said earlier that this Bill had a long gestation period. It started with Hancock. I put it to the Minister that the signs of pregnancy did not start to appear until the Troubleshooters case came on the scene. The Minister will recall that yesterday in questions from me and Senator Crane concerning the union movement in particular it was shown that the unions were very reticent to own up to the fact that they had been pushing this particular matter. In fact, towards the end of the Minister's evidence he admitted that the Troubleshooters case certainly had an influence on his thinking. I would have thought that, if this legislation was so good and so necessary, the trade union movement would have been proud to say that it initiated it and would have pressed the Minister to go on with it.

We get back to why we need this legislation. We have already heard where it was born. It was born after the Hancock case. One would have to ask whether the 810,000 self-employed contractors, whom the Minister identified to me yesterday in answer to a question, asked for it. I think Senator Cook said that they did not queue up at his door. It seems from the evidence we have had that the organisation did not ask for it. Certainly the NEF did not ask for it. Of all the witnesses we heard yesterday, including the ones that the Government side of the Committee had called—with the exception of Job Watch, which is an independent labour organisation funded by the Victorian Government—the ACTU, the CMFEU and the Minister were the only ones who felt that the Bill was necessary.

Contractors and subcontractors have been around ever since I can remember, and I have never had the feeling that they needed to be represented in the Industrial Relations Commission, and neither do I believe they want to be represented by the trade union movement, as my colleague Senator Crane has said. It seems to have popped up in just about every submission we have had. It seems that the major feeling is that the whole reason for this Bill is to give the trade unions the power to coerce independent contractors into the trade union movement. If we multiply one million trade union members—that figure was another estimate—by $300 each, which is the annual membership fee, we are looking at $300m. It would be quite a windfall for the trade union movement if all the contractors could be forced into it. I know that will not happen, but certainly the building workers—some 40,000 odd—would contribute something like $12m to the trade union coffers.

I will comment more as we get further through the Bill, particularly on matters relating to the excising of section 127A. I believe this is where Mr Spicer and the members of the NEF, along with others who have accepted the advice of the Minister, have been hoodwinked because they thought they were getting away with something when they got section 127A taken out. I think we can put the record straight. Even you yourself, Mr Chairman, commented that section 127B (a) (b) and (c)—where the contract is unfair, harsh and against the public interest—could raise the sorts of things that could have come up under section 127A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has pointed out, the reason he has deleted this amendment is that he believes that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission has the power anyway and this will be proved in the High Court. The Minister during his reply on the second reading debate earlier made a mischievous statement when he in fact vilified the Housing Industry Association and the Australian Small Business Association and tried to point out that they were at odds with the rest of the employers. To an organisation, every employer who gave evidence yesterday—whether written or verbal—made it quite clear that they were totally opposed to the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill.
—Including submissions from those who did not give evidence.

—I thank Senator Crane. Every employer organisation was opposed to the legislation. Every employer organisation made the point that it would not have contemplated even initiating this sort of legislation which would give the power to the trade unions to intervene in the work of independent contractors. I am pointing this out because the Minister indicated that they were split. They were not split, but it is quite correct that a group of them, part of the forum, believed it had negotiated as far as it could go and therefore agreed with the Minister not to pursue a television campaign against the Bill, even though it was totally opposed to the legislation. The only difference is that the HIA and ASBA decided that, because they were still horrified with the legislation, they would continue to run a television program opposed to it.

PARA.TAB: The Minister made the point that somehow this came about from the Hancock report. Although I am not a member of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I attended the hearing yesterday and asked certain questions. It was perfectly obvious that the ACTU pussyfooted about, even though I put the question to its representatives directly, `Did you initiate this with the Minister because of the Troubleshooters court case?'. They looked backwards and forwards at one another and said, `I don't know, did you talk to him?' `No, I didn't; did you?'. I have seen my kids lie better than that. It was patently obvious that the ACTU had initiated it. Senator Calvert drew attention to this. He said, `I don't know why the trade union movement was not proud to admit to the fact'. The reason it was not, of course, was that everyone knows that this Minister, because of his own background, because of his own allegiance, has an allegiance to the trade union movement. I am not critical of him.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Building Workers Union.

—The Minister is an ex-member of the Building Workers Industrial Union, which is terribly interested in this. It has always been opposed to contractors on building sites and has never liked their being involved in the home building organisation. Everyone is aware of that.

PARA.TAB: I do not know why that should be hidden, but that sensitivity was there. It was patently obvious that the ACTU was trying to avoid actually coming out and admitting that it initiated it. We had difficulty getting Senator Cook to admit for two hours that he was a member of the BWIU.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!
—It is true; this is a fact.
—It was in my declaration of interest.

—I know it was in a declaration of interest, but the Minister was not about to tell us in this chamber. We all knew it was a declaration of interest, but the sensitivity was there. Senator Cook is simply the Minister representing the BWIU and the Minister assisting the President of the ACTU. We all know that.

PARA.TAB: I was really answering a query raised by my colleague Senator Calvert. What the ACTU did not want to show was that it was in fact the organ grinder and the Minister was the monkey. That is what it was about. There is no doubt that this legislation came to the fore because of what happened in the Troubleshooters case. If honourable senators look at the submission from the ACTU to the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on page 4—if my memory is correct; I do not have it in front of me—they will see that the ACTU actually came out and said that this is what initiated this legislation. To get it to admit that in the Committee was like taking teeth out without an anaesthetic.

I draw that to everyone's attention because that is why there are organisations such as the Housing Industry Association, which has been built on subcontractors. The whole of our housing industry has been built on subcontractors and it is very efficient. I remember some years ago doing a whole series of reports on restrictive work practices in the building industry. After our investigations, the comment was made that our major construction industry was among the most inefficient in the world and our home building industry was the most efficient. The simple reason was that the housing industry is made up of subbies. They are individual contractors who have a vested interest in being very efficient so that they can move to the next job and maximise their rate of return, their profit and the amount of money in their pockets. They are not paid on an hourly basis and their wages can be equated to that paid to a taxi driver. Of course, taxi drivers are not paid by the hour, but by the amount of work they engender themselves. It is the same with a builder, a plumber and an electrician. I thought I would clarify that point, because it is very important.

It was wrong of the Minister to single out the Housing Industry Association and the Australian Small Business Association, because, even in conjunction with the Confederation of Australian Industry and other members of the forum, they are absolutely at one in being totally opposed to the legislation. As I pointed out earlier, the only difference was that the other group had made some arrangement whereby it would not pursue a television program if certain amendments occurred, and the HIA and ASBA felt that they had still not solved the problem and they would still be under attack, which would be to the detriment of not only their own members and themselves, but also to the public of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After some cursory reference to the Government's amendment No. 1, most people who have spoken on this matter have chosen to establish a position on the Bill itself. I think it is probably best if I indicate initially that I can understand the reason for amendment No. 1 and support that reason. I think something in particular should be stated with regard to the Bill as a whole: amendment No. 2 will clarify a number of matters for us because it heads towards the clarification of the definition of what the Bill is all about. The amendment is written in clear terms to avoid doubt. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is declared that a reference in this Act to an independent contractor is confined to a natural person.

I agree with Senator Calvert's observation—I do not think it took a lot of skill on his behalf—that genuine contractors have been around ever since he could remember. I support his observation. I did not have to try very hard to notice that either. It is a fact. I contend that, although this Bill does not have the capacity to quarantine genuine contractors in any particular sector, we can look at the housing industry and observe that it is composed of a great number of self-employed contractors: people who are in business for themselves; people who, by definition, are not the subject of this legislation; and people who have been unfairly led to believe that their businesses will be destroyed by this legislation.

PARA.TAB: We have an amendment forthcoming to clarify the fact that those people are not referred to, that the reference in this legislation is to a natural person. If people have been told that their livelihood will be destroyed, they will certainly be afraid, whether what they have been told is true or not. Those people would certainly be opposed to any suggestion of legislation which compromised their livelihoods. But we have here a specific reference to a natural person and not to the myriad of companies that have written to a number of senators, a myriad of companies engaged in the building industry which, by definition of amendment No. 2, which is a clarification, are not included. I think it is a fallacy to base a whole case on the fear that is engendered by this misinformation.

The other information that has been provided to us and alluded to in previous speeches is that unionisation could add significant costs to the domestic housing industry. I do not dispute that assessment or those figures, although I have heard several versions, ranging from 10 per cent to 15 per cent to 25 per cent, and even to 40 per cent. I will not take the trouble to dispute that assessment, but I dispute the assumption that tomorrow, or even soon after the passage of this Bill, all domestic building will be unionised by the passage of this Bill. I have foreshadowed, and subsequently I intend to move, Democrats amendments which clarify any misunderstanding there might be about how people might be compelled to join a union before getting an audience before the IRC.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is going to happen through intimidation anyway.

—The assumption that is made cannot be verified by referring to what the Bill actually contains. I accept Senator Walters's interjection. It is useful to say that intimidation has occurred in any number of industries, not just the housing and construction industries. Intimidation occurs daily to encourage people to join unions, to get out of unions or to do all sorts of other things. But it is not the purpose of this legislation to pursue those cases. That is a legal matter. We in this chamber cannot be policemen; we can only be legislators. When we look at what the legislation does, we see that it does not do any of those things which have been assumed; it does not provide a basis for the assumption that there will be an instant unionisation of the housing industry upon the passage of this legislation.
—We have before us 25 amendments proposed by the Government. I am not quite sure how many amendments the Australian Democrats are putting up, but I think there are a considerable number.
—Several.
—There are several. This points more than anything else to the fact that this piece of legislation should never have been put under the guillotine.

PARA.TAB: We have an important piece of legislation before us that the Government has not been able or has not had the ability to draft in a fashion that is acceptable to be passed through this Committee. As a consequence, it has had to do deals with the Democrats to get the legislation through. It has put up 25 separate amendments because of its inability, inefficiency and lack of competence to draft a piece of legislation successfully. The Democrats have a few amendments, according to Senator Bell, but the Opposition has none. We are opposing the Bill in its entirety because we do not believe in the union that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) represents in this place, the BWIU, of which he was an official in Perth when it was creating all the problems it created in the West. He has decided that he will tie the legislation down even further by including the subcontractors.

I have seen intimidation in the building industry. Quite some time ago this intimidation forced a subcontractor to join the union. When I say forced, yes, it was a case of being forced because the subcontractor said that she had no intention of joining the union and refused point blank to do so until the life of her son was threatened by one of the BWIU officials. I said to this subcontractor, `Don't give in, take them to court; name him and we'll give you all the support we can'. She said, `There's no way I'd put my son's life at risk'. That is how this particular union works.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thugs.

—Yes, they are thugs. We are all well aware of this sort of intimidation. The Minister is also well aware that that sort of intimidation goes on and has gone on in his union for many years. He now brings a situation into this place where the subcontractors will no longer have the choice. They will be commandeered into the unions.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister knows, when we get into Government we will have voluntary unionism. This legislation will be very short-lived because we will not be conducting closed shops or allowing closed shops to be conducted. With voluntary unionism, we will be able to get rid in large part—I say in large part because intimidation is such a surreptitious, cowardly action—of some of the intimidation that presently goes on.

In the last month we had a pretty good example of the way this Government works in the situation that arose in APPM. When we compare the action that this Government took over the APPM dispute with the action that this same Government took over the pilots strike, people must wonder what on earth this Government is up to. In one situation it denied the pilots any justice at all because Bob Hawke's mate demanded it. In the other case the Government denied the employer—an employer who was paying 25 per cent over-the-award payments. It was not questioning those payments, was not questioning giving 9 per cent superannuation to its employees, was not questioning a 35-hour week and was not questioning the generous redundancy payments when someone wished to leave; it was questioning the work practices.

This Government tried to interfere and made such a fool of itself in the process because all the Minister succeeded in doing was to make sure that the employer got every single one of the demands it first wrote in the letter that it sent its employees. The company has given up nothing. The Minister really did make a fool of himself. I guess that is what we have come to expect from this Government.

As my colleagues Senator Crane, Senator Calvert and Senator Parer have said, there is no way that we would support this sort of thuggery that the Government is introducing in this legislation. I am surprised that the Democrats are willing to go ahead with this sort of thuggery and are insisting that the subcontractors be brought in to the union movement at all.

This first clause does nothing to improve the Bill. Indeed, the employers have made it very obvious that it really does not matter what amendments the Government attempts to introduce. None of them help. The housing industry is presently running advertisements which say very clearly to people that an additional $7,000 will be put on the cost of its buildings. We all know when the subcontractors are building a home because they do not work the special hours set aside that the union insists on. They will work any time. They will work to get the job done. They will work to be productive and they will work to make the dollar that they want.

The Government is so intent on supporting a similar situation of absolute control. It says, `We know best'. As Mr Kelty says, the workers have to be protected from themselves. This is the Government's attitude. The Government says, `We have to make sure we protect the workers from themselves and they must abide by the Government's decision'. I would be most interested to see whether the Minister can possibly explain to us how this can improve the legislation that he originally drafted because, to my mind, it does not improve the legislation one iota.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to speak on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill because I thought that most of my views would be known through the way I voted on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I have to take exception to some of the views of Senator Walters. As a Tasmanian, I cannot allow her to tell this chamber and the community at large that the approach taken by the North Broken Hill-APPM management was the right way to go.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator Walters that, yes, due to enterprise bargaining over the years those workers have a 35-hour week, a 9 per cent superannuation scheme and, in the case of redundancy, four weeks pay for every year worked—not bad conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —And 25 per cent over-award.

—I say to the bawling, mewling Senator Walters across the chamber that she does not see the point I am making. Those conditions were gained through what were, in effect, enterprise bargains struck in their particular enterprise. They are not the product of the industrial relations club; they were struck there and then by that management and those particular unions for that particular operation. I understand why the management at APPM had to look at those conditions to see whether they affected its viability. I understand why the management needed to question some of the work practices and why it had the right to demand some changes in work practices in difficult and highly competitive times, especially when that operation is expected to move towards world competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: What I do not understand is a company that sat behind closed doors and carefully planned in-house a campaign which did not involve any further negotiation with the unions, which involved the most aggressive approach to the unions, which in fact said that the unions ought to be pushed out of all negotiations. I am also accepting in this place—for heavens sake, I am accepting of the Opposition's viewpoint more than it is of mine—that the unions have been slow and pig-headed at times in those negotiations. I accept that. I am not saying that the unions are perfect; I am saying that what they were giving up was the product of an enterprise bargain—those opposite should remember their policy about enterprise bargaining—struck between the enterprise unions and their representatives and that enterprise.

Now, suddenly, in the true traditions of enterprise bargaining, when that particular operation—that is, North Broken Hill-APPM—attempted to negotiate downwards, trouble struck. Why? Because it took the wrong approach. The company was frustrated with the unions' delays, and that is understandable. But, like a stupid teenage child who cannot get what he or she wants, the company then decided to do what my children call `chuck a Reggie'. It decided that it would go all in; it was crash through or crash.

Industrial relations is like all sorts of human relationships. It is about working together towards a goal, even when people come from different angles. In fact, these people were not coming from different angles—the work force in Burnie is pretty conservative. It puts Liberals back into the Parliament year after year. On the whole, they are not the red radicals that we would expect in some other places around Australia as was par for the course 20, 30 or 40 years ago. The work force of APPM is very conservative.

Yet this aggressive management, indoors, planned a campaign to cut the unions out completely, to unilaterally withdraw the very things it gave its unions and the workers before in that enterprise bargain. It planned it all carefully, but there was one problem: because APPM planned it in-house and because many companies tend to be fairly hierarchical no-one said, `Hang on a sec; there is a problem here. What if the unions don't behave according to plan? What if the unions say, "We would actually like to be included in the negotiations"? What if the ACTU says, "This question of cutting unions out of negotiations unilaterally is not a good idea"? What if the ACTU says, "This is a matter of very important national principle"?, and what if competitor companies agree with the ACTU?'. Nobody asked those questions in formulating this cosy little in-house plan.

I can imagine the company drawing up the sheets, typing up the tactics and the strategy it was going to follow. I have seen it before. I saw it with EZ in its bad days on the west coast at Rosebery when it tried that twice. Nobody thought about that by the look of it. So we ended up with what was a tragedy for Burnie and a tragedy for Tasmania's industrial relations reputation.

That one company did not realise that with the election of the Hawke Government nine years ago, industrial relations in this country changed overnight. They have moved towards the best examples around the world; statistically that has been proved. There is no doubt, as many employers have told me, that the ACTU has become a much more sophisticated organisation; that the union movement in general, including the ACTU, has lifted its game enormously and has taken on board a certain type of social and economic responsibility which goes far beyond its vested interests. This Government has invited it in because we know there is expertise there and because it has been willing to act responsibly in the community interest. The statistics are there to prove that. The commentaries about Australia's industrial relations record overseas, even from some of our competitors, have been very positive. What does Senator Walters want to do? She wants to go back to the bad old days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. Senator Aulich is giving us a blow by blow description of the past industrial relations problem at the Burnie APPM. I would suggest to you, Madam Chair, that that has nothing whatsoever to do with this Bill. As we are operating under a guillotine, I would point out to you that time is precious and ask you to ask Senator Aulich to address his remarks to the legislation before the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—I think that the previous speaker was also traversing some of the same area, but I would ask Senator Aulich to keep to the relevant matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Chair. I understand the concern of both you and Senator Boswell that I should take up time in this chamber that could valuably be used by members of the Opposition. I understand that. Senator Walters raised the issue; I did not. I said I was not going to get to my feet until Senator Walters got up and gave us a pen picture of the paradise for workers that would come about if the Liberal Party got into government. I think I am entitled to say, `No, I am sorry; on past experience that is not going to happen; on the experience of APPM, that is not going to happen; there is another way'.

PARA.TAB: I do not question the bona fides of a significant number of Opposition members. They are like everyone else. Some of them have been former employees; some of them have run businesses; some of them have had trouble with unions; and others have had very good relationships with unions. Opposition senators are varied and come from different backgrounds. The people I take exception to—the ones who oppose this Bill, many of whom are not in this chamber—are the people who say, `You know, the only way to solve industrial relations is to get it into the civil courts', to make sure there is a Mudginberri, a Dollar Sweets and all those other great cases where everyone wins, provided they are not affected personally; in other words, those people who say, `Let's have a big H.R. Nicholls bunfight; let's have a matter of principle debated and taken to the courts'.

What happened—and I am not going to answer this question for you—to all of those proprietors who did in fact end up in the courts with these major cases, like Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets and Troubleshooters? Where are they now? I can tell honourable senators where the people who advised them are, the people who pushed them into the fight—just as Senator Walters was talking about pushing people into the fight: they are still doing all right; they still have their comfortable positions; they are still walking around talking about industrial relations in terms so unrealistic that they would make Plato blush. They are okay. But the poor sucker who got dragged into that dispute to look after his so-called rights is not better off.

Which of those parties involved in any of those major disputes is better off? Is APPM better off? No. APPM now has a legacy of bad industrial relations which has totally wiped out the work that it has been doing over the years, all because it followed Senator Walters's approach. Unfortunately, Senator Walters is not unusual. She represents a very strong view within her political party. She has been rolled on a number of things, but I think that on this one she will agree with the very unrealistic, tough, one-sided approach that has been taken by a number of shadow Ministers in the industrial relations area. Maybe it is because the Opposition failed so dismally under Malcolm Fraser's Government that it is now jumping in a completely different direction—trying to be tough, and really intending to be tough, for the time when it gets into government one day.

The New Zealand model is not the way to go. New Zealand is a unitary state. It does not have to worry about States. There is one government. There is no upper House. It is very easy to push a Bill through its Parliament without an upper House discussing it in detail. It could get a new industrial relations system off the ground legally in a very short time.

It will not be that easy for Australia, with all its State governments and its bicameral Parliament. What will happen on the way? APPM found that it made a mistake. It tried to correct it, but it did so in a very bad way—an aggressive way that did not take into account the realities of industrial relations.

When we look at this Bill, we are looking at a number of big questions. Do we want legalism or things to work out by negotiation through the industrial relations forums? Do we want to go into the civil courts and sort it all out there, or do it another way? That is not to say that going into the civil courts is not sometimes necessary. We all know that the last thing we want to do is go to a court because, in terms of time, cost and predictability of results, the only people who have some idea of an answer to those three factors are the lawyers and no-one else—neither the plaintiff nor the defendant. We all know that and yet, somehow or other, knowing that, the Opposition is still pushing the line that legalism is the way to solve industrial relations problems.

This Bill involves the question of approach, not just specifics. It concerns how the whole Bill is framed. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has listened to the voices of all practitioners in the industrial relations area and the community. He has also listened to the voice of the 810,000 people who are currently not covered and do not get the protection that they deserve. A good industrial relations system gives security, protection and the right to be protected against exploitation. I believe that, in the long run, it gives management the right and the chance to manage in a responsible way. The options are there: we can go down the Opposition's route, or we can take the Government's route, which is an evolutionary approach to industrial relations that takes into account the fact that community expectations change. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Aulich must tell the truth. I will just go through a few points where he was not telling the truth.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. Senator Walters has been in this place since Adam was a boy, and she is starting to show it. My point of order is that she cannot say that I do not tell the truth. I ask you to ask her to withdraw that remark.

—I will not withdraw, Madam Temporary Chairman, because it is not unparliamentary to say that the honourable senator was not telling the truth. He was not, and I will give you the three instances when he was not. He said that I had said the company—
—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. Can I have an interpretation from you as to whether Senator Walters is at the moment making a point of order or continuing with her speech?
—I am continuing my speech.
—Does Senator Walters refuse to withdraw her statement that I do not tell the truth?
—Absolutely.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—It is a very fine line, but I understand that it is not actually ruled as unparliamentary to say that someone is not telling the truth or is telling an untruth. I fail to see the fine line that has been drawn in the past, but that is the precedent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of explanation on a point of order. Senator Walters can say that I do not tell the truth. If I said that Senator Walters is a liar, would that be accepted?
—No.
—So there is a difference. That is beyond my comprehension and maybe that of most senators in this chamber.
—It is beyond my comprehension as well, but that is the precedent, as I understand it.

—It is a shame. I thought Senator Aulich had been here long enough to understand Standing Orders, but obviously he has not. I will point out where Senator Aulich was not telling the truth. He said first of all that I had said the company had acted in a correct fashion. I did not say that.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I have waited for Senator Boswell to renew his point of order on the question of relevance. He has not done so; therefore, I raise it. Senator Boswell earlier took a point of order about these remarks being related to the Bill. I think you said at that point, Madam Temporary Chairman, that Senator Aulich was ranging a bit far and wide but that the issue he was talking about had been raised before. The issue has been raised before by Senator Walters and it is now being carried on with. This Bill is under guillotine, a point that Senator Boswell has made, and it would be useful for the services of this chamber if people directed themselves to the subject of the amendments rather than simply ranging far and wide. I think there has now been sufficient diversion into all the other issues for you to require Senator Walters to address the amendments before the Chair and be relevant to the issue.
—Madam Temporary Chairman, on the point of order: I will very briefly point out where Senator Aulich was wrong and untruthful in saying what he did regarding my personal speech.
—Are you seeking to make a personal explanation?

—I would prefer it to be in context; otherwise I will have to wait until the end of the debate. I do not think that is an appropriate place, at whatever hour we finish. I will not be more than about two minutes, if that. First of all, I did not say the company handled things correctly. I do not believe it did, but I did not say it did. Secondly, I did not even mention pushing people into a fight. At no stage did those words pass my lips. Nor did I say that it was a paradise for workers.

PARA.TAB: It is a pity Senator Aulich does not tell the truth. It would be much better, as a senator for Tasmania, if he did tell the truth about one of his colleagues there. I believe Senator Aulich was trying to avoid saying—and he would not say it—that the workers at APPM get a 25 per cent over-award payment. I touched very briefly on APPM. I was talking to the Bill and the subcontractors and every other issue associated with the legislation. Senator Aulich confined his remarks entirely to the APPM dispute for the whole quarter of an hour for which he spoke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Industrial relations is a subject that I have not spent a great deal of time on, but I am forced into this debate because I am worried about the consequences of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. I am worried about the small business operators—the 810,000 people whom Senator Aulich said needed protection. In my time I have built houses as a sideline and I have employed these people. I believe the building industry and all the other industries that use subcontract labour are terribly efficient. Small business people have never come to me saying that a contract they had signed was unfair or unconscionable. I have interceded on behalf of a number of small business people from all walks of life, particularly when the National Party was in government in Queensland. Small business used to beat a path to my door on many issues, but never once did building subcontractors or any other subcontractors come and say, `Look, we need union protection'. In fact, the opposite was the case: they tried to avoid the unions like the plague, and they still do.

PARA.TAB: I employed people. I never questioned whether they were in a union. I always believed it was up to them. In fact, at one stage the transport union threatened to blackball me because I would not insist that my workers join a union. I said, `If you want to talk to them, you go and talk to them. You are quite within your rights to go into my factory and talk to them'. I was told that if they did not join a union no-one would pick up goods I wanted to send and I would be black-banned. I said, `If you want to do that, go ahead'. I must not have been a big enough fish to worry about because the black ban never took place.

I am at a loss to understand this Bill. It says that the way for any small business operator—whether he be a carpenter, an electrician, a plumber or whatever—to get out of this is by incorporating or forming a proprietary limited company. I would suggest that the accountants and solicitors will do very well out of this legislation. I do not know what it costs to form a corporate company now. It was around $1,000 when I was in business and it is probably a lot more now. I do not think it is $40,000. Did Senator Bell say $40,000?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I didn't interject.
—I am sorry, I thought Senator Bell was indicating that it was a lot more than I thought it was. An independent contractor has only to incorporate. As the amendment to the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: To avoid doubt, it is declared that a reference in this Act to an independent contractor is confined to a natural person.

If those people incorporate they avoid this legislation. So one has to question what the legislation is about. Why is the Government going ahead with this legislation? Is it just a sop to the unions or is it a sop to the accountants and solicitors who will make a fortune out of it? What will it actually achieve? It has an escape clause a mile wide which every small business operator will use.

PARA.TAB: Having telegraphed that to the Minister, I hope he is not going for his pencil to try to work out an amendment on the run. I ask him to inform the chamber what he is on about, because every small business operator will incorporate and then this legislation will not apply to him. All it will probably cost him is another $3,000 or $4,000 which will inevitably be added onto the cost of the next building he is constructing, or the wiring, the plumbing, or whatever he is doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will certainly be passed on.

—It will be passed down the line. This legislation is just a nonsense. I do not believe it is required. I do not believe that anyone, except the unions, wants it. I cannot see why it is necessary. If the Government is going to support the unions, I cannot see why it has to have a gun at people's heads, virtually forcing them to incorporate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell, in his usual perceptive style, has raised the issue of why we need to bring in legislation dealing with subcontractors. All this trouble arose out of the case of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia and Others v. Odco Pty Ltd.
—You mean Troubleshooters, in other words.

—Yes, Troubleshooters; that was very perceptive of Senator Calvert. On appeal the case was heard by the Full Court, comprising Justices Wilcox, Burchett and Ryan. In part of the judgment concerning the facts as found by Mr Justice Woodward, the Full Court had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: His Honour also found that the rates of pay offered to its workers were adjusted unilaterally each year by Troubleshooters without consultation with the workers who were nevertheless advised of each adjustment shortly before or immediately after it occurred.

In listening to this debate, the impression received from those on the other side is that they are talking about a contract that is agreed upon between two parties arguing about conditions. One side says, `We will offer you X dollars', and the other side says, `No, I want Y', and they settle on Z; or there is a discussion about conditions.
