There is some equality of bargaining between the parties involved. That was not the situation with Troubleshooters. In that case a body hire company, in effect, said to people, `We will arrange to get work for you on the basis that we set out'. The judgment further states, in talking about whether the relationship established was that of employee-employer or of contractor-subcontractor:

However, the agreement that Troubleshooters workers are not to receive annual leave or sick leave or any payment referable to those entitlements and that no deduction of income tax is to be made from their remuneration signifies a mutual intention that they are not to be regarded as employees.

The court used those tests to decide that they were not employees. But in using those tests the court indicated that the conditions that are necessary to protect workers were not part of the agreement that Troubleshooters put forward.

PARA.TAB: It has been asked: what disadvantage was there to people who worked under the conditions that were offered by Troubleshooters? We come in here and quite properly deal with policy. We deal with ideas and we mention cases from time to time. I have heard of cases where people have worked under the Troubleshooters contract and have been injured. Through you, Mr Chairman, I would be interested to hear what Senator Crane has to say about this. When one hears of a family man of 28 who receives an injury and is thereafter not entitled to any workers' compensation is left bereft of any aid by way of money, bereft of any ability to work and bereft of any of those entitlements that he would get as an employee, the rosy picture that is sometimes painted in this chamber is shown to be flawed.

The danger in the subcontracting cases where those subcontracts are of the sort put forward in the Troubleshooters case is that the people are very vulnerable to injury and to being left bereft of any benefits if they should be injured. It is incumbent upon this Government—indeed I would have thought it would be incumbent upon this chamber—to see that those sorts of people are protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any government.
—Any government. I thank the honourable senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to comment, but now that Senator Cooney has raised the Troubleshooters case, I would just like to put something straight. I certainly would not say that my colleague Senator Cooney was talking in the way that Senator Walters accused Senator Aulich of speaking. I would like to quote from evidence we had yesterday in the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. A representative from Troubleshooters came along to talk to us. He quoted from the High Court's judgment on page 26. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The conditions under which Troubleshooters men work have to be compared and contrasted with those of employees in the industry generally. It is necessary here to consider, first, the VBIA and then certain industrial awards.

Troubleshooters raised a question which has been raised by Senator Cooney. It said that it represents 10,000 subcontractors through its agency, and they are all union members. It challenged the unions during the court case to present one disadvantaged worker. The unions did not present one disadvantaged worker. Troubleshooters made the point that, instead of being victimised and hounded by the unions, it should have been given a medal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just witnessed in the committee stage of this Bill a substitute second reading debate by a number of senators who have taken this opportunity to perambulate far and wide their views about industrial relations. I think it is also true to say that most of what they have said has no relevance whatsoever to the amendment before the Chair or, indeed, little relevance to anything in the Bill. However, that has never been a reason why people do not speak on industrial relations. I think it is a reasonable observation to make that every time the subject of industrial relations is raised, prejudices are excited and bigotries are spouted. This occasion has been no different.

PARA.TAB: A couple of senators have prefaced their remarks with the words, `I know nothing about industrial relations', and then proceeded to tell us the nothing that they know. I would enjoin them to go and find out before they speak. Senators Bell, Boswell and Cooney have directed themselves to the amendment, or something close to the amendment, and I think they deserve some acknowledgment and reply from the Government.

The amendments that are before the committee now are supported by the extreme organisations—the HIA and the Small Business Association. They are also strongly supported by the National Employers Forum. The Government has made these amendments after long discussion and a declaration of intent by the Australian Democrats. These amendments are not supported by the ACTU, and the ACTU has made that publicly clear.

In the face of all that, it is passing weird that not one Opposition speaker has indicated support for these amendments. The tenor of the remarks of all the speakers is that they are opposed to them. I would be grateful to know—and I would prefer it to be shown by the vote rather than yet another intervention—whether the coalition will support the Government in making amendments which are supported by the employers and opposed by the ACTU, or whether they will oppose the amendments and support the ACTU against the Government and the employers. Not one Opposition speaker has indicated what the Opposition's intention is, and I am interested to know that.

The second thing I want to remark on is the fact that, by virtue of these amendments, what we retain as a Bill dealing with independent contractors is a more narrowly drawn version of that which exists in New South Wales legislation—legislation enacted under the Greiner Government last year. Given the excitability of the remarks made by honourable senators opposite, I would be interested to know why they never raised these questions and objected when the Greiner Government did it but do now raise these questions when we do it and provide for a national reflection of existing New South Wales State legislation.

The amendments we now have strip the Bill of the section that would have dealt with the broadening of the powers of the Industrial Relations Commission to determine what class of worker a contractor or a wages employee under an award should be for particular work. So the only part of the Bill that is left for independent contractors is that part which confers on the Commission the power to find in a particular case raised by an individual who may or may not be a union member whether the contract is harsh and unfair and, if it finds it is harsh and unfair, what will then rectify the contract to eliminate the harsh and unfair character of it.

I think that is a fairly straightforward, reasonably humane, socially desirable enactment of law. It makes the law simple, accessible and reasonable for the ordinary person. So I would be interested in hearing from the Opposition whether it supports a simple, accessible, easy process to be engaged in to deal with harsh and unfair contracts or whether it does not support that and thus upholds harsh and unfair contracts as reasonable contracts. The question here is: does the Opposition want harsh and unfair contracts to be able to be dealt with simply, accessibly and easily or not? I have not heard from the Opposition where it stands on that. I am pretty sure that all of the people who work in the contract system would like to know whether, if they have been victims of a harsh and unfair contract, there is a way of remedying that.

Before I resume my seat, and because the debate is shortly to be adjourned, as I understand it, I would like to refer to a number of remarks made on the broad sweep of issues which are, as I have said, not relevant. I do not want to be marked down as agreeing with the irrelevancies that have been trotted out tonight simply by not replying seriatim to each one of them. I will not bother to reply to them other than to fall back on my second reading speech and my reply to the second reading debate as well.

However, I will not let one remark go. I do think it is incumbent on me in all seriousness to reply to the remarks made by Senator Walters. I ask Senator Walters to make her remarks outside the chamber if she has any courage. I am sure she will not; that would be typical of her. She referred to the fact—a fact declared in my interests and lodged so that it is publicly accessible—that I am a member of the BWIU. I certainly was a member of the BWIU, and of that I am proud. She then went on to say that a BWIU organiser, in unnamed circumstances, threatened the life of an individual should the father or mother of that individual not comply to a certain thing. I want to have clear, in the first instance, whether Senator Walters is saying that I put my former membership of the BWIU above my oath of office as a Minister of the Crown to discharge the duties of government fairly and properly. If she is saying that, I ask her to say it outside and I will win a huge settlement from her for libel.

Secondly, I say that it is reprehensible in the extreme that she should trot out this allegation and then bracket that, in circumstances known to her but apparently not reported by her to the proper judicial authorities or the police for prosecution, with this event about so-called life threatening behaviour. I in no sense support illegal acts and have stood strongly against them wherever they have occurred, including within the union movement from time to time as they occurred: witness my move to deregister the BLF for that reason.

I in no sense accept any allegation or imputation that I am involved in that sort of threat. I think it is reprehensible and disgusting that Senator Walters should suggest that. If she were courageous enough to do so outside, I would again achieve a large settlement from her. I move:
That progress be reported.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the death of Brett Whiteley who is, of course, a great loss to Australian art. Brett Whiteley became a very important artist in the 1960s. His exhibition in London at that time was hailed as a major success. He was a great fan of Francis Bacon, who also died recently. He became a great friend of Bacon's in London and painted portraits of him. Whiteley's iconic images of Sydney, of his view of Sydney from his studio in Lavender Bay, are exhibited prominently in the Art Gallery of New South Wales and have proved extremely popular with visitors to the Gallery, as was his collection of drawings of the Pont Neuf shown in recent times. In fact, there was often more interest in them than whatever large showings were on view in the main areas. During the period when he was influenced heavily by Van Gogh, he produced paintings of great worth.

PARA.TAB: Brett Whiteley was a popular artist. Members of the general public certainly knew his name, his paintings, his style and his face better than any other modern artist since Nolan. Until recently, I was fortunate to have two outstanding line drawings by Brett Whiteley on the wall of my office, one a lascivious outline of a woman eating an ice-cream and, the other, the back view of a female nude—both outstanding line drawings. However, there were conflicting views of Brett Whiteley's genius. Bernard Smith, in his book Australian Painting, had this to say about Brett Whiteley:

SPEECH.PARA: Whiteley (b. 1939) was awarded the first prize in the young painters' section at the Bathurst show at the age of seventeen. At twenty-one, following three years study at Julian Ashton's, he gained an Italian Travelling Scholarship and (after some months in Italy) reached London in 1960 at the height of the brief vogue for Australian art. His work gained instant recognition from the moment it appeared in the Recent Australian Painting exhibition at the Whitechapel Gallery in June 1961. It was purchased by the Tate, the Contemporary Art Society and the Victoria and Albert Museum. In the next few months he exhibited in group shows in Germany, Amsterdam and Paris, rounding off the year by winning the International Prize at the Biennale des Jeunes, Paris, and representing Australia at a Young Painters' Convention organized in Paris by U.N.E.S.C.O. Since 1961 his work has been showing constantly on the international circuit and is widely known.
However, there were some other points made by Bernard Smith in his book Australian Painting which reveal a different side of Brett Whiteley. He went on:

Whiteley's early manner, revealed in his first one-man show held at the Matthiesen Gallery, London, in 1962, is cast in an abstract expressionist mould. . . But the temperature of Whiteley's hot-brown Australia was increased several degrees by the presence of fatty, tumescent forms poking about the rocks adventurously in a kind of primordial tumble. Erotic landscapes of this kind were being shown in Sydney at this time by Charles Reddington, Robert Hughes and others. The sexed-and-fleshed landscape is a mode which has continued to fascinate Whiteley, but into it he has added increasingly, in recent years, images of violence and death.
Those images appear to have caught up with Brett Whiteley the man. According to Bernard Smith:

Whiteley is an uncommonly good draftsman with a splendid feeling for space, placement and accent; indeed his natural gifts have much in common with those of Toulouse-Lautrec, but a tormenting ambition to attain a profundity which is obviously not for him lies at the source of his failure. It is in his drawings and graphics of animals that his natural abilities have been allowed to flow most easily, and these constitute his most lyrical and personal statements.

There is no doubt that Australian art has benefited enormously from the presence of Brett Whiteley. There is no doubt that he will leave a permanent mark on the Australian art scene, and there is also no doubt that the tragic nature of his death will create even more questions about what did drive Brett Whiteley, what genius was behind him, what monkeys were on his back, and what were the pressures which drove this man to produce such magnificent works of art and yet create such concerns, disappointments and depression that he obviously felt in his personal life. He will certainly be missed from Australian art, and he has contributed an immense amount to the history of Australian art.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to contribute to this debate, but Senator Baume's reference to `fatty, tumescent forms' captured my attention. As an observer of the Senate benches, it is a rather compelling image. I simply want to say that Brett Whiteley was an artist who achieved an enormous degree of recognition internationally as well as here in Australia. This is entirely deserved recognition. He was an astonishingly compelling draftsman; quite a luscious applier of paint in landscapes and portraiture—in fact in all forms of the painter's art.

PARA.TAB: It is distressing that he should have died in such tragic circumstances at what many people still regard as the height of his creative powers. I think all honourable senators would join with Senator Baume in expressing condolences to his friends and those who have suffered as a consequence of his premature and untimely death.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a statement at the national conference of the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia held on the Gold Coast recently that the Government would not intervene in or direct where superannuation funds invested their assets:
(1) What safeguards are in place to prevent superannuation funds investing their assets in `high risk' areas where they may lose all or part of their funds.
(2) What form of compensation, if any, will contributors to superannuation funds have if the fund they invest in becomes bankrupt.
(3) Will the superannuation funds be subject to independent auditing by the Federal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Occupational Superannuation Standards (OSS) legislation establishes operating standards for superannuation funds. The standards increase the protection of fund members' benefits. Of direct relevance to superannuation investments is the provision that superannuation funds should only be maintained for the purposes of providing benefits in the event of the retirement of the member, or for dependants in the event of the death of the member or for ancillary purposes. This definition underpins the `sole purpose' test for funds wishing to be eligible for tax concessions. The test entails certain safeguards for the investments of superannuation assets. Certain forms of investment (eg investment in the running of a business and speculative investments) would not generally satisfy the sole purpose test.

Other specific investment safeguards in the OSS legislation include standards regarding restrictions on loans to members, borrowing except for temporary finance purposes and in-house assets. Another investment standard is that fund investments should be made on an arm's length basis.

In addition, trustees of superannuation funds are subject to the `prudent man' requirement in trust/ trustee laws. This requires that trustees must take such care as an ordinary prudent person would take if he were minded to make an investment for the benefit of other people for whom that person felt morally bound to provide. This standard together with the general duty of trustees to act in the best interest of members entail that superannuation trustees invest assets to achieve the highest returns obtainable, consistent with acceptable levels of risk.

I would also draw the Senator's attention to the former Treasurer's Statement of 20 August 1991 that the Government wants to ensure there is an adequate prudential framework to improve the security of superannuation savings and that over the coming months it would announce a series of measures on prudential supervision of the superannuation industry.

(2) As announced in the Statement of 20 August 1991, the Government recognises that there is an obligation on it to provide an appropriate prudential framework for superannuation but does not believe that it can or should attempt to guarantee superannuation funds.

(3) Yes. Under the OSS legislation, a fund's accounts must be audited annually by an independent auditor for the fund to be eligible for concessional taxation treatment. However, the ISC supplements this self-assessment approach to the administration of the OSS legislation with audits of superannuation funds. The Government announced in the 1991 Budget Statement that additional resources would be given to the Commission to upgrade its audit function.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to recent court decisions that have thrown some doubt about the often fine distinction between capital and income, will the Capital Gains Cell of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) give a priority to issuing a determination as to the considered view of the ATO on capital gains/ income guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Commissioner of Taxation established the Capital Gains Tax Specialist Cell within the Australian Taxation Office to deal with and resolve the most difficult and complex issues involving the capital gains provisions of Part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. As part of its functions, the Cell issues Determinations as a means of quickly disseminating the ATO's views on the operation of those provisions.

Where the profit or any other amount received from a transaction is income under ordinary concepts, and the capital gains provisions also apply in respect of the receipt, the effect of subsection 160ZA(4) is that the amount will generally be assessable only as income. That is, the application of the capital gains provisions will rarely need to be considered.

Whether the profit or other amount received from a transaction is capital or income can only be determined in light of the facts of each transaction. The ATO has recently issued an Exposure Draft Taxation Ruling, EDR 72, "Income Tax: profits on isolated transactions" which considers the factors the ATO considers relevant in determining whether or not the profit is income.

As the question of the distinction between income and capital is one of interpreting the general income tax law, it is not a question with which the Capital Gains Tax Specialist Cell would generally deal. In addition, as the matter has been addressed by the Exposure Draft Taxation Ruling, the Commissioner has advised that the Cell will not also issue a determination on that matter.

Items of a good subject to quota may be imported either within quota, or out of quota. While items imported out of quota attract a lower tariff rate, they also incur a flat levy on each item. The flat levy is generally large compared to the import price, and

ANSWER.PARA: so the rate of duty payable is much more than on goods imported within quota.

Effective rates of assistance measure the net assistance to an industry's value added. TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice on 29 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the Australian Government's response to the recent report of the European Commission on Human Rights which deals with the violation of human rights by Turkey against the people of Cyprus.
(2) Does the Australian Government accept the conclusions of the European Commission on Human Rights that Turkey is guilty of violating various articles of the European Convention on Human Rights.

(3) What form of protest has the Australian Government made to the Turkish Government in view of this latest report concerning the human rights violations which Turkey has committed against the people of Cyprus.

(4) Is the Australian Government in any position to provide legal assistance to Australian citizens of Greek Cypriot background whose human rights have been violated by Turkey, particularly in regard to the deprivation of property and possessions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In response to an application (Application No. 8007/77) of the Republic of Cyprus against Turkey, the Report of the European Commission on Human Rights concerning Turkish human rights violations in Cyprus was adopted by the Council of Europe on 4 October 1983. The Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe decided to release the report publicly on 2 April 1992. I understand that in terms of procedure the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe has resolved to take no further action on the case. The Australian Government does not plan to take any action on the report.

(2) The Australian Government accepts the conclusions of the European Commission on Human Rights that Turkey violated various articles of the European Convention on Human Rights. The conclusions are in accordance with our understanding of the situation in Cyprus.

(3) Given the length of time since the Report was adopted by the Council of Europe and the decision of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe that no further action be taken on this case the Australian Government has not made any representations since the report was publicly released. The Australian Government, however, takes an active interest in the human rights situation in Cyprus. The Australian Government supports the United Nations Secretary-General's efforts to mediate a solution to the divisions which beset Cyprus. It is also monitoring the progress of the bipartisan Committee on Missing Persons. It is the hope of the Australian Government that both will aid in the swift resolution of the human rights problems in Cyprus.

On 26 February 1992, at the 48th Session of the Commission on Human Rights in Geneva, the leader of the Australian Delegation stressed that Australia fully supported the efforts of the United Nations SecretaryGeneral to achieve a settlement of the Cyprus problem. He went on to say that it was important that momentum towards a settlement be maintained, and that all parties continue to work towards narrowing their differences to achieve a comprehensive settlement.

(4) The Australian Government is not in a position to provide legal assistance to Australian citizens of Greek Cypriot origin who have been deprived of property and possessions in Cyprus. First, the Australian Government does not, as a general rule, provide legal assistance to Australian citizens involved in legal actions outside Australia. Secondly, the Australian Government has no substantive role to play because, under the relevant principles of international law, a government can only espouse such a cause to another government on behalf of a person who was a citizen of the pleading country at the time the loss or injury occurred and who was continuously a citizen of that country until the time representation was made.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Fishing: Russian Vessels in Great Australian Bight

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 April 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Russian fishing vessel authorised to carry out feasibility fishing operations in the Great Australian Bight (GAB) fishery:
(1) For what period of time does this special arrangement apply.
(2) What reports have been lodged in relation to: (a) the quantities; and (b) the species of fish taken during feasibility operations to date.
(3) What quantities of fish taken have been landed in Australian ports and in which ports.

(4) What proposals, if any, have been put forward for additional feasibility operations to be undertaken in the GAB fishery by either: (a) the joint venturers engaged in the current exercise; or (b) any other foreign interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The formal Agreement between the Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) and Trawling Industries (Australia) Pty Ltd, the joint venture company, was entered into on 25 February 1992 and is for a period of six months from that date or until terminated, whichever occurs first.

(2) The joint venture Agreement requires the company to ensure that the master of the vessel reports to the AFMA on every sixth day the catch details of the preceding six days fishing. The company also is required to complete a comprehensive trawl logbook which includes details of trawl shot locations, catch weights by species and details of discarded fish. In addition, two Commonwealth observers are required to be onboard the vessel at all times it is fishing inside the Australian fishing zone (AFZ). The Agreement also specifies that the company submit a detailed report of all fishing operations inside the AFZ after completion of those operations.

(3) The Agreement requires all fish taken inside the AFZ to be landed in Hobart and processed by Trawling Industries (Aust) Pty Ltd's associated processing companies: Tas Crays Pty Ltd and Blue Water Seafoods Pty Ltd. The quantity of fish landed so far is approximately 20,000 kilograms.

(4) AFMA has received no other proposals from either the joint venturers engaged in the current exercise or from any other foreign interests to undertake additional feasibility operations within the GAB trawl fishery.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 6 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the situation in southern Sudan where the government is continuing to oppress the Christian minority in breach of human rights conventions?

(2) Has the Anti-Slavery Society of Britain reported people taken captive in the military operations being forced into slavery, and will the Minister undertake to state the Australian Government's abhorrence of these actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Civil war continues in southern Sudan, where the Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA), led by John Garang, is seeking to persuade the Sudanese government to accept a constitutional arrangement which would guarantee full and equal political and economic rights for the Christian and animist minorities. The Sudanese government launched its latest offensive in southern Sudan early this year. A number of towns previously in SPLA hands have fallen to government forces. Peace talks commenced under the chairmanship of the Nigerian government in Abuja, Nigeria, on 26 May 1992. Discussions between the government and rebel factions have been procedural, but are now to cover regional revenue sharing, judicial practice, and religious freedoms. The Australian Government hopes that a peaceful solution to the civil war will soon be found.

Declining economic conditions in Sudan have been exacerbated by a combination of military conflict and drought. Recent estimates put the number of drought-affected and war-affected persons requiring urgent food assistance at about 7.2 million. In the South, the cash economy is virtually non-existent and the people have resorted to barter mechanisms. Communications systems have broken down and no transport is available apart from that provided by international aid organisations. The Australian Government was concerned by the decision taken by the Sudanese government in March 1992 to ban relief flights by international aid organisations. We welcomed the recent partial lifting of this ban, but we remain disturbed by the continuing harassment of international aid organisations. We have conveyed our concerns to representatives of the Sudanese government.

Despite assurances by the Sudanese government that all Sudanese citizens would be treated equally, the Christian minority in Sudan, which is based mainly in the South, has become increasingly alienated. The Catholic Church, for example, has complained that the education system is designed to convert the entire population to Islam, notwithstanding the existence of non-Arabic speaking, non-Muslim groups, which include not only Christians, but many animist tribal groups of southern Sudan.

Sudan is a party to the International Covenants on Civil and Political Rights and on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, and to the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination. It has signed, but not ratified, the Convention against Torture. The human rights situation in Sudan was considered by the Commission on Human Rights at its 47th and 48th sessions (1991 and 1992) under its confidential procedures.

Australia has made representations to the Sudanese Government on individual human rights cases and on the Sudanese government's forced mass relocation of displaced persons. In March this year, Sudan, when responding to representations the Australian Government had made on some individual human rights cases, issued an invitation to the Amnesty International Parliamentary Group (AIPG) to visit Sudan to obtain first-hand information about the human rights situation there.

During the recent visit to Australia of the (non-resident) Sudanese Ambassador to present credentials, I took the opportunity to express the Australian Government's concern about the difficulties faced by international aid organisations in delivering relief supplies and services and about the human rights situation in Sudan.

(2) The Anti-Slavery International Society for the Protection of Human Rights (ASI), a British-based human rights organisation, made submissions to the United Nations Working Group on Contemporary Forms of Slavery in 1987 and 1988 alleging that people taken captive in military operations in Sudan were being forced into slavery. ASI's 1988 annual journal also contained a report to this effect. It has not produced further reports or submissions on the subject since then. We understand that Africa Watch, an American-based human rights group, is monitoring the situation. Sudan is a party to the Slavery Convention of 1926 (as amended) and to the Supplementary Convention on the Abolition of Slavery, the Slave Trade and Institutions and Practices of Slavery.
The Australian Government shares, with the overwhelming majority of states, an abhorrence of slavery and unreservedly condemns its practice in all forms.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 14 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What guidelines are applicable to the broadcasting of violent or sexually explicit material on television.
(2) Would the same guidelines also apply to any pay television services that might be proposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Guidelines applicable to the broadcasting of violent or sexually explicit material on television are contained in Section 118 of the Broadcasting Act 1942 (the Act) and in program standards determined and administered by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT).

Section 118 of the Act states that the Corporation (ABC) or a licensee shall not broadcast matter which is blasphemous, indecent or obscene. The test of obscenity and indecency is whether the matter in question offends to a substantial degree the sexual modesty of the average man or woman in the Australian community or offends to a substantial degree the contemporary standards of decency currently accepted by the Australian community.

The ABT's Television Program Standards specify in broad terms what kinds of material may be shown at particular times of the day. The ABC is also required to take account of these standards in its provision of television services within Australia. A licensee must ensure that any program to be transmitted has assigned to it a classification (AO, PGR, G, C or P) which is appropriate. This classification is determined by criteria which specify the degree of violence, sex and nudity that can be portrayed and also indicates the times at which such programs may be broadcast. Other standards specify what is allowable in program promotions and during children's viewing time.

The ABT is currently conducting an Inquiry into Television Program Standard (TPS) 12 (Promotions for Programs) and undertaking a major review of its classification standards for programs and advertisements on commercial television.

As a result of a key recommendation of the ABT's Inquiry into Violence on Television (1988-1990), the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations in 1991 launched The Portrayal of Violence on Television: A Code of Industry Practice. This code which is agreed to and supervised by the ABT, deals specifically with the program areas in which violence is most commonly an issue. Whilst the Code itself contains no penalties or policing mechanisms, the Tribunal has scope to review broadcasters' performance in relation to the Code during licence renewals or if it has reason to believe that broadcasters are acting in serious or repeated disregard of the Code.

The ABT's review of the television coverage of the massacre at Strathfield by the Sydney commercial stations found that the industry's code had been applied successfully. The Tribunal received a minimal number of complaints about this coverage indicating, in their view, that the Code is being effectively applied.

(2) A decision in favour of Pay TV is not a green light for the transmission of pornographic material that offends community standards of taste and decency. The Government will not under any circumstances allow X-rated material to be screened on Australian television.

If R-rated programs are transmitted, this would be permitted only in conjunction with an approved technical lock-out device. These devices could comprise special smart cards that are issued only on request to adults, and/or personal identification numbers as many of us now use with our bank accounts. This would allow parents to control access by children to programs.

The Government has consistently stated that it does not foresee the circumstances whereby Pay TV programming would include anything that would offend against accepted community standards. Detailed regulatory provisions have been spelt out in the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992 that was introduced into the Senate on 4 June 1992. The Bill proposes that Codes of Practice be developed by all broadcasters in the area of program classification. The codes would be required to reflect the Office of Film and Literature Classification system. The codes must be registered with the regulatory authority, the Australian Broadcasting Authority. If they are not operating to provide appropriate community safeguards, mandatory program standards may be introduced by the Authority.
The regulatory authority will have significant powers to deal with breaches of standards and the provisions of the Act.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Touch Screen Equipment

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a trial by the Department of Social Security for clients to have access to touch screen computer terminals to check their Social Security benefits, has any information on the result of the trial been received and are there any plans to extend the trial to other public sector agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Department of Social Security, in conjunction with a company with expertise in this area, has been developing a touch screen system for use in the Department. To trial this technology a step by step guide to lodging claims under a number of the Department's income support programs is being developed and should be available before the end of June. During the trial it is planned to locate the touch screen equipment for part of the time in the Bellerive CES office Tasmania which is co-located with the Department of Social Security's Regional Office. This trial includes some community information which has been developed from local pamphlets. The next phase of the trial will be to develop a multi-lingual service. This will be located in the Cabramatta Regional Office, NSW. Plans for incorporating other government agencies' information have not been developed at this stage but if the trials show high acceptance of the touch screen technology this could certainly be pursued.
